THIS OFFERING IS AVAILABLE ONLY TO INVESTORS WHO ARE EITHER (1) QUALIFIED INSTITUTIONAL BUYERS (“QIBs”) WITHIN THE MEANING OF RULE 144A (“RULE 144A”) UNDER THE US SECURITIES ACT OF 1933, AS AMENDED (THE “US SECURITIES ACT”), OR (2) NON-US PERSONS ACQUIRING THE SECURITIES IN AN “OFFSHORE TRANSACTION” OCCURRING OUTSIDE THE UNITED STATES IN ACCORDANCE WITH REGULATION S (“REGULATION S”) UNDER THE US SECURITIES ACT AND, IN THIS CASE, ONLY TO INVESTORS WHO, IF RESIDENT IN A MEMBER STATE OF THE EUROPEAN ECONOMIC AREA (“EEA”) OR THE UNITED KINGDOM (THE “UK”), NOT A RETAIL INVESTOR (AS DEFINED BELOW).

Our operations comprise the following six business lines, each of which falls within three broader categories, and as such, we present them throughout this Offering Memorandum in this manner: ----- - rental activities at Pinewood Studios and Shepperton Studios, comprising Stage and Other Production Accommodation, Media Hub and Television Studios; - ancillary activities at Pinewood Studios and Shepperton Studios, comprising Post Production and Ancillary Studio Services; and - other activities, primarily consisting of International Sales and Marketing. Rental activities are by far the largest contributor to our business, accounting for 92.6% of Contribution for the twelve months ended September 30, 2021. Rental activities typically include income generated by the use of stages, workshops, offices, and TV studios. Demand for our ancillary activities, accounting for 6.0% of Contribution for the twelve months ended September 30, 2021, is driven in part by demand for our rental activities. These activities typically include post production services, recharging of utilities, and revenue/profit sharing arrangements with third-party providers. The chart below displays the percentage of our Contribution by business line for the twelve months ended September 30, 2021. A brief description of each of our business lines is set forth below. _Rental: Stage and Other Production Accommodation_ Our Stage and Other Production Accommodation business line relates to Pinewood Studios and Shepperton Studios. As our core business line, Stage and Other Production Accommodation drives the largest proportion of Contribution. Stage rental relates to the rental of stage space and infrastructure required to produce screen content. The stages are used to house the physical set on which action and sounds are recorded. Our stages come in a variety of sizes and types and are generally soundproofed and heated. Pursuant to the Long-term Contracts, 100% of our existing stage space at Pinewood Studios and Shepperton Studios has been contracted by Disney and Netflix, respectively. Other Production Accommodation rental primarily relates to the renting of office space and workshop space where sets are created or stored. Demand for Other Production Accommodation is typically driven by demand for our stages. Pursuant to the terms of the Long-term Contracts, 100% of our existing Other Production Accommodation space at Pinewood Studios and Shepperton Studios has been contracted by Disney and Netflix, respectively. See “Business—Material Contracts—Disney Long-term Contract” and “Business—Material _Contracts—Netflix Long-term Contract.”_ Stage and Other Production Accommodation as a percentage of Contribution has continued to increase with the completion of approximately 205,000 square feet of lettable space at Pinewood East Phase 2, which was completed in autumn 2019 (with one of the workshop blocks, totalling approximately 39,000 square feet, ----- completed in summer 2020), and will increase further by approximately 1.1 million square feet in aggregate upon completion of the five new stages at Pinewood West, Shepperton North West and Shepperton South development projects. Disney has pre-let the five new stages at Pinewood West as part of the Disney Long-term Contract and Netflix has pre-let approximately 60% of the space being developed at the Shepperton South studio. For more information on our Stage and Other Production Accommodation business line, see “Business—Our Business _Lines—Rental—Stage and Other Production Accommodation.” Rental: Media Hub_ We lease space on-site to independent companies that support film and television production. Pinewood Studios and Shepperton Studios offer approximately 228,000 square feet of space, to approximately 178 independent businesses as of September 30, 2021. The tenants pay rent directly to us and supply their services to the production companies filming at the studios, as well as to external “off-the-lot” customers. Tenants in our Media Hub benefit from association with our strong brand and proximity to their customer base. Historically, the Media Hub has been a secure source of Contribution. There is significant demand for on-site space, with occupancy rates averaging 95% over the past ten fiscal years to the fiscal year ended March 31, 2021. For more information, see “Summary—Our Key Strengths—Resilient and Cash Generative Business Model Now _Underpinned by Long-term Contracts.” All turnover generated under the Long-term Contracts is reported under_ Stage and Other Production Accommodation. Accordingly, at the commencement of the Long-term Contracts, certain turnover previously reported under the Media Hub business line moved to Other Production Accommodation with any reallocation of the demises in connection with the Long-term Contracts. For more information on our Media Hub business line, see “Business—Our Business Lines— Rental—Media Hub.” _Rental: Television Studios_ We have three dedicated Television Studios available to hire at Pinewood Studios, one of which is contracted to the National Lottery (Camelot). We have relationships with customers such as the BBC, Endemol Shine UK, Fremantle and Avalon, which contribute to the success of this business line. In addition to earning turnover from Television Studio space, we generate turnover from supplying freelance crew as well as owned and hired television equipment. The Television Studios at Pinewood Studios are excluded from the Disney Long-term Contract and we will continue to manage and hire the Television Studios on a case-by-case basis. For more information on our Television Studios business line, see “Business—Our Business Lines—Rental—Television _Studios.” Ancillary: Ancillary Studio Services_ Ancillary Studio Services comprise additional services utilised by production companies hiring Stage and Other Production Accommodation. The key services we provide in this business line are utilities (for example, we offer electricity, water and gas, which are principally passed through at cost to our long-term contract customers) and other services through revenue or profit-sharing agreements with preferred third-party service providers. For more information on our Ancillary Studio Services business line, see “Business—Our Business _Lines—Ancillary—Ancillary Studio Services.” Ancillary: Post Production_ Post Production provides support to content creators. This business line includes localisation services which offer audio mixing in multiple languages for our customers requiring international re-versioning services. In addition, through this business line we offer our customers mixing theatres, cutting rooms, and production offices available for dry hire at Pinewood Studios and Shepperton Studios, all of which are excluded from the Long-term Contracts. For more information, see “Business—Our Business Lines—Ancillary—Post Production.” _Other Activities_ We also generate turnover by providing sales, marketing and brand licensing services and consultancy services relating to studio space to other studios around the world. Historically, we provided these services to studios in Atlanta, Canada, China, the Dominican Republic, Malaysia, and Wales. On August 5, 2019, we divested our equity interest in Pinewood Atlanta Studios, although we continued to provide sales and marketing services until October 14, 2020, and it ceased to be a Pinewood branded studio on December 14, 2020. We separately ceased providing services to studios in Malaysia in July 2019 and in Wales on March 31, 2020. -----

We are one of the leading independent providers of the infrastructure that is required to produce film and television content. Founded in 1936 and headquartered in the United Kingdom, we own premium, large-scale facilities, also known as studios, for hosting film, television and other media productions. Our two freehold studios, Pinewood Studios and Shepperton Studios, are set over 502 acres with approximately 2.0 million square feet of space in close proximity to central London, which makes us a preferred choice for major film production companies. Pinewood Studios and Shepperton Studios are valued at a Market Value of £2,158 million pursuant to the Valuation Report. Pinewood-branded studios have hosted over 2,000 films, which have received among them 170 Oscar awards and 230 BAFTA awards and include numerous blockbuster film productions such as 23 out of the 25 James Bond films, 16 out of the 27 Marvel super hero films and 8 out of the 12 Star Wars films. We signed long-term index-linked contracts for 100% of our Stage and Other Production Accommodation at Pinewood Studios and Shepperton Studios with Disney and Netflix, respectively in 2019. Collectively, these Long-term Contracts cover a total of approximately 1.6 million square feet. These contracts are each for an initial term of at least ten years and provide for annual rent increases, subject to floors. Disney utilises Pinewood Studios for its own productions as well as for its affiliated production companies, including Lucasfilm and Marvel. Netflix utilises Shepperton Studios as a production hub to produce original content. The Long-term Contracts simplify our business model, improve the resilience and visibility of our turnover from investment-grade rated tenants, and demonstrate the continued demand for our facilities at Pinewood Studios and Shepperton Studios. See “Business—Material Contracts—Disney Long-term Contract” and “Business—Material _Contracts—Netflix Long-term Contract.”_ Demand for purpose-built studio space remains extremely strong. Over the last few years, we have been progressing our expansion plans at our UK studios, Pinewood Studios and Shepperton Studios. Construction is currently underway for five new stages at Pinewood Studios that will provide approximately 100,000 square feet of additional stage space at Pinewood West, which we anticipate opening in 2022. Disney has pre-let these stages pursuant to the Disney Long-term Contract. At Shepperton Studios, we have detailed planning consent to develop an additional approximately 1.0 million square feet of lettable area, adjacent to the existing studio. We intend to develop this expansion in two phases, which we refer to as Shepperton North West and Shepperton South. Construction of both phases is underway and we have entered into fixed price contracts for the works, thereby significantly derisking the execution of these projects. Additionally, we entered into a long-term contract with Netflix to pre-let approximately 0.5 million square feet of space, equivalent to 60% of the space being developed, at our Shepperton South studio. The lease will commence on completion of the development, expected towards the end of 2023, and is on terms similar to the Netflix Long-term Contract. There is strong interest from several customers for the remaining approximately 0.5 million square feet being developed at Shepperton. In the twelve months ended September 30, 2021, Contribution from Stage and Other Production Accommodation, together with the specialty stages, accounted for 83.8% of total Contribution. We earned 98.6% of our total Contribution for the twelve months ended September 30, 2021 in the United Kingdom, with 92.6% representing rental income at Pinewood Studios and Shepperton Studios, our two freehold studios.

Subsubsection Title: Resilient and Cash Generative Business Model Underpinned by Long-term Contracts
Subsubsection Text: As a result of the Long-term Contracts, 100% of the Group’s existing Stage and Other Production Accommodation is under contract for an initial term of at least ten years, providing long-term visibility on future turnover. In the twelve months ended September 30, 2021, Contribution from Stage and Other Production Accommodation, together with the specialty stages, accounted for 83.8% of total Contribution. Rent under the Long-term Contracts is linked to UK RPI, with annual rental rate increases. See “Business—Material Contracts.” Our Long-term Contracts have not been impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic. Prior to entering into the Long-term Contracts, our studios had a long history of consistently operating at what we believe to be our structural maximum occupancy levels under a model of short-term hire agreements. In addition, our Media Hub business line has also demonstrated consistently high occupancy rates historically. For the past ten fiscal years, our Media Hub business line occupancy rates averaged 95%. For more information, see “Business—Our Business Lines—Rental—Media Hub.” We have a proven track record of stable or growing Adjusted EBITDA generation, including during both the global financial crisis and the COVID-19 pandemic. We also benefit from high Adjusted EBITDA margins. For example, we had an Adjusted EBITDA margin of 64% for the twelve months ended September 30, 2021 and 65% for the fiscal year ended March 31, 2021. The high Adjusted EBITDA margins are attributable to our business model focused on providing infrastructure related offerings. Our Adjusted EBITDA margin tends to increase as we expand the space at our existing studios while leveraging on our existing central and operative functions. In addition, our results benefit from having ceased a number of low margin or loss-making activities. See “— _Summary Historical Financial Information and Other Data—Statistical, As Adjusted and Other Financial Data.”_ (1) Joint ventures were proportionally consolidated in accordance with UK GAAP until the fiscal year ended March 31, 2013; from the fiscal year ended March 31, 2014, joint ventures were accounted for under the equity method in accordance with IFRS. Our year-end was December 31 until 2010. Adjusted EBITDA for the year ended December 31, 2011 was based on interim results for twelve-month period ended Dec 31, 2011. The fiscal year ended March 31, 2013 reflects a twelve-month fiscal year ending on March 31, 2013. In 2021 we entered into an agreement for lease with Netflix in respect of stages, workshops and offices at Shepperton Studios in relation to the Shepperton Expansion Project. See “Business—Material Contracts— _Netflix Shepperton South Long-term Contract.” For the twelve months ended September 30, 2021, our Pro Forma_ Adjusted EBITDA would have been £94.3 million, giving pro forma effect to the anticipated EBITDA effects of certain pre-leased space currently being constructed as part of the expansion projects to be funded in connection with the Offering and adding back the effect of certain costs related to the UK Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme, ----- as illustrated in the table below. For a reconciliation of Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA, see “Summary Historical Financial Information and Other Data—Statistical, As Adjusted and Other Financial Data.” We have averaged over 93% cash conversion over the past three fiscal years ended March 31, 2021, calculated as Adjusted EBITDA less maintenance capital expenditure as a percentage of Adjusted EBITDA. Maintenance capital expenditure has averaged approximately £3.4 million per annum for the three fiscal years ended March 31, 2021. In addition to this maintenance capital expenditure, we recognised an average of approximately £4.3 million of maintenance spend per annum as an expense within indirect costs for the three fiscal years ended March 31, 2021. See “—Summary Historical and Financial Information and Other Data— _Statistical, As Adjusted and Other Financial Data.”_

Subsubsection Title: World Class Facilities with Significant Freehold Backing
Subsubsection Text: We own the freehold interest of both Pinewood Studios and Shepperton Studios, which are valued at a Market Value of £2,158 million pursuant to the Valuation Report. Pro forma for the remaining capex expected to be incurred for the Shepperton Expansion Project and new stage construction at Pinewood West, the adjusted valuation would be £2,672 million. This valuation is supported by the Disney Long-term Contract and the Netflix Long-term Contract which ensure 100% occupancy of our current Stage and Other Production Accommodation for the duration of the contracts, each of which has an initial term of at least ten years as well as the Netflix Shepperton South Long-term Contract. Pinewood Studios and Shepperton Studios are the two largest independent studios in the United Kingdom with a combined approximate 2.0 million square feet of space set over 502 acres and 25 and 14 stages, respectively, close to central London and Heathrow airport. Pinewood Studios is one of the largest independently operated studios in the world in terms of stage space, with approximately 1.4 million square feet of total space on an approximately 379-acre site. It currently has two facilities, Pinewood West and Pinewood East. Shepperton Studios has approximately 600,000 square feet of total space situated on an approximately 123-acre site. It currently has one facility, Shepperton North, and two additional facilities under development, Shepperton North West and Shepperton South. Our studios are capable of hosting productions of various budgets simultaneously. We believe, however, that production companies view our studios as a premium offering well suited for large budget productions, for release either in theatres or on streaming platforms, given the extent and quality of the infrastructure available. Our studios feature a wide range of different size purpose-built stages, workshops, and offices as well as specialised facilities such as exterior and interior water tanks, backlots, television stages, and post production facilities. We further believe that our operational capabilities, resulting from decades of experience running a secured environment, providing 24/7 access where the most demanding production companies can operate, also differentiates us from most of our competitors. -----

Subsubsection Title: Market Leading Position and Iconic Brand
Subsubsection Text: The Pinewood brand is globally recognised with over 80 years’ experience, over which Pinewoodbranded studios have hosted iconic film moments. A selection of the films and High-end TV we have hosted includes: 1960s: Six _James Bond_ films including _Dr. No_ (the first _James Bond_ film), _Lawrence of Arabia, Dr. _Strangelove, 2001: A Space Odyssey, To Sir, with Love, and Chitty Chitty Bang Bang_ 1970s: _Superman, Fiddler on the Roof, The Great Gatsby, The Thirty Nine Steps, The Omen and Alien 1980s: _Batman, Superman II, Gandhi, Full Metal Jacket, Out of Africa, Blade Runner, The Princess Bride and Aliens 1990s: _Robin Hood: Prince of Thieves, Interview with the Vampire, Patriot Games, The Fifth Element, _Mission Impossible and The Mummy_ 2000s: _Gladiator, Charlie and the Chocolate Factory, Love Actually, Casino Royale, The Da Vinci Code, _The Bourne Ultimatum and Mamma Mia!_ 2010: _Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part I, Clash of the Titans and Robin Hood 2011: _Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows, X-Men: First Class and_ _Pirates of the Caribbean: On _Stranger Tides_ 2012: _Snow White and the Huntsman, The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey and Skyfall 2013: _Thor: The Dark World, Fast and Furious 6 and Gravity 2014: _Exodus: Gods and Kings, Maleficent and Guardians of the Galaxy 2015: _Spectre, The Avengers: Age of Ultron and Star Wars: The Force Awakens (Episode VII) 2016: _The Huntsman: Winter’s War, Assassin’s Creed and Rogue One: A Star Wars Story 2017: _Star Wars: The Last Jedi (Episode VIII), The Mummy and Kingsman: The Golden Circle 2018: _Jurassic World: Fallen Kingdom, Mamma Mia! Here We Go Again and Mary Poppins Returns 2019: _Star Wars: The Rise of Skywalker (Episode IX), Rocketman,_ _Dumbo and The Innocents (Season 1) 2020: _1917, Criminal (Season 2), The Expanse (Season 5), The Old Guard and The Midnight Sky 2021: _No Time To Die, RuPaul’s Drag Race UK (Series 2), The Dig, Old, Cruella, Jupiter’s Legacy, _Cinderella, Eternals and Black Widow_ Between 2010 and 2021, 83 out of 274 blockbuster films were filmed at Pinewood-branded studios, representing 30% of all blockbuster films for that period. Among these 83 productions, 71 were filmed in the United Kingdom at Pinewood Studios and Shepperton Studios and the remaining 12 were filmed at Pinewood Atlanta Studios and Pinewood Toronto Studios. -----

Subsubsection Title: Total Blockbuster Films and Proportion Filmed at Pinewood (2010-2021)[(1)]
Subsubsection Text: Source: Industry sources. (1) Includes blockbuster films that were filmed at Pinewood Atlanta Studios, a studio we divested our equity interest in on August 5, 2019 and which ceased to be a Pinewood branded studio on December 14, 2020. For more information, see “Business—Our Business Lines—Other Activities—International Sales and Marketing” and_ “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations —Key Factors Affecting Comparability of _Future Results of Operations—Exit from Joint Ventures and Third-Party Studio Licenses—Pinewood Atlanta Studios Joint Venture and Management Services Agreement.”_

Our customers operate in a market with strong underlying demand, which is driven by consumption of content, principally blockbuster films and from online streaming platforms. In recent years, and particularly during the COVID-19 pandemic, demand for content from streaming platforms has accelerated. To match this demand, OTT operators have significantly increased their investments in content production. The number of streaming platforms has multiplied in recent years, and operators continue to invest considerably in streaming content, such as Disney, Apple, NBCUniversal and Warner Media. Disney has invested in Disney+, its own direct-to-consumer streaming platform, and expects their investment in original content for this streaming platform to exceed $8 billion by 2024, more than double the amount that was estimated in April 2019. When Disney launched Disney+ in November 2019, 10 million people subscribed on the first day. Disney+ had 87 million subscribers as of September 30, 2021 and is targeting between 230 and 260 million subscribers by 2024. In 2019, Apple increased its committed spending for original video content over the next several years from $1.0 billion to $6.0 billion. NBCUniversal, owned by Comcast, launched its own OTT platform, Peacock, in April 2020 and had 19 million subscribers as of September 2021. Warner Media also launched its own OTT platform, HBO Max, in May 2020 and had 58 million subscribers as of June 2021. In 2021, Warner Media announced that it would premiere 17 movies simultaneously in theatres and on HBO Max in the United States. Collectively Disney, Apple, NBCUniversal, Comcast and Warner Media have over 100 million subscribers to their OTT platforms. We believe long-term planning associated with spending on original content by OTT operators and on franchise films (such as the Marvel super hero franchise, Star Wars or James Bond), has resulted in larger and more predictable annual slates for a number of production companies. Consequently, such production companies are often committing to take production space further in advance of filming (traditionally three months in advance and now up to twelve months in advance). On the back of this demand, in 2019 we entered into the Long-term Contracts with Disney and Netflix who occupy space at Pinewood Studios and Shepperton Studios. As we continue to see favorable demand-supply fundamentals for purpose-built studio infrastructure, in 2021 we entered into a new long-term contract with Netflix to pre-let approximately 0.5 million square feet of space, equivalent to 60% of the space being developed, at our Shepperton South studio. -----

The ability to attract large budget productions requires a complex ecosystem, including comprehensive infrastructure with excellent operations, a highly skilled English-speaking workforce (ideally based in close proximity to the studio), good transport links (particularly by air), and a location close to an international city where talent is willing to reside. We benefit from infrastructure developed over decades of hosting films, with a multitude of stage options, as well as a specialist underwater facility, a paddock tank and backlot sites for outdoor filming, ample workshop and office space, businesses on-site providing services to production companies, theatres on-site for post-production editing and convenient transport links. We also benefit from a convenient location, with both Pinewood Studios and Shepperton Studios approximately one hour from central London and approximately 30 minutes from Heathrow airport. Aside from convenience for our customers, being located close to central London offers certain other strategic advantages. According to the Office for National Statistics, as of 2020 there were approximately 65,967 film and video production workers in the United Kingdom, with an estimated 66% based in London and South East England, which is a draw for major film production companies seeking a location to produce blockbuster films or Highend TV. The production sector workforce has increased by approximately 78% since 2010, at a CAGR of approximately 6%. The production sector workforce has increased by 3% since 2017, at a CAGR of approximately 1%. Whereas studios in many other jurisdictions may require the transport and accommodation of film crews at significant cost, filming at Pinewood Studios and Shepperton Studios provides proximate access to producers, directors, actors, cinematographers and a large skilled worker base including, among others, technicians, engineers, carpenters, make-up artists and wardrobe specialists. Top talent, including producers, directors and cast, are also attracted to London as a filming destination and temporary residence while filming. While there are a number of proposed new studios at various stages of development in the United Kingdom, we believe that any potential competitor would still experience difficulties in locating and developing similarly-sized, well-located sites near central London due to scarcity of land, planning restrictions, high alternative land use values and high build costs. Even if such a site were available, the considerable time and expense required to build similar infrastructure to that of Pinewood Studios and Shepperton Studios, is likely to deter most new market entrants. Additionally, we benefit from relationships with multiple major film production companies spanning decades and such relationships cannot be easily or quickly replicated by new market entrants. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business.”

Subsubsection Title: Importance of Creative Industries to the UK Economy
Subsubsection Text: The United Kingdom’s success in the creative industries is driven by a wide range of specialist subsectors, creating a rich, cross-disciplinary environment for collaboration and innovation. The creative industries are defined by DCMS to include film and television production, software services, music, the performing arts, advertising and marketing, publishing, and design. Employment in the creative industries grew at a CAGR of 4% between 2011 and 2021. In 2021, the creative industries employed over two million people, or about 7% of the United Kingdom’s work force. Within the United Kingdom creative industries, film and video production constitutes an important driver of employment, economic output and exports. In recent years, the United Kingdom has benefited from increase in production spend. According to BFI, production spend on UK feature films and High-end TV increased at a CAGR of 15% between 2017 and 2021. Inward investments continue to drive the overall spending with bigger budget films taking space in the United Kingdom.

Subsubsection Title: Solid Growth Potential with Demonstrated Track Record of Development
Subsubsection Text: We have achieved consistent growth over the past several years, with Adjusted EBITDA increasing from £44.7 million in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2019 to £64.0 million in the twelve month period ended September 30, 2021. This growth has principally been driven by our core rental business with steady demand-led increases in our rental rates, increased occupancy and investment in the business. A significant driver in our ability to generate cash has been our track record of pre-letting and completing development projects on time and within budget. For example, (i) in 2016, we developed approximately 300,000 square feet in connection with Pinewood East Phase 1, and (ii) in 2019, we developed approximately 205,000 square feet in connection with Pinewood East Phase 2 (with one of the workshop blocks, totalling approximately ----- 39,000 square feet, completed in summer 2020). Pinewood East Phase 1 and Pinewood East Phase 2 were leased prior to or immediately after completion, demonstrating our track record of accurately assessing demand and judicious approach to development. In recent years, we have experienced, and continue to experience, excess demand which we believe we will be able to accommodate through further expansion of our existing studios. At Pinewood Studios, we have planned for future revenue growth through pre-letting five sound stages, currently under construction, to Disney and through obtaining planning consent for the future development of Pinewood East Phase 3. Additionally, we own two undeveloped land sites adjacent to the existing facilities totalling approximately 165 acres, which we may use for development in the future. At Shepperton Studios, we are pursuing an expansion on the undeveloped land adjacent to the existing facilities totalling approximately 97 acres, which would add a further approximately 1.0 million square feet of space. The expansion has been substantially de-risked with the long-term contract with Netflix and the signing of a fixed price contract for the construction. Collectively, these projects will allow us to nearly double our stage space in the United Kingdom, allowing us to maintain our market leading position.

Subsubsection Title: Focus on Our Core Business Lines: Offering the Infrastructure Required for the Production of Film and Television Content
Subsubsection Text: In the last four years, we: (i) eliminated several non-core activities, including Media Investment, (ii) rationalised our international presence by exiting our 40% equity interest in Pinewood Atlanta Studios as well as terminated our agreements for studios in Wales and Malaysia, and (iii) entered into the Long-term Contracts, derisking our future Stage and Other Production Accommodation turnover. We intend to continue to remain focused on providing the infrastructure required to produce film and television content and providing exceptional customer service. To achieve this, we recognise that our people, processes, and systems are fundamental to our success, and we continue to invest in each of these aspects of our business.

Subsubsection Title: Continue to Expand Our Footprint at Pinewood Studios and Shepperton Studios
Subsubsection Text: In autumn 2019, we completed the development of Pinewood East Phase 2, comprising approximately 205,000 square feet of stage, workshop and office space (with one of the workshop blocks, totalling approximately 39,000 square feet, completed in summer 2020). The entire development is included in the demise of the Disney Long-term Contract. Looking ahead, we are actively pursuing various expansion projects at Pinewood Studios and Shepperton Studios that will allow us to meet the stable, excess demand for our facilities. The United Kingdom, with its established ecosystem and stable tax incentives, remains one of the most attractive markets for major film production companies and streaming platforms to produce content. We believe that our established locations, combined with the existing infrastructure at our UK studios, afford us a competitive advantage. At Pinewood Studios, and as part of the Disney Long-term Contract, Disney pre-let five new stages at Pinewood West, for which construction is underway and is expected to complete in 2022, adding approximately 100,000 square feet of lettable area and contributing to the future growth of the business. Additionally, the Group also has outline planning consent to develop a further approximately 120,000 square feet in relation to Pinewood East Phase 3. In addition, in September 2020, we submitted an outline planning consent application for the 77 ----- acre site adjacent to Pinewood Studios which we acquired in August 2020 and we refer to as Pinewood South. We expect to receive a decision from the local planning authority before January 2022, and if successful, the planning application would give us the ability to build a global screen industries growth hub comprising (i) additional production accommodation space, (ii) a visitor experience, (iii) an education hub, and (iv) a business growth hub totaling approximately 750,000 square feet. See “—Business—Studios and Facilities—Pinewood Studios.” At Shepperton Studios, we are pursuing an expansion which will add a further 17 new sound stages and Other Production Accommodation space totalling approximately 1.0 million square feet of lettable area in aggregate across two phases. Shepperton North West, the first phase of this expansion, comprises three sound stages and Other Production Accommodation totalling approximately 165,000 square feet. Enabling and early works commenced in May 2021 and we contracted Sir Robert McAlpine to undertake the main works for the development in October 2021. The development is expected to complete in the first half of 2023. Shepperton South, the second larger phase of the expansion, comprises 14 sound stages and Other Production Accommodation totalling approximately 800,000 square feet. Enabling and early works commenced in August 2021 and we have signed a fixed-price main works contract with Laing O’Rourke in November 2021. The development is expected to complete towards the end of 2023. Additionally, we entered into a long-term contract with Netflix to pre-let approximately 0.5 million square feet of space, equivalent to 60% of the space being developed, at our Shepperton South studio. The lease will commence on completion of the development, expected towards the end of 2023, and is on terms similar to the Netflix Long-term Contract. There is strong interest from several customers for the remaining approximately 0.5 million square feet being developed at Shepperton. Our range of expansion plans that are underway and under consideration are projects, with both short and long-term timeframes, that will allow us to meet the demands of our customers. We continue to adopt a prudent approach to any expansion by conducting various detailed feasibility studies to assess viability and risks and also seek to de-risk the income by entering into long-term rental contracts in advance of the construction completion. In addition, if we undertake any future expansion opportunities for which work has not commenced, we will implement a prudent approach towards financing. We work with reputable construction companies with a track record of timely project completion and have contracts in place that incentivize timely and cost-efficient completions. Our business is highly cash generative and we expect to be able to fund a certain amount of expansionary investment through internal cash generation.

Subsubsection Title: Continue to Pursue Opportunities for International Expansion
Subsubsection Text: We believe there is an opportunity to expand our platform to key international markets. We believe the strength of our brand, industry relationships and operational expertise make us a partner and operator of choice for owners of international studios. Our international presence helps us strengthen our market leading position by providing global solutions to our clients. Expanding internationally allows us to capitalise on our existing brand and operational structure, resulting in synergies and an efficient use of resources. We have formulated our strategy for international expansion, focusing on key established markets within North America, Europe, Australia and emerging markets such as China and India, which could be attractive due to the rapidly growing box office sales and strong demand for locally produced content. Should we choose to enter or expand within these markets, we will likely do so by acquiring existing facilities, establishing partnerships with well capitalised, reputable, local owners or developers who recognise the value of partnering with us to brand and operate their studio, or selectively pursuing development opportunities ourselves.

Since the take private transaction in 2016, our strategy has been based on three pillars. This strategic focus, combined with strong underlying demand for our Stage and Other Production Accommodation and investment into the business has resulted in (i) the simplification of our business following the elimination of several non-core activities, (ii) growth in Adjusted EBITDA over the periods presented in this Offering Memorandum, and (iii) increased visibility of future turnover, pursuant to the Long-term Contracts. In the coming years we expect to continue to pursue these same strategies and progress our expansion plans.

In 2021 we entered into an agreement for lease with Netflix in respect of stages, workshops and offices at Shepperton Studios in relation to the Shepperton Expansion Project. The parties, terms and maturity of this new lease is substantially the same as those of the existing Netflix Long-term Contract as described under “Business— _Material Contracts—Netflix Long-term Contract.”_ We expect that Netflix will take possession of the property and begin paying rent upon completion of the Shepperton South development works, which is expected towards the end of 2023. Where Netflix do not require space at Shepperton South, the contract includes a mechanism for the space to be marketed and hired by us to third-party productions. ----- The demised premises under the Netflix Shepperton South Long-term Contract will include stages, workshops and offices at Shepperton Studios, totalling approximately 0.5 million square feet of stages and Other Production Accommodation space. Use of the premises is only for film production in respect of the stages and workshops, and general office use for the areas demised as offices. See “Business—Material Contracts—Netflix Shepperton South Long-term Contract.” -----

Subsection Title: Guarantors” and, together with the Company, the “Guarantors”). The Issuer and the Subsidiary Guarantors also guarantee, on a senior
Subsubsection Text: basis, the Revolving Credit Facility and the Existing Notes. The Notes Guarantees will rank, senior in right of payment to the respective Guarantor’s existing and future debt that is expressly subordinated in right of payment to such Guarantor’s Notes Guarantee and will rank pari passu in right of payment with the respective Guarantor’s existing and future debt that is not so subordinated, including such Guarantor’s obligations under the Revolving Credit Facility, such Guarantor’s guarantee in respect of the Existing Notes and certain hedging obligations. The Notes and the Notes Guarantees thereof will be secured by the Collateral. The property and assets that will secure the Notes and the Notes Guarantees will also secure the Revolving Credit Facility, the Existing Notes and certain hedging obligations on a first-ranking and pari passu basis. Pursuant to the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement, in the event of a distressed disposal of, or an enforcement of the security interests over, the Collateral, the holders of the Notes will receive proceeds from such Collateral only after the obligations under the Revolving Credit Facility, certain hedging obligations and certain other future indebtedness permitted under the Indenture have been repaid in full. The validity and enforceability of the Notes Guarantees and the security interests and the liability of each Guarantor will be subject to the limitations described in “Limitations on the Validity and Enforceability of the Notes Guarantees and _Security Interests and Certain Insolvency Law Considerations.” The Collateral and the Notes Guarantees may be released in certain_ circumstances. See “Description of the Notes—The Notes Guarantees,” and “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to the Notes and Our _Structure.”_ ----- On or about the Issue Date, the Proceeds Loan Agreement governing the Existing Notes Proceeds Loan will be amended and restated to reflect (i) the Notes Proceeds Loan in a principal amount thereunder equivalent to the aggregate principal amount of Notes offered hereby, (ii) the interest rate of the Notes and (iii) the maturity of the Notes, and the Issuer will lend, pursuant to the Notes Proceeds Loan, the entire gross proceeds of the Offering to the Company, who will then apply the proceeds of the Notes Proceeds Loan as set forth under “Use of Proceeds.” See “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Proceeds Loan.” (4) The Issuer issued an initial aggregate principal amount of £550.0 million of its 3¼% Senior Secured Notes due 2025 on September 25, 2019 and an additional £200.0 million aggregate principal amount of its 3¼% Senior Secured Notes due 2025 on January 25, 2021 (collectively, the “Existing Notes”) that are fungible with, and form the same series as, the initial Existing Notes. The Existing Notes are guaranteed by the Guarantors and secured by the same Collateral that will be secure the Notes offered hereby. See “Description of _Certain Financing Arrangements—Existing Notes.”_ (5) On or prior to the Issue Date, the Company expects to enter into an Additional Increase Confirmation (as defined in the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement) which, subject to the satisfaction of various conditions precedent set out therein, will increase the total commitments in respect of the Revolving Credit Facility by £15.0 million to £65.0 million. The Issuer, together with the same subsidiaries of the Company that initially guarantee the Notes also guarantee the Revolving Credit Facility and the Revolving Credit Facility is also secured by the same Collateral that will initially secure the Notes. See “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Revolving Credit _Facility” for further information on the Revolving Credit Facility. Pursuant to the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement, in the event of_ a distressed disposal of, or an enforcement of the security interests over, the Collateral, the holders of the Notes and holders of the Existing Notes will receive proceeds from such Collateral only after the obligations under the Revolving Credit Facility, certain hedging obligations and certain other future indebtedness permitted under the Indenture have been repaid in full. (6) The Notes will be guaranteed on the Issue Date by each of (i) the Company, (ii) Pinewood-Shepperton Studios Limited, (iii) Pinewood Studios Limited, (iv) Shepperton Studios Limited, (v) Pinewood PSB Limited and (vi) Pinewood Shepperton Facilities Limited. As of, and for the twelve months ended, September 30, 2021, the Guarantors accounted for 96% the total assets, 99% of turnover and 98% of Adjusted EBITDA of the Company and its subsidiaries on a consolidated basis, after the effect of intercompany eliminations. See “Description of the Notes— The Notes Guarantees” and “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to the Notes and Our Structure.” -----

Subsubsection Text: - be general senior obligations of the Issuer, secured as set forth under “—Security”; - rank pari passu in right of payment with all existing and future indebtedness of the Issuer that is not subordinated in right of payment to the Notes, including, any indebtedness under the Revolving Credit Facility, the Existing Notes and certain hedging obligations; - rank senior in right of payment to all existing and future subordinated indebtedness of the Issuer; - be effectively subordinated to any existing and future indebtedness of the Issuer that is secured by property or assets that do not secure the Notes, to the extent of the value of the property or assets securing such indebtedness; - be structurally subordinated to any existing and future indebtedness of subsidiaries of the Company that do not guarantee the Notes, including obligations to trade creditors; and - be guaranteed on a senior basis by the Guarantors, subject to certain guarantee limitations.

The Notes Guarantees will be subject to release under certain circumstances. See “Description of the Notes—The Notes Guarantees.”

Prior to**, 2023, the Issuer will be entitled at its option to redeem all or a portion of the Notes at a redemption price equal to 100% of the principal amount of the Notes redeemed, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to the date of redemption, plus the applicable “make-whole” premium described in this Offering Memorandum. On or after, 2023, the Issuer will be entitled at its option to redeem all or a portion of the Notes at the applicable redemption prices set forth under the heading “Description of the Notes—Optional Redemption,” _plus accrued and unpaid interest to, but excluding, the redemption date._ Prior to, 2023, the Issuer will be entitled at its option on one or more occasions to redeem the Notes in an aggregate principal amount not to exceed 40% of the aggregate principal amount of the Notes (including any additional notes) with the net cash proceeds from certain equity offerings at a redemption price equal to % of the principal amount outstanding in respect of the Notes redeemed, plus accrued and unpaid interest to, but excluding the redemption date, provided that at least 50% of the original principal amount of the Notes (including any additional notes) remains outstanding immediately after each such redemption. See “Description of the Notes—Optional Redemption.” Prior to, 2023, the Issuer may redeem up to 10% of the aggregate principal amount of the Notes originally issued (including any additional notes) during each calendar year at a redemption price equal to 103% of the principal amount of the Notes redeemed, _plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to the redemption date. In connection with any tender offer or other offer to purchase all of the Notes, if holders of not less than 90% of the aggregate principal amount of the then outstanding Notes validly tender and do not validly withdraw such Notes in such tender offer or offer to purchase, the Issuer will have the right to redeem all Notes that remain outstanding at a price equivalent to the price offered to each holder of the Notes in such tender offer or offer to purchase plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, thereon. See “Description of the Notes—Optional Redemption.”

Subsection Title: Additional Amounts ............................ All payments made by the Issuer or any Guarantor with respect to the
Subsubsection Text: Notes or the Note Guarantee thereof will be made without withholding or deduction for or on account of taxes unless required by law. If the Issuer or any Guarantors are required by law to withhold or deduct amounts for or on account of tax imposed by a Relevant Taxing Jurisdiction (as defined under “Description of Notes—Withholding _Taxes”) from a payment in respect of the Notes, the Issuer or the relevant_ Guarantor will, subject to certain exceptions, pay the additional amounts necessary so that the net amount received by a holder of the Notes (after ----- the withholding or deduction) is not less than the amount that such holder would have received in the absence of the withholding or deduction. See “Description of the Notes—Withholding Taxes.”

Subsection Title: Tax Redemption ................................... The Issuer may redeem the Notes in whole, but not in part, at any time,
Subsubsection Text: upon giving prior notice, at a redemption price equal to 100% of the principal amount of the Notes _plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to the date of redemption, if certain changes in tax law impose certain withholding taxes on amounts payable on the Notes, and, as a result, the Issuer or an applicable Guarantor is required to pay additional amounts with respect to such withholding taxes. See “Description of the Notes—Redemption for Taxation Reasons.”

Subsection Title: Change of Control ............................... Upon the occurrence of certain events constituting a change of control,
Subsubsection Text: the Issuer may be required to offer to repurchase all outstanding Notes at a purchase price equal to 101% of the principal amount thereof _plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to the date of such repurchase. However, a change of control will be deemed not to have occurred if a specified net total loan-to-value ratio is not exceeded in connection with such event. See “Description of the Notes—Change _of Control” and “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to the Notes and Our Structure—We will require a significant amount of cash to service our debt and sustain our operations, which we may not be able to generate or raise.”_

Subsection Title: Certain Covenants ............................... The Indenture, among other things, restricts the ability of the Issuer, the
Subsubsection Text: Company and its restricted subsidiaries to: - incur or guarantee additional indebtedness and issue certain preferred stock; - pay dividends on, redeem capital stock and make certain other restricted payments; - make certain investments; - create or incur certain liens; - sell, lease or transfer certain assets; - agree to restrictions on dividends by restricted subsidiaries; - enter into certain transactions with affiliates; - merge or consolidate with other entities; and - impair the security interests for the benefit of the holders of the Notes. Each of these covenants is subject to a number of significant exceptions and qualifications. See “Description of the Notes—Certain Covenants” and the related definitions. Certain of the covenants will be suspended if and for as long as we achieve investment-grade ratings. See “Description of the Notes— _Certain Covenants.”_

Subsection Title: No Established Market for the Notes ..................................................... The Notes will be new securities for which there is currently no
Subsubsection Text: established trading market. Although the Initial Purchasers have advised the Issuer that they intend to make a market for the Notes, they are not obliged to do so and they may discontinue market making at any time ----- without notice. Accordingly, there can be no assurances as to the development or liquidity of any market for the Notes.

Subsection Title: Listing ................................................... Application will be made to the Authority for the listing of and
Subsubsection Text: permission to deal in the Notes on the Official List of the Exchange. There can be no assurance that the Notes will be listed on the Official List of the Exchange, that such permission to deal in the Notes will be granted, or that such listing will be maintained.

Subsection Title: Use of Proceeds .................................... The gross proceeds of this offering of the Notes sold on the Issue Date
Subsubsection Text: will be used, along with cash on balance sheet: (i) to fund expansion projects, including the Shepperton Expansion Project and five new stages at Pinewood West, and (ii) to pay fees and expenses related to the Offering. Pending the allocation of an amount equal to the net proceeds from the Offering to fund the foregoing expansion projects, all or a portion of an amount equal to the net proceeds from the Offering may be used to invest in interest-bearing accounts and short-term, interestbearing securities, and/or to provide for working capital and other general corporate purposes, including payment of interest or principal on debt, funding other capital and/or operating expenditures and acquisition of assets useful in our business, or a combination of the foregoing. To the extent there are net proceeds remaining on balance sheet following the use of funds for the foregoing expansion projects, we may allocate such amounts to general corporate purposes, including other expansion projects. See “Use of Proceeds.”

Subsection Title: Governing Law .................................... The Indenture is, and the Notes and the Notes Guarantees thereof will be,
Subsubsection Text: governed by the laws of the State of New York. The Intercreditor Agreement, the Security Documents and the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement are governed by English law.

Deutsche Bank AG, London Branch. Registrar and Transfer Agent ............ Deutsche Bank Luxembourg S.A. Principal Paying Agent ....................... Deutsche Bank AG, London Branch. Listing Agent ........................................ Carey Olsen Corporate Finance Limited. Risk Factors

Subsubsection Text: (a) Loss on disposal of participating interests adjusted items for the fiscal year ended March 31, 2020 was due to the Group completing the sale of its equity investment in Pinewood Atlanta Studios to its joint venture partner, which was completed in August 2019. The proceeds, net of costs, totalled £12.6 million, recording a loss on disposal of £1.8 million. The sale agreement included earnout provisions linked to the financial performance of the studios for the year ended December 31, 2019, and the sale proceeds included £0.6 million related to the earnout payments received following the disposal. (b) Other operating expenses/(income) adjusted items (excluding impairment of property, plant and equipment) for the fiscal year ended March 31, 2020 represents £2.8 million for the sale of the Group’s interest in POP Global Ltd in February 2020. Previously, this investment was fully impaired and held at nil cost. Offsetting this amount was £2.6 million of land transfer tax which was calculated and paid in the year in relation to restructuring the Group’s property portfolio to optimise ownership across subsidiary undertakings. (c) Administrative expenses/(income) adjusted items for the fiscal year ended March 31, 2021 represent the unwind to the income statement of £0.5 million of unamortised deferred trademark royalties in connection with Pinewood Forest LLC, originally recognised on balance sheet in 2016, on the termination of the agreement with Pinewood Forest. Administrative expenses/(income) adjusted items for the fiscal year ended March 31, 2020 represent a restructuring cost of £0.4 million, a derecognition of £1.7 million of fair value of Pinewood MBS following the option to receive an additional 10% of equity in the business, and a receipt of £0.7 million, net of costs, as a result of the early termination of our Pinewood Iskandar Malaysia Studios agreement. Administrative expenses/(income) adjusted items for the fiscal year ended March 31, 2019 represent £0.9 million of restructuring reorganisation costs. Gain on loan to participating interests adjusted items, for the fiscal year ended March 31, 2021, represents the gain from additional loan notes issued by PMBS to the Group, with a face value of £2.0 million, which were received for nil consideration. The additional loan notes were initially recognised on the balance sheet at fair value, estimated to be the face value, resulting in a corresponding gain in our income statement of £2.0 million. Amounts described as “Administrative expenses/(income) adjusted items” were previously referred to as “exceptional items” within the audited consolidated financial statements for the fiscal year ended March 31, 2019. For more information, see “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Factors Affecting Comparability— _Adjusted Items—Administrative Expenses.”_

Income from pre-leased expansion does not include the impact related to the EBITDA contribution from the Shepperton North West development (approximately 0.2 million square feet) and the remaining lettable area of the Shepperton South development not covered by the long-term contract with Netflix (approximately 0.3 million square feet). (e) Net impact of furlough costs reflects the funds received and subsequently repaid by the Group to the UK government in relation to the UK Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme in the last twelve month period ending September 30, 2021. (3) Adjusted EBITDA margin is calculated as Adjusted EBITDA (which includes impact of income from participating interests) divided by turnover (which does not include the impact of income from participating interests). Subsubsection Text: (5) Adjusted EBITDA margin (excluding joint ventures and associates) is calculated as Adjusted EBITDA (excluding joint ventures and associates) divided by turnover. (6) Total capital expenditure represents cash paid for the purchase of property, plant and equipment, intangibles, investments and joint ventures, the purchase of intangible assets, proceeds received from the disposal of property, plant and equipment and investment in joint ventures together with amounts repaid from joint ventures, and movement in long-term liability, as disclosed in the statement of cash flows in the audited consolidated financial statements of the Company and the unaudited interim condensed consolidated financial statements of the Company, adjusted for the movement in capital expenditure related payables. (7) Maintenance capital expenditure represents capital expenditure required to maintain the ongoing standards of studios, infrastructure and other facilities, net of proceeds on disposal of such assets. (8) Investment capital expenditure is defined as expenditure expected to generate an incremental return on capital, net of proceeds on disposal of such assets. (9) Cash conversion is calculated as Adjusted EBITDA less maintenance capital expenditure, as a percentage of Adjusted EBITDA. (10) As adjusted total debt represents the total principal amount of debt as if the Offering and the application of the proceeds therefrom as described under “Use of Proceeds,” had taken place on September 30, 2021. The Revolving Credit Facility was undrawn as of September 30, 2021 and we expect the Revolving Credit Facility to be undrawn on the Issue Date. (11) As adjusted cash and cash equivalents represents cash and cash equivalents as if the Offering and the application of the proceeds therefrom as described under “Use of Proceeds,” had taken place on September 30, 2021. We intend to apply the net proceeds from the Offering, along with £218.4 million of cash on balance sheet: (i) to fund expansion projects, including the Shepperton Expansion Project and five new stages at Pinewood West, and (ii) to pay fees and expenses related to the Offering. Funds to pay for the foregoing expansion projects are expected to be deployed in the next two and a half years in accordance with the following schedule: approximately 20% in the year ending March 31, 2022, approximately 50% in the year ending March 31, 2023 and the remaining approximately 30% in the year ending March 31, 2024; however, the foregoing disbursement schedule is subject to change as the construction and build-out progress. As adjusted cash and cash equivalents figure presented above does not give effect to any movements in cash and cash equivalents since September 30, 2021. Pending the allocation of an amount equal to the net proceeds from the Offering to fund the foregoing expansion projects, all or a portion of an amount equal to such net proceeds may be used to invest in interest-bearing accounts and short-term, interest-bearing securities, and/or to provide for working capital and other general corporate purposes, including payment of interest or principal on debt, funding other capital and/or operating expenditures and acquisition of assets useful in our business, or a combination of the foregoing. To the extent there are net proceeds remaining on balance sheet following the use of funds for the foregoing expansion projects, we may allocate such amounts to general corporate purposes, including other expansion projects. For further information, see “Use of Proceeds” and “Capitalisation.” (12) As adjusted net debt represents as adjusted total debt, less as adjusted cash and cash equivalents. Subsubsection Text: The following tables set forth summary historical financial information for the Company as of, and for the fiscal years ended, March 31, 2019, 2020 and 2021 and for the six months ended September 30, 2020 and 2021. The summary historical financial data as of and for the fiscal years ended March 31, 2019, 2020, and 2021 has been derived from the audited consolidated financial statements of the Company as of and for the fiscal years ended March 31, 2019, 2020, and 2021, respectively, prepared in accordance with UK GAAP. The summary historical financial data as of and for the six months ended September 30, 2020 and 2021 has been derived from the unaudited interim condensed consolidated financial statements of the Company as of, and for the six months ended, September 30, 2021, prepared in accordance with UK GAAP. The summary historical financial data for the twelve months ended September 30, 2021 has been calculated by adding the unaudited interim condensed consolidated financial information of the Company for the six months ended September 30, 2021 to the audited consolidated financial information of the Company for the fiscal year ended March 31, 2021 and subtracting the unaudited interim condensed consolidated financial information of the Company for the six months ended September 30, 2020. The unaudited financial information for the twelve months ended September 30, 2021 has been prepared solely for the purpose of this Offering Memorandum, is for illustrative purposes only and is not necessarily indicative of our results of operations for any future period or our financial condition at any future date. The results of operations for prior years or interim periods are not necessarily indicative of results to be expected for the full year or any future period. The summary financial information below contains certain Non-GAAP Measures that are not required by, or presented in accordance with, UK GAAP or the accounting measures of any other jurisdiction. The NonGAAP Measures are not measurements of financial performance under UK GAAP or the accounting measures of any other jurisdiction and should not be considered substitutes to other indicators of our operating performance, cash flows, or any other measure of performance derived in accordance with UK GAAP. The Non-GAAP Measures as presented in this Offering Memorandum may differ from, and may not be comparable to, similarly titled measures used by other companies. The calculations for the Non-GAAP Measures are based on various assumptions. There can be no assurances that items we have identified as non-recurring will not recur in the future or that similar items will not be incurred in the future. You should rely on our UK GAAP results and use these Non-GAAP Measures only in a supplemental manner to evaluate our performance. See “Presentation of Financial _and Other Information—Other Financial Information (Non-UK GAAP).”_ The summary historical financial information and other data below also include certain key performance indicators and other non-financial operational data that are not part of our financial statements and have not been audited. Our use or computation of these indicators may not be comparable with the use of computation of similarly titled measures reported by other companies. None of the key performance indicators or other nonfinancial operating data included in this Offering Memorandum should be considered in isolation or as a substitute to any indicator of our operating performance, cash flows or other measure of performance derived in accordance with UK GAAP or the accounting measures of any other jurisdiction. The summary financial information below includes unaudited consolidated as adjusted financial data which has been adjusted to reflect certain effects of the Offering (i) on interest expense as if the Offering and the 2025 Notes Tap Issuance of £200.0 million aggregate principal amount that closed on January 25, 2021 were completed on October 1, 2020, and (ii) on total debt, cash and cash equivalents and net debt as if the Offering had been completed on September 30, 2021. The unaudited consolidated as adjusted financial data has been prepared for illustrative purposes only and does not purport to represent what the actual interest expense, total debt, cash and cash equivalents and net debt of the Company would have been if the Offering had occurred (i) on September 30, 2021 for the purposes of the calculation of total debt, cash and cash equivalents and net debt and (ii) on October 1, 2020 for the purposes of the calculation of interest expense, nor does such data purport to project the Company’s total debt, cash and cash equivalents and net debt and interest expense at any future date. The unaudited adjustments and the unaudited as adjusted financial data set out in this Offering Memorandum is based on available information and certain assumptions and estimates that we believe are reasonable and may differ materially from the actual adjusted amounts. The results of operations for prior years are not necessarily indicative of the results to be expected for any future period. The tables should also be read together with “Risk Factors,” “Capitalisation,” “Selected Historical Financial _Information” and “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations.”_ For an explanation of certain terms used in the tables below, please see “Presentation of Financial and Other _Information—Other Financial Information (Non-UK GAAP).”_

Subsubsection Title: We rely on the Disney Long-term Contract and the Netflix Long-term Contract for a significant portion of our turnover. The termination, non-renewal or default under one or both of these Long-term Contracts could reduce our future turnover.
Subsubsection Text: We are subject to customer concentration risk as a result of our reliance on relatively few numbers of customers for a significant portion of our revenues. For the fiscal year ended March 31, 2021, our top five customers generated 85% of our turnover, with Disney and Netflix generating 43% and 27% of our turnover, respectively. The contracts are 12-year and 10-year long contracts for Disney and Netflix, respectively, signed in 2019. Termination of a Long-term Contract, a dispute over compliance with contract terms, disruption (including extensions not being exercised), default by Disney or Netflix, or our inability to renew or replace any Long-term Contract when it expires, may have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsubsection Title: We face competition risks, including competition from new market entrants and the expansion of new and existing studios.
Subsubsection Text: We compete with a variety of studios, both internationally and domestically within the United Kingdom, on the basis of availability of space, availability of an appropriately skilled labour force in close proximity to the studios and certain fiscal incentives. Our key competitors tend to be located in areas with availability of local crews, close to gateway cities with good transport links and usually in English speaking territories offering well established, stable tax incentive schemes. Internationally, key competing locations include (i) Los Angeles, which has the greatest concentration of competitor studios such as Warner Bros., NBCUniversal and Sony Pictures, (ii) New York, (iii) Vancouver, which benefits from being in the same time zone as Los Angeles, (iv) Atlanta, and (v) Toronto. We also compete internationally with studios in the Czech Republic, Hungary, Romania, Italy, Germany, Australia and other countries. We face the risk of increased competition from potential new market entrants. For example, the London Borough of Barking and Dagenham has plans to develop a 20-acre site into new film production studios. In addition, in 2020 Sky announced its plan to develop a 32-acre site at Elstree Studios into a new TV and film studio in partnership with Legal & General. There are a number of proposed new facilities at early stages of development or seeking planning permission in the United Kingdom. Hudson Pacific Properties and Blackstone Group announced plans to develop a 91-acre site in Hertfordshire and the University of Reading with affiliates of Commonwealth Real Estate LP received planning permission for the development of a studio complex at Shinfield Studios. There are a number of other potential or proposed studio developments across the United Kingdom. While we believe the scale of our business and reputation, combined with significant barriers to entry within our market, such as the difficulties associated with obtaining planning consent and the frequently higher alternative use values, may mitigate the impact of competition from these proposed new developments, particularly in the London area, there can be no assurance that existing and future competition, including competition from new developments and market entrants, will not affect our market share and have negative effects on our business. Furthermore, should existing competing studios either in the United Kingdom or elsewhere invest significantly to improve their offerings, or new market entrants successfully establish a presence either in the United Kingdom or elsewhere, this may result in increased competition and have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operation. ----- We also compete with temporary facilities and location filming and the risk that our own customers will develop and/or expand their own in-house film and television production capabilities. Competition may require us to make significant new investments or reduce rental rates to avoid losing new and existing customers. Historically, our business largely depended on repeat business from, and sustained relationships with, certain customers. Since the commencement of the Long-term Contracts, we have limited space available to accommodate customers (other than Disney and Netflix) and available space for such customers depends on us either developing additional space not subject to the Long-term Contracts or offering existing space that is not required under the terms of the Long-term Contracts. Although we have longstanding relationships with most of our other historical customers and we believe that our relationships with those customers are stable, our ability to enter into new contracts with them for new space that becomes available may be negatively impacted by the Longterm Contracts. As a potential consequence of the Long-term Contracts, third parties, including existing competing studios or our customers, may prioritise and invest in, or otherwise build, alternative sites in order to guarantee sufficient production space for their productions which would previously have been produced at our studios. In addition, customers and production companies may establish relationships with third-party studios and other competitors to facilitate their production needs during the term of the Long-term Contracts and there can be no assurance that we can maintain or re-establish relationships with such production companies during or after the completion or termination of the Long-term Contracts. There can be no assurance that increased competition will not have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsubsection Title: Our business and financial performance are affected by general economic and geopolitical conditions in the United Kingdom and elsewhere, and any adverse developments in the United Kingdom or global economies or global geopolitical conditions may have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.
Subsubsection Text: Our business is influenced by general economic trends. Discretionary consumer spending, including spending on entertainment such as blockbuster films and online streaming platforms, is affected by global economic conditions. Demand for blockbuster films and online streaming platforms, for which the provision of required infrastructure is our operational specialty, may decrease if disposable income decreases, unemployment increases or spending habits change to reflect any increased uncertainty or apprehension regarding economic conditions. While demand for blockbuster films and online streaming platforms has been generally resilient through market downturn, we cannot guarantee that this will continue to be the case. A significant deterioration or sustained decline in economic conditions or the continued widespread closure of cinemas due to, for example, the COVID-19 pandemic could reduce demand for blockbuster films and online streaming platforms and, in turn, adversely impact production companies and result in reduced demand for any of our services and planned or future studios and facilities that are not subject to the Long-term Contracts. If economic conditions deteriorate in any of the markets in which we operate, there can be no assurance that the valuation of our properties will not decline, nor that such deterioration of economic conditions will not have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. The current uncertainty in the global economic and geopolitical conditions (particularly in the eurozone and the United Kingdom as a result of Brexit, and globally as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic) also poses a risk to our commercial relationships with our customers, suppliers and creditors. While we are subject to the Longterm Contracts for initial terms of at least ten years, if the current economic situation deteriorates significantly, or if our customers are forced to cease doing business, our business would be materially adversely impacted. The financial condition of some of our customers may expose us to credit risk. If our customers suffer financial difficulty, they may not pay us, which would have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations.

Subsubsection Title: The movement of the pound sterling in relation to the US dollar and other currencies could impact our business, financial condition and results of operations.
Subsubsection Text: While our rental rates pursuant to the Long-term Contracts are and will continue to be quoted in pound sterling, the majority of major production companies are based in the United States and set their production budgets in US dollars. To the extent that the pound sterling depreciates against the US dollar, the United Kingdom may become a more attractive place to invest for film production purposes, but may also increase the cost of imported supplies for our construction activities and specialist equipment. To the extent that the pound sterling appreciates against the US dollar, film-making that is budgeted in US dollars, but executed in the United Kingdom, could become relatively more expensive and our studios and services in the United Kingdom may be less price ----- competitive in relation to studios and services in the United States and elsewhere. This may have a material adverse impact on turnover attributable to Stage and Other Production Accommodation for our services and planned or future studios and facilities that are not subject to the Long-term Contracts. For the reasons stated above, fluctuations in exchange rates could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations.

Subsubsection Title: Our financial performance is tied to our reputation and any damage to our reputation could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.
Subsubsection Text: The Pinewood brand is widely recognised domestically and globally within the film and television production industry. The success of our business is underpinned by the integrity of our brand and our reputation for quality of service. We believe favourable recognition of our brand is important to maintaining a key position in an industry where trust and confidence with customers is paramount. Factors affecting brand recognition, such as negative publicity following an accident or other safety incident involving loss of life or injury, are often outside our control, and our efforts to maintain or enhance favourable brand recognition may not have their desired effects. We are also exposed to possible brand damage from poor customer service performance at our studios in the United Kingdom or at the studios of our international partners operating under the Pinewood brand. We are exposed to the risk that litigation, employee misconduct, operational failures, the outcome of regulatory or other investigations or actions, the reputations and actions of our international partners, press speculation and negative publicity, among other matters, whether or not founded, could damage our brand and our reputation. Any decline in perceived favourable recognition of our studios could have an adverse impact on the reputation of our ancillary and other business lines, and vice versa. A decline in favourable recognition of our brand could also impact our ability to attract or retain customers. The occurrence of any of the foregoing may have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsubsection Title: We are exposed to risks related to the Shepperton Expansion Project and new stage construction at Pinewood West as well as any other expansion projects we may undertake in the future, each of which may require the application of significant capital expenditures. Such risks include the inability to complete such projects on time or at all, the inability to generate the desired returns therefrom, the credit risks or the risk of insolvency of our construction contractors or the inability to raise additional capital as might be required to complete such projects, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.
Subsubsection Text: The net proceeds from the Offering, along with cash on balance sheet, are intended to be allocated to fund expansion projects, including the Shepperton Expansion Project and five new stages at Pinewood West, and to pay fees and expenses. On account of the size and complexity of the Shepperton Expansion Project, and the large number of parties involved, the Shepperton Expansion Project presents a number of risks which may materialize over the various phases of the construction process as well as various unexpected practical issues as the development progresses.
