Impediments to the proper execution of construction projects include, for example, ineffective project management, any failure to perform against contractual obligations on the part of a contractor, delays in obtaining construction inputs and supplies and potential nonperformance or potential insolvency of a contractor. In addition, external factors, such as adverse weather conditions, may negatively affect the execution of the Shepperton Expansion Project and/or the new stage construction at Pinewood West and our other expansion projects. While we intend to allocate the net proceeds of the Offering to fund expansion projects, including the Shepperton Expansion Project and five new stages at Pinewood West, we may require additional funding for the foregoing expansion projects and/or other capital expenditure plans and the ongoing maintenance and expansion of our sites will depend upon a number of factors, including the rate at which we choose to implement the Shepperton Expansion Project and other development projects, which will depend on the contractors’ and other service providers’ abilities and resources as well as our judgement of the demand for the increased space. If the plans or assumptions set out in our business plan change or prove to be inaccurate, or if we make any material acquisitions, we may be required to seek additional financing. There can be no assurance that additional financing will be available or, if available, can be concluded on terms acceptable to us. We cannot guarantee that we will be able to complete the expansion projects, including the Shepperton Expansion Project or the new stage construction at Pinewood West, in a timely manner or at all. Completed construction may contain defects or may not be completed to our specifications which could require us spend time and incur expenses, including through legal action, to cure and/or seek damages and our remedies may be limited ----- by contract, insurance limitations and/or the viability of our contractor or subcontractors. We also cannot guarantee that, if completed, these investments and initiatives will yield the anticipated or desired results, including, but not limited to, increased capacity and turnover or, if turnover does increase, that the additional turnover will be sufficient to recover the amounts invested and/or provide the desired return on such investments. A failure to realise the anticipated or desired results on such investment could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. We are subject to the potential risk of underperformance or nonperformance by our contractors, who might not be able to deliver on projects as initially anticipated in terms of cost and time to completion. Whilst we seek to work with contractors on fixed-price contracts or with a degree of fixity, where the potential liabilities related to potential delays or cost over-runs lie with the contractors, we cannot rely on negotiating fixed price contracts on construction projects in future. Also, if a contractor encounters financial difficulties or becomes insolvent, they might face hurdles and delays in honouring such liabilities or might not be able to fulfil them at all. We have certain guarantees in our contracts with construction contractors in a potential event of insolvency. However, claims over such guarantees might be delayed or might not succeed at all and as a result may delay the overall project timeline and increase the potential costs associated with the development. Furthermore, our contractors and their vendors may be subject to their own operating, financial and regulatory risks. While such expansion opportunities could be frustrated or not come to fruition, to the extent they do, they will involve a substantial amount of capital expenditure and will result in us incurring development risk. For example, the final amount of capital expenditure required for a development or project could be higher than that originally estimated. In addition, although there is strong interest from several customers for the remaining approximately 0.5 million square feet being developed at Shepperton, we may not be successful in finding suitable tenants. Furthermore, the length of time required to deliver the projects could be longer than originally estimated due to delays or other unforeseen circumstances, which could result in increased costs, loss of turnover, or could impact our reputation, if we had committed the newly built space before it had been completed. Construction of additional space will most likely take place while the existing studios are in occupation and therefore may cause disruption to our customers which, in turn, could result in a material adverse effect on our reputation, results of operations, financial condition and business. For more information on our planned capital expenditures, see “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Liquidity and _Capital Resources—Capital Expenditures” and “Business—Studios and Facilities.”_

Subsubsection Title: We may not obtain the necessary approvals, licenses, titles or permits for our planned and future developments, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations.
Subsubsection Text: Facilities at our studios are required to be constructed and operated in accordance with the relevant planning permission and codes. If the construction or use of such facilities is not conducted in accordance with the relevant planning permission and codes, the relevant council and or regulators may, in certain circumstances, prohibit the use of such facilities until such failure to comply is remedied. Further, a council can require compliance with the conditions of any planning permission or planning agreement, or, in certain circumstances, the alteration or reinstatement of any construction carried out without planning permission. We may experience material difficulties or failures in obtaining planning permissions and maintaining or renewing the necessary licenses or approvals for the facilities at our studios, which could result in delay in construction, the closure of our facilities, or fines. Stringent and varied requirements of local regulators with respect to zoning, land use and environmental factors could also delay or prevent development of new studios in particular locations. Obtaining planning permission for future developments may be difficult. There are either planned expansions or the potential for expansions at Pinewood Studios and Shepperton Studios. For more information on our planned or potential expansions, see “Business—Studios and Facilities.” If we are unable to obtain the requisite planning permissions for these planned expansions at our existing studios, we would be unable to carry out these expansions. We work with and engage our local planning authorities with regard to issues of shared concern that impact the development, redevelopment and expansion of our studios, including sensitivities to site noise, listed structures, road congestion and other traffic issues, and health and safety issues. If we were to fail to cooperate with local planning authorities or if our work relationship with such authorities were to be adversely affected for any reason, this could negatively impact our ability to obtain the requisite planning approvals, consents and licenses necessary for the development, redevelopment or expansion of our studios, or it could result in the withdrawal of existing approvals, consents and licenses. Additionally, possible changes to planning rules (such as the categorization of flood zones), laws or regulations (such as regulations that prohibit development within a ----- certain distance of flood defence structures) may, if enacted, adversely affect our ability to develop, redevelop or expand our studios. Any refusal to grant, or delay in granting, our requested planning or other consents, or the application of any special conditions to such consents (or our breach of such conditions), could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsubsection Title: We and our subsidiaries could be adversely affected by the contractual rights of third-parties under joint venture, sales and marketing and trademark licensing agreements, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations.
Subsubsection Text: We and our subsidiaries have entered into and may in the future enter into joint ventures, which could involve the following risks, among others: - co-investors may have economic or other interests that are inconsistent with our and/or our relevant subsidiary’s interests, as applicable, and are in a position to take or influence actions contrary to our interests and plans, which may create impasses on decisions and affect our ability to implement our strategies; - disputes may develop between us and/or our relevant subsidiary and the relevant co-investors and we may have to bear the cost of any litigation or arbitration proceedings; - co-investors may fail to fund their share of any capital or debt contribution which may be required, which may result in us and/or our relevant subsidiary having to pay the co-investor’s share; - co-investors may breach agreements relating to an investment, which may cause a default under such agreements and result in liability for us and/or our relevant subsidiary; - co-investors may operate in jurisdictions of high geopolitical uncertainty and/or may engage in violations of applicable anti-bribery, anti-money laundering and sanctions laws and regulations, which could result in liability for us and/or our relevant subsidiary; - co-investors may have drag-along rights or rights pursuant to call options which entitle them to compel us and/or our relevant subsidiary to sell our share in an asset or instrument before we are entitled to or at a lower price than otherwise expected to receive; - co-investors may have tag-along rights which entitle them to compel us and/or our relevant subsidiary to sell our or its share in connection with a disposal of an asset or instrument, which may adversely affect our and/or our relevant subsidiary’s ability to pursue our or its sale strategy or to obtain the best price possible; - co-investors may have rights pursuant to put options which entitle them to compel us and/or our relevant subsidiary to purchase their share in an asset or instrument at a lower price than otherwise expected to receive; and/or - we and/or our relevant subsidiary may, in certain circumstances, be liable for the actions of coinvestors. Any arrangement in which we and/or our subsidiaries do not fully control business operations may in the future present, greater financial, legal, operational and/or compliance risks including those outlined above. To the extent that any of these risks materialise, they could have a material adverse impact on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsubsection Title: Our insurance coverage may not be adequate to cover all possible losses that we could suffer and our insurance costs may increase, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations.
Subsubsection Text: We seek to maintain comprehensive insurance coverage at commercially reasonable rates. Although we carry insurance to cover certain risks, our insurance policies do not cover all types of losses and liabilities and are subject to limits and excesses. There can be no assurance that our insurance will be sufficient to cover the full extent of all losses or liabilities for which we are insured and we cannot guarantee that we will be able to renew our current insurance policies on favourable terms, or at all. In addition, if we sustain significant losses or make ----- significant insurance claims, then our ability to obtain future insurance coverage at commercially reasonable rates could be materially adversely affected.

Subsubsection Title: If occupancy rates in connection with planned or future studios and facilities that are not subject to the Long- term Contracts, or more generally across the industry, do not meet our expectations or decrease, it could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.
Subsubsection Text: Historically, one of the key factors affecting our turnover was the occupancy rates of our facilities. While occupancy rates are less relevant for the facilities subject to the Long-term Contracts, they remain applicable to planned or future studios and facilities that are not subject to the Long-term Contracts, including, as of the date of this Offering Memorandum, the remaining 50% of the space to be developed across Shepperton South and Shepperton North West. Occupancy rates are driven by contracted bookings for stages, for which we historically competed with a variety of studios on the basis of availability of space, availability of an appropriately skilled labour force in close proximity to the studios and certain fiscal incentives. Prior to signing the Long-term Contracts, for the fiscal year ended March 31, 2019, the occupancy rates of our stages in the United Kingdom, calculated by totalling the total square footage sold and paid for each working day of the period divided by the total space available during such period, was 95%. For an explanation of how we calculate occupancy rates, see “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Significant Factors _Affecting Results of Operations—Occupancy Rates.” While stage occupancy rates have remained consistently_ high over the past several years, we cannot guarantee that we will be able to maintain or obtain such levels or that they will remain stable in the future in relation to studios and facilities that are not subject to the Long-term Contracts. In addition, a decrease in occupancy rates more generally across the industry may adversely impact the value of our properties irrespective of the Long-term Contracts, and could also impact the renewal of our Longterm Contracts. When combined with the relatively fixed nature of our costs, a decrease in occupancy rates could have a material adverse effect on our profitability, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsubsection Title: If our fixed costs increase, it could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.
Subsubsection Text: While a substantial portion of our cost structure is fixed, there can be fluctuations in such costs from period to period due to changes in prices of inputs. We incur significant fixed costs related to business rates, insurance, cleaning, security and maintenance that we do not pass to the customer on an as-used basis. In addition, rising costs, particularly for gas, electricity and other forms of energy that are not passed to the customer, may have an impact on our operating profit. While we have invested in an energy efficient replacement equipment program and use meter systems to monitor our energy consumption, there can be no assurance that energy costs, or other costs, will not grow at a faster rate than our turnover. In such circumstances, our profitability could be materially and adversely affected. The realization of these risks could have a materially adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsubsection Title: We are exposed to the risk of serious accidents and other safety incidents on our properties and we cannot guarantee that our internal policies and procedures will prevent such accidents or safety incidents.
Subsubsection Text: Our ability to attract and retain customers depends, in part, upon the external perceptions of our business, the quality and safety of our studios and services, and our corporate and management integrity. While we carefully maintain the safety of our studios and certain high-risk activities taking place in our studios (including the use of props and technology involving open flames, pyrotechnics and water) which are the responsibility of the production companies that carry them out while in occupation of our studios, there are inherent risks involved with such activities. An accident or injury at any of our studios, or even an accident or injury at studios operated by our competitors, particularly one that receives media attention, could negatively impact our brand or reputation, cause the loss of customer confidence and negatively impact our results of operations. The considerable expansion in the use of social media over recent years has compounded the impact of negative publicity. Despite the health and safety measures that we have imposed, incidents involving harm to persons at certain of our properties, as well as damage to property and assets have occurred. For example, we have experienced fire damage, water damage and structural damage in the past that have caused significant damage to some of our studios. Although we have implemented changes to reduce the likelihood of such events happening again, there can be no assurance that such events will not occur in the future. ----- Any accident or other safety incident involving loss of life or injury or damage to property or assets, or the public perception of risk thereof, could expose us to financial risk, including personal injury and other liability claims and criminal proceedings. Internal investigations or investigations by insurers or other interested parties following an accident or other incident involving a stage or other feature of our studios could cause the affected studios to be closed for a temporary period or indefinitely, which could negatively impact our brands and reputation. In addition, mechanical or technical faults in certain specialty equipment or stages, such as the underwater facility, could be subject to closure. The effects of these closures, if significant in the aggregate or affecting key stages or our reputation, could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsubsection Title: We are exposed to risks relating to regulations and liabilities arising from our operations and assets, including environmental, health and safety laws, regulations, and liabilities.
Subsubsection Text: Our business is subject to numerous laws and licensing and authorization regimes in the jurisdictions in which we operate, regulating a number of operating issues, including health and safety procedures, equipment specifications, employment requirements, environmental laws and regulations and other requirements relating to our operations and assets. We are also exposed to regulatory and financial liability risks from, for example, hazardous materials or soil and ground water contamination. These laws and regulatory regimes are constantly subject to change and could impose substantial costs upon us and subject us to claims, fines and penalties. For example, recent changes in general sentencing guidelines applicable to The Health and Safety at Work Act 1974 and The Management of Health and Safety at Work Regulations 1992 have resulted in the potential for significantly higher fines and prison sentences for health and safety violations. The new guidelines categorise such incidents by level of actual harm and the risk of potential harm. As a result, if an incident could have caused a fatal injury, such incident will be categorised under a high level of harm, even if the resulting injury is minor or if no injury results. For companies with annual turnovers in excess of £50 million, such as ours, there is no limit to the fine that can be imposed. There can be no assurance that any or all of the regulatory and licensing and authorization frameworks under which we operate will not become more restrictive in the future. Our strategy to expand internationally increases our risk exposure to political and regulatory changes. The impact of, and costs associated with, complying with changes in interpretation of existing, or the adoption of new, legislation, regulations or other laws or licensing and authorization regimes in the jurisdictions in which we operate, or in which we have plans to operate, can be difficult to anticipate or estimate and could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. Regarding environmental, health and safety laws and regulations, a number of the buildings at Pinewood Studios and Shepperton Studios were built with materials containing asbestos. Although we have a health and safety process for managing the presence of any such asbestos, including any works that need to be undertaken in accordance with health and safety legislation and by licensed asbestos contractors, we cannot guarantee that there will not be a deterioration of the condition of any asbestos at our facilities. We have received claims related to asbestos at our studios and, even though we maintain what we believe to be adequate levels of insurance coverage with respect to these claims, there can be no guarantee that our policies will continue to cover such claims or that our level of coverage will be adequate to cover our liabilities. There is no current requirement to remove all of the asbestos at Pinewood Studios and Shepperton Studios, however, should such removal become necessary (as a result of United Kingdom or European Union legislative changes or otherwise), the cost could be significant and such removal may have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. We also face various development risks and or constraints as a result of the ground conditions upon which some of our facilities are located. For example, a parking lot and two stages at Pinewood Studios partially sit upon a former landfill. While this land is periodically monitored with respect to gas and liquid leakage, we cannot guarantee that our monitoring will detect all leakage or that, in the case of detection, our remedial measures will be sufficient to contain such leakage. We have in the past, detected a gas leak in one of our stages at Pinewood East and undertook remedial measures. We cannot assure you that our remedial measures will be effective or that such similar leaks will not occur in the future. Moreover, if an accident or other unanticipated event were to result in the leakage of gas or liquid from the former landfill at Pinewood Studios, there is a risk that filming at those studios could be interrupted or otherwise affected thus potentially adversely impacting our rental income. Additionally, part of the land planned for expansion works at Shepperton Studios is a former mineral extraction site. If any environmental issues are uncovered, such matters could potentially result in more expensive engineering solutions. We may also be held liable for claims, penalties or fines from government authorities, individuals and other third parties arising out of human exposure to hazardous materials, soil and ground water contamination or as a result of any environmental damage. Our insurance may not be sufficient to cover these ----- claims, penalties or fines and/or such claims, penalties or fines may result in a material change in the terms on which such insurance is renewed (including substantial increases to our insurance premiums). We cannot guarantee that our current provisions and measures for compliance with applicable environmental, health and safety laws and regulations will be sufficient to cover any incidents, accidents or other liability, and the occurrence of any of the foregoing risks could have a material adverse effect on our business, reputation, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsubsection Title: Any interruptions to our operations or our customers’ access to our studios and services could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.
Subsubsection Text: Our ability to host production companies and provide related services depends on customers’ access to, and proper functioning of, our studios. Our studio infrastructure may be vulnerable to damage caused by fire, flood, power outage, telecommunications failure, break-ins, earthquake, human error and other events. If any of our studios and/or infrastructure thereon were rendered incapable of operation, then we may be unable to host production companies at our studios, comply with the terms of the Long-term Contracts, or provide related services, and as a result, we would be unable to generate turnover related to such studios and/or infrastructure. While we carry business interruption insurance, we cannot guarantee that such coverage will be sufficient to cover any claims made against us, and the occurrence of any of the foregoing risks could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsubsection Title: Our success depends on our ability to attract, recruit and retain quality employees and key personnel, and the loss of any of these personnel, or any inability to attract new personnel, could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.
Subsubsection Text: Our success depends on our ability to attract, recruit and retain quality employees and key personnel in a highly competitive labour market. There are many contributory factors that affect our ability to retain key employees, many of which are beyond our control. The impact of failing to retain key employees and key personnel can be high due to loss of key knowledge and relationships, loss of creative talent, lost productivity, and hiring and training costs, all of which could result in lower profitability. We are also dependent upon the services of certain key management personnel and other highly skilled employees. Experienced personnel and top creative talent in the entertainment industry are in high demand and competition for their talents is intense. Our success depends largely on the continued service and availability of these key personnel. Any inability to retain, or successful attract and recruit where necessary, members of our senior management, other key employees and staff could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsubsection Title: Our customers benefit from the supply of services from, and access to, a skilled freelance labour force in close proximity to our studios. A major disruption of, or lack of access to or a material increase in cost of a skilled labour force could result in reduced occupancy rates and damage to our reputation, which could result in a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.
Subsubsection Text: The production of films and television programs at Pinewood Studios and Shepperton Studios requires the availability of skilled personnel in the film and television related industries. There can be several hundred to several thousand people involved in any given production and many of these individuals will work on a freelance basis for our customers. For productions to be delivered on time, the content producers require a highly skilled crew base. Crew members are typically comprised of freelance workers who possess unique skills that are critical to the creation and production of content, and therefore indirectly serve to maintain the demand for lettable space. We do not have any control over these freelance individuals and if their availability is limited for any reason, including but not limited to a public health crisis, epidemic, or pandemic (including the COVID-19 pandemic), or the rates that these people charge becomes inflated, our competitive position could be adversely impacted. Many of these labourers are members of unions and are covered by industry-wide collective bargaining agreements. For purposes of productions that require these services or that may utilise planned or future studios and facilities that are not subject to the Long-term Contracts, a strike or the possibility of a strike could cause such productions to slow down or stop due to the length of the strike and/or inability to reach agreement on a new union contract. This could result in occupancy rates below our expectations in connection with our planned or future studios and facilities that are not subject to the Long-term Contracts. For example, a Screen Actors Guild strike that lasted for four months between 2007 and 2008 disrupted production companies’ operations, reducing demand for our studios and resulting in decreased occupancy rates. An inability to reach agreement on one or more of such ----- union contracts or renewal on less favourable terms may also have an adverse effect on our customers operations and could have a corresponding adverse impact on the demand for our planned or future studios and facilities that are not subject to the Long-term Contracts. Should there be a major disruption in the supply of labour at our studios or demand for our studios and services for any of the foregoing reasons or otherwise, our business, financial condition and results of operations may be materially and adversely effected.

Subsubsection Title: A security or privacy breach or disruption to our information technology systems could damage our reputation and have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.
Subsubsection Text: Our business depends on the ability of our customers to access secure information technology systems. Interruption or loss of access to such systems could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition. Our computer systems also store information about our customers and certain of their own information, some of which is sensitive data. We have, from time to time, experienced unsuccessful attempts by others to gain unauthorized access to our computer systems and networks. In the current environment, there are numerous and evolving risks to cyber security, including criminal hackers, other unauthorized external or internal attempts to access our information technology systems and human or technological error. Although we believe we have taken and continue to take reasonable and appropriate security measures to prevent unauthorized access to our information technology systems, our technology may fail to adequately secure the private information we maintain and protect it from theft, unauthorized access or inadvertent loss. Litigation, adverse publicity or other consequences from a breach of our information technology systems, whether external or internal, could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition. In addition, the breach of our security procedures at our studios, the studios of our international partners or the studios of our competitors may generate adverse media coverage of us or the production studio industry generally, resulting in regulatory changes that affect our industry and may adversely affect the general attitudes of potential customers towards us and our brand. A breach of our security procedures may result in the exposure of our customers’ intellectual property to the public. This risk is compounded by the increased influence of social media as well as the ready availability of cameras on mobile devices. Similarly, we are subject to data protection legislation (including the Data Protection Act 2018). Noncompliance or technical defects resulting in a leak or the misuse of personal data could subject us to significant financial penalties depending on the type and severity of the breach. As a result, any such events could damage our reputation and have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsubsection Title: We may be adversely affected by terrorist activities or other security incidents, political direct action, natural disasters, significant power outages or technological system failures, and we cannot guarantee that our disaster recovery and insurance plans will adequately protect us.
Subsubsection Text: Our operations may be disrupted by a variety of risks and hazards, including environmental hazards, industrial accidents, occupational and health hazards, technical failures, hazards arising from the use of technical equipment and props on our studios, labour disputes, extended interruptions due to inclement or hazardous weather conditions and other accidents. These risks and hazards could also result in damage to, or the destruction of, studios, personal injury, environmental damage, business interruption, monetary losses and possible legal liability. In particular, the success of our operations depends on the efficient and uninterrupted operation of the infrastructure available at our studios and used to deliver our services. A failure of our infrastructure due to unforeseen disaster could occur. Our disaster recovery procedures cover specific disasters at our studios, and we believe that they are appropriate. However, it is not possible to cover every eventuality. A natural or man-made disaster may occur that we have not provided for, and while we maintain insurance and disaster recovery plans, such insurance policies and disaster recovery plans may not adequately protect us. Such disaster could have a material adverse impact on our business. Were a significant terrorist attack to take place that diminishes confidence in international flights, this could limit willingness of US-based production teams to travel to our studios. Were a significant terrorist attack to take place in the United Kingdom, this could affect the willingness of international film artists and production teams to work in the United Kingdom and specifically in the London region due to a perceived security threat. This could also have a material adverse effect on our business. Some of the artists who work at our studios are high profile. While we make every effort to maintain a secure environment and a production team will typically ----- also include its own security professionals, if a security incident were to occur to an artist while on-site, this could damage our reputation. While we currently maintain insurance policies at levels we believe are consistent with industry practice, no assurance can be given that we will be able to obtain such insurance cover at reasonable rates, or at all, or that any cover obtained will be adequate and available to cover all possible claims. Inability to recover insurance claims or to obtain future insurance coverage could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business—Our insurance coverage _may not be adequate to cover all possible losses that we could suffer and our insurance costs may increase, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations.”_

Subsubsection Title: We face risks related to health epidemics, pandemics and other outbreaks, including COVID-19, which could adversely affect our business.
Subsubsection Text: The ongoing COVID-19 outbreak is a global pandemic that has caused governments around the world to continue to implement a variety of measures to reduce the spread, including travel restrictions and bans, social distancing requirements for both individuals and businesses, shelter-in-place and lockdown orders and required closures of non-essential businesses. The government in the United Kingdom imposed two national lockdowns in addition to periodic tier-based restrictions from time to time. While Pinewood Studios and Shepperton Studios have remained open and fully operational, and the Long-term Contracts and the rent payments thereunder have not been impacted, we cannot assure you that our studios and facilities will not be closed or that our operations will not be disrupted as a result of future lockdowns or other COVID-19-related disruptions. We cannot provide assurance that the COVID-19 pandemic, including any resurgence or further variant, or any outbreak of other contagious diseases will not have a material adverse effect on our future operations. The circumstances of the current COVID-19 pandemic are changing rapidly, and at this time we are unable to reasonably estimate the full impact of the COVID-19 outbreak on our financial results and liquidity, as well as operations. The future developments of the COVID-19 pandemic could give rise to circumstances that result in one or more of the following: - we could be subject to changes in laws and governmental regulations that adversely affect our business and operations; - we may face prolonged work stoppages at our facilities, including total or partial shutdowns of one or more of our stages or production buildings; - we may experience disruptions to our agreements and operations as result of a government mandated or other closure and any other unforeseen circumstances; - we may be subject to disruptions in demand for our facilities or our customers may try to terminate their leases; - we could lose key customers, customers could become insolvent or we could have a reduction or volatility in demand for our facilities; - we may be subject to customers failing to make timely payments or defaulting on payments; - the third parties on which we rely, such as suppliers, may fail to meet their obligations to us, or may face significant disruptions in their ability to do so; - we could face increased costs and decreased income due to, for example, the need to enforce social distancing measures; - we could face increased costs or delays in our expansion projects related to supply chain challenges, disruptions, or financial difficulties faced by our contractors; - we could be subject to adverse fluctuations in currency exchange rates; - our activities, events and projects may be cancelled or delayed which may negatively impact relationships with our customers; ----- - we may experience a disruption or delay in executing our strategic capital initiatives due to travel restrictions and/or health and safety concerns; - we may face higher employee compensation costs, as well as incremental costs associated with implementing enhanced protocols to protect our employees; - we might lose key management and operating personnel; - we may be impacted by government budget constraints, tax constraints or government shutdowns; - our goodwill and other long-lived assets could become impaired; - our access to capital markets may be restricted, which could adversely affect our short-term liquidity and prevent us from fulfilling our obligations, including those under the Notes; and - we may be impacted by deterioration in the global credit, financial and economic environment, which could have a negative impact on our results of operations, financial position or cash flows. The ultimate impact of the COVID-19 pandemic depends on the severity and duration of the pandemic and the actions taken by governmental authorities and other third parties in response, each of which is uncertain, rapidly changing and difficult to predict. Any of these disruptions could adversely impact our business and results of operations. In addition, these and other impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic could have the effect of heightening many of the other risk factors disclosed in this Offering Memorandum.

Subsubsection Title: We cannot assure you that the projections or assumptions used, estimates made or procedures followed in the Valuation Report of our property portfolio are correct, accurate or complete. Additionally, other than in certain circumstances, we are not required to obtain an updated Valuation Report or further valuation reports.
Subsubsection Text: This Offering Memorandum refers to the Valuation Report with respect to our freehold properties on a portfolio basis. Property valuations, including those used in the Valuation Report, are prepared on the basis of various assumptions, estimates and projections. We cannot assure you that the assumptions or projections used, estimates made or procedures followed in the Valuation Report are correct, accurate or complete. Further, the Valuation Report expressly does not contain a valuation of any portion of our business that is not connected to our freehold properties and land. Actual results may differ materially from the assumptions and projections used and estimates made in the Valuation Report, for example, changes in the demand for our services and changes in rental prices. Other appraisers may reach different valuations of our property portfolio. Moreover, the value determined in the Valuation Report could be significantly higher than the amount that would be obtained from the actual sale of our property portfolio, especially in a distressed or liquidation scenario or if the properties are sold on an individual basis. Accordingly, the Valuation Report should not be considered a representation of the actual present or future value of our property portfolio. The realizable value of our property portfolio at any given time will depend on various factors, including but not limited to: - market, economic and media production industry conditions, including demand and capacity for our studios and services; - whether any property sales are anticipated; - the effect any sale may have on the remaining portfolio; - the availability of buyers; - the availability of financing; - the time period in which the properties are to be sold; - the supply of similar properties; ----- - the condition of the properties; - regulatory and political risks, including obtaining any necessary consents required to transfer our studio operations; and - other operational cost risks. In addition, we anticipate that the appraised value of our property portfolio will change over time, and it may change materially. After the issuance of the Notes, neither third-parties nor we will provide the holders of Notes with revised valuations and we expressly disclaim any duty to update such valuation under any circumstance. Furthermore, the Indenture does not require us to obtain an updated Valuation Report or further valuation reports unless we take certain actions, such as the incurrence of debt or payment of dividends based on the loanto-value ratios contained in the Indenture. See “Description of the Notes—Reports.”

Subsubsection Title: The withdrawal of the United Kingdom from the European Union could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.
Subsubsection Text: On June 23, 2016, the United Kingdom held a referendum in which voters voted to exit the EU, commonly referred to as “Brexit.” On March 29, 2017, the UK government invoked Article 50 of the Lisbon Treaty to begin the process of formally leaving the European Union, and on January 31, 2020, the United Kingdom withdrew its membership in the European Union and entered into a transition period which expired on December 31, 2020. During the transition period, the majority of rights and obligations associated its membership in the European Union continued to apply to the United Kingdom. On December 24, 2020, the European Union and United Kingdom announced that they had reached the EU—UK Trade and Cooperation Agreement, which was implemented on December 31, 2020 and entered into force provisionally on January 1, 2021. Despite the implementation of the EU—UK Trade and Cooperation Agreement, there remains significant uncertainty as to how the agreement will affect relations between the United Kingdom and the European Union. Significant political and economic uncertainty remains about whether the terms of the relationship will differ materially in practice from the terms before withdrawal. Lack of clarity about future laws and regulations in the United Kingdom as the United Kingdom determines which European Union laws to replace or replicate could depress economic activity and restrict our access to capital. Political parties in several other member states of the EU have proposed that a similar referendum be held on their country’s membership in the EU. It is unclear whether any other member states of the EU will hold such referendums, but further disruption can be expected if there are. Political instability in the EU as a result of Brexit may result in a material negative effect on credit markets and foreign direct investments in Europe. A potential deterioration in economic conditions could result in increased unemployment rates, increased short term and long term interest rates, consumer and commercial bankruptcy filings, a decline in the strength of national and local economies, and other results that could negatively impact household income. Areas where the uncertainty created by the UK’s withdrawal from the EU is relevant include, but are not limited to, asset valuations, currency exchange rates and credit ratings, which have been, and may continue to be, subject to increased market volatility. Any reduction in the willingness or the ability of our customers to pay their debts due to Brexit-related changes in the economic environment of the United Kingdom or the European Union could materially affect our revenue and our ability to perform debt collection in a manner consistent with our past practice. In addition, fluctuations in the exchange rate between the dollar and the British pound sterling could negatively impact us if it becomes more expensive for major film production companies from the United States and other countries to utilise our studios and facilities. Additionally, our existing contractors may be able to pass through any increased construction cost due to Brexit. While we do not anticipate any significant future disruption to our operations as a result of Brexit, any of these effects of Brexit, and others that we cannot anticipate, could adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsubsection Title: Unauthorized use of our trademarks could damage our brand and affect our reputation, business, financial condition and results of operations.
Subsubsection Text: Our brand name and reputation are integral to our business. We own the Pinewood Studios and Shepperton Studios trademarks. However, while we take steps to protect our intellectual property, unauthorized ----- use of our trademarks may occur, our rights to our trademarks could be challenged by third parties or our use of these trademarks may result in liability for trademark infringement, trademark dilution, or unfair competition, adversely affecting our profitability. We may also become subject to these risks in the international markets in which we operate and in which we plan to expand. Any impairment of our intellectual property or brands, including any due to changes in the United States, United Kingdom, or foreign intellectual property laws or the absence of effective legal protections or enforcement measures, could adversely impact our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsubsection Title: Title to some of our freehold properties may be challenged or defective. Any impairment or defect in title could have a negative impact on our business, financial condition and results of operations.
Subsubsection Text: We generated 98.6% of our total Contribution for the last twelve months ended September 30, 2021 in the United Kingdom, primarily from activities relating to our two freehold properties, Pinewood Studios and Shepperton Studios, which are integral to our business. There is no guarantee that title to any of our properties will not be challenged or impaired. Third parties may have valid claims underlying portions of our interests, including prior unregistered liens, agreements, transfers or claims and title may be affected by, among other things, undetected defects. As a result, we may be constrained in our ability to operate our properties (including the performance of our obligations under the Long-term Contracts) or unable to enforce our rights with respect to our properties. An impairment to, or defect in, title to our properties could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations.

Subsubsection Title: Our tax burden could increase due to changes in tax laws, rules or treaties or their application or interpretation, adverse decisions of tax authorities or current or future tax audits.
Subsubsection Text: Our tax burden could increase due to changes in tax laws, rules or treaties or their application or interpretation, adverse decisions of tax authorities or current or future tax audits. Our tax burden is dependent on certain aspects of tax laws and their application and interpretation. Any changes in tax laws or their interpretation could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. For example, the tax implications of Brexit are not fully known as of the date of this Offering Memorandum. As a result of future tax audits or other review actions of the relevant tax authorities, additional taxes could be identified, which could lead to an increase in our tax obligations, either as a result of the relevant tax payment being levied directly on us or as a result of us becoming liable for tax as a secondary obligor due to a primary obligor’s (such as, for example, an employee’s) failure to pay. Tax authorities in European countries are routinely challenging corporate transactions, including financings such as the Offering. Any future audit may require us to pay additional taxes (and any accrued interest and penalties).

Subsubsection Title: We may not be able to successfully integrate any business we acquire.
Subsubsection Text: We may not be able to successfully integrate any business acquired in the future into our operations without encountering difficulties. These difficulties may include, among other things, the integration of certain operating and IT systems, the loss of customers or key employees, diversion of management’s attention, the disruption of our respective ongoing businesses or possible inconsistencies in standards, procedures and policies. Furthermore, certain contracts between an acquired business and third parties may have terms and conditions that are weaker than our standard contracts, and we may not be able to integrate or update them as quickly as we would like or without incurring significant fees. In addition, we may not have, or be able to retain or hire, employees with the appropriate skill sets for the tasks associated with our integration plans, particularly in the expected time frame in which we require them, and could experience employee departures and early retirement due to relevant business changes, all of which could adversely affect the success of the integration plans. In particular, the loss of key managers or other experienced and knowledgeable local employees, may result in the loss of knowledge and continuity for the relevant business. The integration process for any acquisition or acquired business, if implemented ineffectively, would likely restrict the realisation of the full expected benefits, including revenue generation and/or any cost savings or anticipated synergies. The failure to integrate any acquisition or acquired business efficiently or otherwise in accordance with our expectations could cause an interruption of, or a loss of momentum in, our activities and could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operation. In addition, in order to fully integrate the financial accounting systems of an acquired businesses, we may be required to update and enhance our internal accounting systems and processes and our internal controls over financial reporting. This may require additional capital investments by us, and may require incremental ----- resources and system configurations that could increase our operating costs in future periods. In addition, the integration processes may require significant time and attention from our management team, resulting in a drop in performance of the existing business linked to the diversion of attention from our day-to-day operations. Moreover, we may face unexpected and significant delays in completing the integration processes. Failure to identify and remediate deficiencies in our internal controls over financial reporting in a timely manner could prevent us from accurately and timely reporting our financial results and lead to a loss of investor confidence. These difficulties and expenses could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, or results of operations.

Subsubsection Title: We are largely dependent on demand for production of new screen content and film productions. Any changes in demand for these productions or technological developments resulting in decreased demand for our studios could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.
Subsubsection Text: Our business is influenced by demand for production of new screen content and large budget film productions. Historically, demand for our studios has been largely dependent on trends in the media industry and audience demand for blockbuster films and High-end TV, which must generally be filmed at large studios such as ours. The demand for blockbuster films and High-end TV that our customers produce is subject to changing consumer trends and preferences. The availability of new screen content and changes in consumer preferences may in the future make it more difficult for our customers to predict or fulfil this demand accurately. Our success depends in part on our customer’s ability to effectively predict and respond to quickly changing consumer demands and preferences, and to translate market trends into appropriate, saleable merchandise offerings. If our customers are unable to successfully predict or respond to changing styles or trends or if they misjudge the market, the renewal of any Long-term Contract and the value of our properties may be adversely impacted, and our occupancy rates for new space not subject to Long-term Contracts could be lower, resulting in lower turnover which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows. In addition, a decrease in occupancy rates more generally across the industry may adversely impact the value of our properties irrespective of the Long-term Contracts, and could also impact the renewal of any Longterm Contract. Further, there may be advances in technology in the media industry that make the processes and techniques currently utilised at our studios obsolete or less desirable, which could have a material adverse effect on our results of operations. Should there be a trend towards productions that do not require stages, for example, animation or location filming, this could also impact on the demand for our studios, which could impact the renewal of any Long-term Contract and have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

Subsubsection Title: Our customers benefit from certain film industry tax incentive regimes in the jurisdictions in which we operate and any adverse change to these regimes, the application thereof or changes to the schemes in competing jurisdictions could negatively affect our occupancy rates and have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.
Subsubsection Text: Our customers benefit from certain tax incentive arrangements in the United Kingdom and elsewhere, for example in the United Kingdom under the UK Film Tax Relief as set out in Part 15 of the UK Corporation Tax Act 2009, and rely on such tax incentives in planning production budgets. Demand for film production studios in the United Kingdom is driven in part by this tax regime and its attractiveness relative to tax regimes in other countries that can supply the same scale and quality of production studios, such as the United States or Canada. Such tax incentive regimes in the United Kingdom and elsewhere are subject to changes in legislation and judicial interpretation. In particular, the tax incentive arrangements applicable to the UK film industry continue to attract scrutiny from the UK government, HMRC, the media and the courts. If the UK Film Tax Relief were discontinued or changed to a less incentivizing regime, it could damage the attractiveness of the United Kingdom as a destination for film-making and may have a material adverse effect on our occupancy rates and turnover, financial condition and results of operations. There can be no assurance that the policies applicable to us and our customers with respect to UK Film Tax Relief will not be eliminated or scaled back, thereby reducing the advantages that they currently provide to us and our customers. Changes to similar tax incentive regimes in other jurisdictions (such as the states of California and Georgia in the United States, the province of British Columbia and the Member States of Hungary and Croatia) ----- could add to, or detract from, the relative attraction of film making in the United Kingdom. If UK Film Tax Relief were to be reduced, amended or eliminated, if our customers no longer qualified for UK Film Tax Relief, or were other jurisdictions to increase or change their incentives, our business, financial condition, operating results or prospects could be materially and adversely affected. Additionally, the establishment by other jurisdictions (particularly by the United States) of taxes on the importation of films produced in other jurisdictions, could outweigh the economic benefit gained from UK Film Tax Relief and could, in turn, reduce the attractiveness of the United Kingdom and specifically our studios as a destination for producing films. While changes in tax regimes may not directly impact our turnover attributable to the Long-term Contracts, such changes could impact turnover for additional space not subject to Long-term Contracts or the renewal of the Long-term Contracts, as well as the value of our properties. Changes in tax regimes by the United Kingdom and other jurisdictions could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to the Notes and Our Structure
Subsubsection Title: Our substantial leverage and debt service obligations could adversely affect our business and prevent us from fulfilling our obligations with respect to the Notes and the Notes Guarantees.
Subsubsection Text: We are, and following the issuance of the Notes, will continue to be, highly leveraged. We cannot guarantee that we will be able to generate sufficient cash flow from operations to service our debt obligations on an ongoing basis. As of September 30, 2021, after giving effect to the Offering, we would have had £1,050.0 million of total third-party borrowings, comprising the Notes (excluding capital debt issuance costs). See “Capitalisation.” In addition, we have available borrowing under the Revolving Credit Facility which we may draw in the future, comprising £50.0 million of current commitments but with respect to which on or prior to the Issue Date, the Company expects to enter into an Additional Increase Confirmation (as defined in the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement) which, subject to the satisfaction of various conditions precedent set out therein, will increase the total commitments by £15.0 million to £65.0 million. Further increases to the Revolving Credit Facility may occur in the future. The degree to which we will remain leveraged following the issuance of the Notes could have important consequences to holders of the Notes offered hereby, including, but not limited to: - making it difficult for us to satisfy our obligations with respect to the Notes; - increasing our vulnerability to, and reducing our flexibility to respond to, general adverse economic and industry conditions; - requiring the dedication of a substantial portion of our cash flow from operations to the payment of principal of, and interest on, indebtedness, thereby reducing the availability of such cash flow, and limiting the ability to obtain additional financing to fund working capital, capital expenditure, acquisitions, joint ventures or other general corporate purposes; - limiting our flexibility in planning for, or reacting to, changes in our business and the competitive environment and the industry in which we operate; - placing us at a competitive disadvantage compared to our competitors, to the extent that they are not as highly leveraged; and - limiting our ability to borrow additional funds and increasing the cost of any such borrowing. Any of these or other consequences or events could have a material adverse effect on our ability to satisfy our debt obligations, including the Notes. We have historically, and may in the future, experience significant fluctuations in our monthly and intramonth working capital, which have historically been driven by our lease payment structure. In addition, our intramonth working capital varies significantly due to regularly scheduled payments on certain days of each month to our trade creditors as well as to our employees. As a result, we may rely on our Revolving Credit Facility to fund a portion of our working capital requirements going forward. Drawings under our Revolving Credit Facility will vary and may be substantially higher during certain months and weeks to compensate for months with reduced cash reserves. ----- Despite our substantial leverage, we may still be able to incur more debt under the Indenture, which could further exacerbate the risks described above. The Intercreditor Agreement provides that with respect to a distressed disposal of, or an enforcement of the security interests over, the Collateral, holders of the Notes will receive proceeds from such Collateral only after the obligations under the Revolving Credit Facility, certain hedging obligations and certain other future indebtedness permitted under the Indenture to be secured in priority to the Notes have been repaid in full. See “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Intercreditor _Agreement.” Additionally, we could raise additional debt that could be secured or could mature prior to the Notes._ Although the Indenture and the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement contain restrictions on the incurrence of additional indebtedness, these restrictions are subject to a number of significant qualifications and exceptions, and under certain circumstances, the amount of indebtedness that could be incurred in compliance with those restrictions could be substantial. In addition, the Indenture and the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement do not, prevent us from incurring obligations that do not constitute indebtedness under those agreements. We are subject to restrictive debt covenants that may limit our ability to finance our future operations and capital needs and to pursue business opportunities and activities. The Indenture, the Existing Notes Indenture and the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement restrict, among other things, our ability to: - incur or guarantee additional indebtedness and issue certain preferred stock; - create or incur certain liens; - make certain payments, including dividends or other distributions, with respect to the shares of the Issuer; - prepay or redeem subordinated debt or equity; - make certain loans, investments or acquisitions; - create encumbrances or restrictions on the payment of dividends or other distributions, loans or advances to and on the transfer of assets to the Issuer or its restricted subsidiaries; - sell, lease or transfer certain assets, including stock of restricted subsidiaries; - issue or sell share capital of certain of our subsidiaries; - engage in certain transactions with affiliates; - consolidate or merge with other entities; and - impair the security interests for the benefit of the holders of the Notes. All these limitations are subject to significant exceptions and qualifications. See “Description of the _Notes—Certain Covenants.” The covenants to which we are subject could limit our ability to finance our future_ operations and capital needs and our ability to pursue business opportunities and activities that may be in our interest. In addition, the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement requires us to comply with a financial test under certain circumstances. Our ability to meet that financial test can be affected by events beyond our control, and we cannot assure you that we will meet it. A breach of this test could result in a restriction on the ability to make new drawings under the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement and a default or an event of default under the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement. Upon the occurrence of any event of default under the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement, subject to applicable cure periods and other limitations on acceleration or enforcement, the relevant creditors could cancel the availability of the facilities and elect to declare all amounts outstanding under the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement, together with accrued interest, immediately due and payable. In addition, any default under the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement could lead to an event of default and acceleration under other debt instruments that contain cross-default or cross-acceleration provisions, including the Indenture and the Existing Notes Indenture. If our creditors, including the creditors under the Revolving Credit Facility, accelerate the payment of those amounts, we cannot assure you that our assets and the assets of our subsidiaries would be sufficient to repay those amounts in full, to satisfy all other liabilities of our subsidiaries which would be due and payable and to make payments to enable us to repay the Notes, in full or in part. In addition, if we are ----- unable to repay those amounts, our creditors could enforce against any collateral granted to them to secure repayment of those amounts.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to the Notes and Our Structure
Subsubsection Title: Despite our current indebtedness and restrictive covenants, we and our subsidiaries will still be able to incur significant additional amounts of debt or make certain restricted payments, which could further exacerbate the risks associated with our substantial leverage.
Subsubsection Text: We may be able to incur substantial additional indebtedness in the future. Although the Indenture will, and the Existing Notes Indenture and Revolving Credit Facility Agreement do, contain restrictions on the incurrence of additional indebtedness, these restrictions are subject to a number of significant qualifications and exceptions, and under certain circumstances, the amount of indebtedness that could be incurred in compliance with those restrictions could be substantial. In addition, the Indenture will, and the Existing Notes Indenture and Revolving Credit Facility Agreement do, not prevent us from incurring obligations that do not constitute indebtedness as such term is defined under those agreements. Moreover, although the Indenture will, and the Existing Notes Indenture and Revolving Credit Facility Agreement do, contain restrictions on our ability to make restricted payments, including the declaration and payment of dividends, we will be able to make substantial restricted payments under certain circumstances. Adding new debt to our and our subsidiaries’ existing debt levels or making restricted payments could exacerbate the risks associated with our substantial leverage described above, including our possible inability to service our debt.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to the Notes and Our Structure
Subsubsection Title: We will require a significant amount of cash to service our debt and sustain our operations, which we may not be able to generate or raise.
Subsubsection Text: Our ability to make principal or interest payments when due on our indebtedness, including the Revolving Credit Facility, the Existing Notes and our obligations under the Notes, and to fund our ongoing operations, will depend on our future performance and ability to generate cash, which, to a certain extent, is subject to the success of our business strategy as well as general economic, financial, competitive, legislative, legal, regulatory and other factors, as well as other factors discussed in these “Risk Factors,” many of which are beyond our control. We cannot assure you that our business will generate sufficient cash flows from operations, that currently anticipated turnover growth, cost savings and operating improvements will be realised or that future debt and equity financing will be available to us in an amount sufficient to enable us to pay our debts when due, including the Notes, or to fund our other liquidity needs, including the repayment at maturity of any then outstanding amount under the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement, which (unless the lenders thereunder agree otherwise) will mature on March 30, 2025 (being the date falling six months prior to the maturity of the Existing Notes). See “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations.” The commitments under the Revolving Credit Facility can be further increased, assuming we have the ability to incur such additional debt under the restrictive covenants included in the Indenture and the Existing Notes Indenture. See “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements” and “Description of the Notes.” At the maturity of the Notes or any other debt that we may incur, if we do not have sufficient cash flows from operations and other capital resources to pay our debt obligations, or to fund our other liquidity needs, we may be required to refinance or restructure our indebtedness. If our future cash flows from operations and other capital resources (including borrowings under the Revolving Credit Facility) are insufficient to pay our obligations as they mature or to fund our liquidity needs, we may be forced to: - reduce or delay our business activities and capital expenditure; - sell assets; - obtain additional debt or equity capital; or - restructure or refinance all or a portion of our debt, including the Notes, on or before maturity. The type, timing and terms of any future financing, restructuring, asset sales or other capital-raising transactions will depend on our cash needs and the prevailing conditions in the financial markets. We cannot assure you that we would be able to accomplish any of these alternatives on a timely basis or on satisfactory terms, if at all. In such an event, we may not have sufficient assets to repay all of our debt. ----- Any failure to make payments on the Notes on a timely basis would likely result in a reduction of our credit rating, which could also harm our ability to incur additional indebtedness. In addition, the terms of our debt, including the Notes, the Indenture, the Existing Notes Indenture and the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement may limit, and any future debt may limit, our ability to pursue any of these alternatives. Any refinancing of our debt could be at higher interest rates and may require us to comply with more onerous covenants, which could further restrict our business, financial condition and results of operations. There can be no assurance that any assets that we could be required to dispose of could be sold or that, if sold, the timing of such sale and the amount of proceeds realised from such sale would be acceptable. If we are unsuccessful in any of these efforts, we may not have sufficient cash to meet our obligations.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to the Notes and Our Structure
Subsubsection Title: Loans under the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement bear interest at floating rates that could rise significantly, increasing our costs and reducing our cash flow.
Subsubsection Text: Loans under the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement bear interest at floating rates of interest per annum rates equal to EURIBOR for loans denominated in euro, CDOR for loans denominated in Canadian dollars and LIBOR for loans denominated in US dollars or sterling, a compounded reference rate based on SONIA compounded in arrear (as the case may be), as adjusted periodically, plus a margin. The Company is in negotiations with the lenders under the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement to amend and restate the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement to provide for market standard screen rate replacement language whereby LIBOR would be replaced by SOFR for loans denominated in US dollars (with effect from a rate switch date to be agreed) and by SONIA for loans denominated in sterling (with immediate effect). Fluctuations in EURIBOR, CDOR, LIBOR, SOFR or SONIA may increase our overall interest burden and could have a material adverse effect on our ability to service our debt obligations. Although we may enter into certain hedging arrangements designed to fix a portion of these rates, there can be no assurance that hedging will be available or continue to be available on commercially reasonable terms. To the extent that interest rates or any drawings were to increase significantly, our interest expense would correspondingly increase, reducing our cash flow. Following allegations of manipulation of LIBOR, regulators and law enforcement agencies from a number of national governments and the European Union are conducting investigations into whether the banks that contribute data in connection with the calculation of daily LIBOR or EURIBOR may have been manipulating or attempting to manipulate LIBOR or EURIBOR. Actions by EURIBOR-EBF (the association that sets the regulatory framework for the calculation of EURIBOR), other regulators or law enforcement agencies could result in changes to the manner in which LIBOR or EURIBOR is determined. In addition, EURIBOR, LIBOR and other interest rates or other types of rates and indices which are deemed to be “benchmarks” are or may be the subject of ongoing national and international regulatory reform, including the implementation of the IOSCO Principles for Financial Market Benchmarks (July 2013) and the new European regulation on indices used as benchmarks in financial instruments and financial contracts or to measure the performance of investment funds, which were entered into force on June 30, 2016. Following the implementation of any such reforms, the manner of administration of benchmarks may change, with the result that they may perform differently than in the past, or benchmarks could be eliminated entirely, or there could be other consequences which cannot be predicted. For example, on July 27, 2017, and in subsequent speeches (including the speech by its chief executive on July 12, 2018) the UK Financial Conduct Authority announced that it will no longer persuade or compel banks to submit rates for the calculation of the LIBOR benchmark after 2021 and, on March 5, 2021, the FCA further announced the dates on which panel bank submissions for all LIBOR settings will cease, after which representative LIBOR rates will no longer be available (immediately after December 31, 2021, in the case of all GBP, EUR, Swiss franc and Japanese yen settings and the 1-week and 2-month USD settings, and immediately after June 30, 2023, in the case of all remaining USD settings). The elimination of the LIBOR benchmark, subject to the ongoing negotiations referred to above, will result in the rate of interest in respect of LIBOR-linked borrowings under the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement being determined with reference to such applicable compounded risk-free rate, which could result in such borrowings being subject to a rate of interest that differs from what LIBOR would have been for an equivalent period. Moreover, subsequent changes in regulatory guidance, industry standards or market practice could result in further changes to way in which LIBOR replacement mechanisms or risk-free rates are drafted, implemented or interpreted. In addition, the potential elimination of any other benchmark, changes in the manner of administration of any benchmark, or actions by regulators or law enforcement agencies could result in changes to the manner in which EURIBOR or similar benchmarks are determined, which could require an adjustment to the terms and conditions, or result in other consequences, in respect of any debt linked to such benchmark (including but not limited to the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement). Any such change, as well as manipulative practices or the cessation thereof, may result in a sudden or prolonged increase in reported EURIBOR or similar benchmarks (including any LIBOR replacement), which could have ----- an adverse impact on our ability to service debt on drawings under the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement or any future indebtedness that bears interest at floating rates of interest.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to the Notes and Our Structure
Subsubsection Title: Our hedging agreements may expose us to credit default risks and potential losses if our hedging counterparties fall into bankruptcy.
Subsubsection Text: We are currently party to certain interest rate swaps and we may enter into additional interest hedging agreements to hedge our exposure to fluctuations in interest rates, primarily under the Revolving Credit Facility. Under any such agreements, we are exposed to credit risks of our counterparties. If one or more of our counterparties falls into bankruptcy, claims we have under the swap agreements or other hedging arrangements may become worthless. Also, such hedging activities may be ineffective or may not offset more than a portion of the adverse financial impact resulting from interest rate or foreign currency fluctuations. In addition, in the event that we refinance our debt or otherwise terminate hedging agreements, we may be required to make termination payments, which would result in a loss. For more information on our hedging arrangements, see “Description of _Certain Financing Arrangements—Hedging Arrangements.”_

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to the Notes and Our Structure
Subsubsection Title: Creditors under the Revolving Credit Facility, any credit facility that refinances or replaces the Revolving Credit Facility, certain hedging obligations and certain other indebtedness permitted to be incurred on a priority basis under the Indenture are entitled to be repaid with the proceeds of the Collateral sold in any enforcement sale in priority to the Notes. Holders of the Notes will not control decisions regarding the Collateral in certain circumstances.
Subsubsection Text: The Notes and the Notes Guarantees thereof will be secured initially on a first-priority basis by the same Collateral securing the obligations under the Existing Notes and the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement. In addition, under the terms of the Indenture, we will be permitted to incur significant additional indebtedness and other obligations that may be secured by the same Collateral on a pari passu basis with the Notes and, in certain circumstances, receive proceeds from enforcement of Collateral prior to the Notes.
