Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Our operations comprise the following six business lines, each of which falls within three broader categories, and as such, we present them throughout this Offering Memorandum in this manner: - rental activities at Pinewood Studios and Shepperton Studios, comprising Stage and Other Production Accommodation, Media Hub and Television Studios; - ancillary activities at Pinewood Studios and Shepperton Studios, comprising Post Production and Ancillary Studio Services; and - other activities, primarily consisting of International Sales and Marketing. Rental activities are by far the largest contributor to our business, accounting for 92.6% of Contribution for the twelve months ended September 30, 2021. Rental activities typically include income generated by the use of stages, workshops, offices, and TV studios. Demand for our ancillary activities, accounting for 6.0% of Contribution for the twelve months ended September 30, 2021, is driven in part by demand for our rental activities. These activities typically include post production services, recharging of utilities, and revenue/profit sharing arrangements with third-party providers. The chart below displays the percentage of our Contribution by business line for the twelve months ended September 30, 2021. A brief description of each of our business lines is set forth below. _Rental: Stage and Other Production Accommodation_ Our Stage and Other Production Accommodation business line relates to Pinewood Studios and Shepperton Studios. As our core business line, Stage and Other Production Accommodation drives the largest proportion of Contribution. Stage rental relates to the rental of stage space and infrastructure required to produce screen content. The stages are used to house the physical set on which action and sounds are recorded. Our stages come in a variety of sizes and types and are generally soundproofed and heated. Pursuant to the Long-term Contracts, 100% of our existing stage space at Pinewood Studios and Shepperton Studios has been contracted by Disney and Netflix, respectively. Other Production Accommodation rental primarily relates to the renting of office space and workshop space where sets are created or stored. Demand for Other Production Accommodation is typically driven by demand for our stages. Pursuant to the terms of the Long-term Contracts, 100% of our existing Other Production Accommodation space at Pinewood Studios and Shepperton Studios has been contracted by Disney and Netflix, ----- respectively. See “Business—Material Contracts—Disney Long-term Contract” and “Business—Material _Contracts—Netflix Long-term Contract.”_ Stage and Other Production Accommodation as a percentage of Contribution has continued to increase with the completion of approximately 205,000 square feet of lettable space at Pinewood East Phase 2, which was completed in autumn 2019 (with one of the workshop blocks, totalling approximately 39,000 square feet, completed in summer 2020), and will increase further by approximately 1.1 million square feet in aggregate upon completion of the five new stages at Pinewood West, Shepperton North West and Shepperton South development projects. Disney has pre-let the five new stages at Pinewood West as part of the Disney Long-term Contract and Netflix has pre-let approximately 60% of the space being developed at the Shepperton South studio. For more information on our Stage and Other Production Accommodation business line, see “Business—Our Business _Lines—Rental—Stage and Other Production Accommodation.” Rental: Media Hub_ We lease space on-site to independent companies that support film and television production. Pinewood Studios and Shepperton Studios offer approximately 228,000 square feet of space, to approximately 178 independent businesses as of September 30, 2021. The tenants pay rent directly to us and supply their services to the production companies filming at the studios, as well as to external “off-the-lot” customers. Tenants in our Media Hub benefit from association with our strong brand and proximity to their customer base. Historically, the Media Hub has been a secure source of Contribution. There is significant demand for on-site space, with occupancy rates averaging 95% over the past ten fiscal years to the fiscal year ended March 31, 2021. For more information, see “Summary—Our Key Strengths—Resilient and Cash Generative Business Model Now _Underpinned by Long-term Contracts.” All turnover generated under the Long-term Contracts is reported under_ Stage and Other Production Accommodation. Accordingly, at the commencement of the Long-term Contracts, certain turnover previously reported under the Media Hub business line moved to Other Production Accommodation with any reallocation of the demises in connection with the Long-term Contracts. For more information on our Media Hub business line, see “Business—Our Business Lines— Rental—Media Hub.” _Rental: Television Studios_ We have three dedicated Television Studios available to hire at Pinewood Studios, one of which is contracted to the National Lottery (Camelot). We have relationships with customers such as the BBC, Endemol Shine UK, Fremantle and Avalon, which contribute to the success of this business line. In addition to earning turnover from Television Studio space, we generate turnover from supplying freelance crew as well as owned and hired television equipment. The Television Studios at Pinewood Studios are excluded from the Disney Long-term Contract and we will continue to manage and hire the Television Studios on a case-by-case basis. For more information on our Television Studios business line, see “Business—Our Business Lines—Rental—Television _Studios.” Ancillary: Ancillary Studio Services_ Ancillary Studio Services comprise additional services utilised by production companies hiring Stage and Other Production Accommodation. The key services we provide in this business line are utilities (for example, we offer electricity, water and gas, which are principally passed through at cost to our long-term contract customers) and other services through revenue or profit-sharing agreements with preferred third-party service providers. For more information on our Ancillary Studio Services business line, see “Business—Our Business _Lines—Ancillary—Ancillary Studio Services.” Ancillary: Post Production_ Post Production provides support to content creators. This business line includes localisation services which offer audio mixing in multiple languages for our customers requiring international re-versioning services. In addition, through this business line we offer our customers mixing theatres, cutting rooms, and production offices available for dry hire at Pinewood Studios and Shepperton Studios, all of which are excluded from the Long-term Contracts. For more information, see “Business—Our Business Lines—Ancillary—Post Production.” _Other Activities_ We also generate turnover by providing sales, marketing and brand licensing services and consultancy services relating to studio space to other studios around the world. Historically, we provided these services to studios in Atlanta, Canada, China, the Dominican Republic, Malaysia, and Wales. On August 5, 2019, we divested ----- our equity interest in Pinewood Atlanta Studios, although we continued to provide sales and marketing services until October 14, 2020, and it ceased to be a Pinewood branded studio on December 14, 2020. We separately ceased providing services to studios in Malaysia in July 2019 and in Wales on March 31, 2020.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We are one of the leading independent providers of the infrastructure that is required to produce film and television content. Founded in 1936 and headquartered in the United Kingdom, we own premium, large-scale facilities, also known as studios, for hosting film, television and other media productions. Our two freehold studios, Pinewood Studios and Shepperton Studios, are set over 502 acres with approximately 2.0 million square feet of space in close proximity to central London, which makes us a preferred choice for major film production companies. Pinewood Studios and Shepperton Studios are valued at a Market Value of £2,158 million pursuant to the Valuation Report. Pinewood-branded studios have hosted over 2,000 films, which have received among them 170 Oscar awards and 230 BAFTA awards and include numerous blockbuster film productions such as 23 out of the 25 James Bond films, 16 out of the 27 Marvel super hero films and 8 out of the 12 Star Wars films. We signed long-term index-linked contracts for 100% of our Stage and Other Production Accommodation at Pinewood Studios and Shepperton Studios with Disney and Netflix, respectively in 2019. Collectively, these Long-term Contracts cover a total of approximately 1.6 million square feet. These contracts are each for an initial term of at least ten years and provide for annual rent increases, subject to floors. Disney utilises Pinewood Studios for its own productions as well as for its affiliated production companies, including Lucasfilm and Marvel. Netflix utilises Shepperton Studios as a production hub to produce original content. The Long-term Contracts simplify our business model, improve the resilience and visibility of our turnover from investment-grade rated tenants, and demonstrate the continued demand for our facilities at Pinewood Studios and Shepperton Studios. See “Business—Material Contracts—Disney Long-term Contract” and “Business—Material _Contracts—Netflix Long-term Contract.”_ Demand for purpose-built studio space remains extremely strong. Over the last few years, we have been progressing our expansion plans at our UK studios, Pinewood Studios and Shepperton Studios. Construction is currently underway for five new stages at Pinewood Studios that will provide approximately 100,000 square feet of additional stage space at Pinewood West, which we anticipate opening in 2022. Disney has pre-let these stages pursuant to the Disney Long-term Contract. At Shepperton Studios, we have detailed planning consent to develop an additional approximately 1.0 million square feet of lettable area, adjacent to the existing studio. We intend to develop this expansion in two phases, which we refer to as Shepperton North West and Shepperton South. Construction of both phases is underway and we have entered into fixed price contracts for the works, thereby significantly derisking the execution of these projects. Additionally, we entered into a long-term contract with Netflix to pre-let approximately 0.5 million square feet of space, equivalent to 60% of the space being developed, at our Shepperton South studio. The lease will commence on completion of the development, expected towards the end of 2023, and is on terms similar to the Netflix Long-term Contract. There is strong interest from several customers for the remaining approximately 0.5 million square feet being developed at Shepperton. In the twelve months ended September 30, 2021, Contribution from Stage and Other Production Accommodation, together with the specialty stages, accounted for 83.8% of total Contribution. We earned 98.6% of our total Contribution for the twelve months ended September 30, 2021 in the United Kingdom, with 92.6% representing rental income at Pinewood Studios and Shepperton Studios, our two freehold studios. -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Factors Affecting Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: From time to time, we may consider the acquisition of other established film production studios. Should we pursue and complete any such acquisitions, our results of operations following any such acquisitions may not be consistent with, or otherwise comparable to, our historical results of operations, including, but not limited to, our turnover, operating costs and results from participating interests.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Factors Affecting Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: Improvement and Expansion of Existing Studios and Facilities
Subsubsection Text: The amount of rental fees we can collect is limited by the amount of space available for rent at our studios and, to an extent, the quality and features of such available space. We carry out ongoing maintenance capital expenditure on our existing studios, and we have also completed several capital expenditure projects which have enabled us to expand our capacity to accommodate our customers and to upgrade the desirability of our business lines. Upon completion, these projects historically have contributed to increased turnover for subsequent periods. Our capital expenditure costs during the three fiscal years ended March 31, 2021 and the six months ended September 30, 2021 were attributable primarily to the development of five new stages at Pinewood West, enabling works at Shepperton North West and the design and enabling works at Shepperton South expansion, the development of Pinewood East Phase 2, including an associated obligation under section 106 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990, as amended, to invest in road improvements, the commencement of construction of the five new stages at Pinewood West, the purchase of certain land holdings, Alderbourne Farm, which is an approximately 88-acre site adjacent to Pinewood Studios, Pinewood South, which is an approximately 77-acre site adjacent to Pinewood Studios, and other optimisation activity at our existing sites, together with other capital maintenance activity of existing studio space. For more information on the Shepperton Expansion Projects, see “Business—Studios and Facilities.” In 2014, we secured outline planning consent to develop: (i) approximately 300,000 square feet of space in connection with Pinewood East Phase 1, which was completed in July 2016; (ii) approximately 205,000 square feet in connection with Pinewood East Phase 2, which was completed in autumn 2019 (with one of the workshop blocks, totalling approximately 39,000 square feet, completed in summer 2020) on budget and on time; and (iii) ----- a further approximately 150,000 square feet GEA in connection with Pinewood East Phase 3, and received detailed planning consent for the development of four new sound stages and a workshop totalling approximately 90,000 square feet GEA in June 2021. Construction of the five new stages at Pinewood West is underway and is expected to complete in 2022. Pursuant to the Disney Long-term Contract, Disney has pre-let these five new stages. See “Business—Studios and Facilities—Pinewood Studios.” With this Offering and a portion of the cash available on balance sheet as of September 30, 2021, we expect to fund the remaining capital expenditure associated with the Shepperton Expansion Project and the five stages at Pinewood West. Funds to pay for the foregoing expansion projects are expected to be deployed in the next two and a half years in accordance with the following schedule: approximately 20% in the year ending March 31, 2022, approximately 50% in the year ending March 31, 2023 and the remaining approximately 30% in the year ending March 31, 2024; however, the foregoing disbursement schedule is subject to change as the construction and build-out progresses. Additional capital expenditures related to other expansion projects are expected to be funded from cash generated by operating activities (including new leases that come online related to the Shepperton Expansion Project) and other capital sources consistent with a prudent financial policy. See “Use of Proceeds.”

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Factors Affecting Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: We collect fees under contracted bookings for our stages, Other Production Accommodation, Media Hub, and Television Studios. For the periods under review, our Stage and Other Production Accommodation occupancy rates were calculated on a weekly basis by square footage and time contracted and paid for. If a customer paid to occupy a facility and then subsequently cancelled, the space was still recorded as being occupied based on the fact that a payment had been received and was non-refundable or was refundable as the space was subsequently resold by us. Stage occupancy is formulated by calculating the proportion of square footage utilised as a percentage of square footage available. Before the commencement of the Long-term Contracts, we faced the uncertainty that should customer demand increase or decrease over a given period, Stage and Other Production Accommodation occupancy rates could increase or decrease accordingly, which could affect turnover generation and costs. However, in connection with the Long-term Contracts, we contracted 100% of our Stage and Other Production Accommodation, and certain areas which were previously occupied by Media Hub tenants, at Pinewood Studios and Shepperton Studios in the United Kingdom with Disney and Netflix, respectively, for the duration of the respective Long-term Contracts. Subsequently, all turnover generated under the Long-term Contracts will be reported under Stage and Other Production Accommodation, and certain turnover previously reported under the Media Hub business line shifted to Other Production Accommodation with any reallocation of the demise in accordance with the Longterm Contracts. As a result, Stage and Other Production Accommodation occupancy rates will remain stable during the duration of these Long-term Contracts. See “Business—Material Contracts—Disney Long-term _Contract” and “Business—Material Contracts—Netflix Long-term Contract.”_ Turnover from Television Studios typically is generated in the same manner; however, television productions generally occupy our studios for a shorter period of time than film production companies. Our Television Studios are excluded from the Long-term Contracts and, therefore, we anticipate they will continue to operate and be booked in future periods in a manner consistent with the periods under review. We also generated turnover from the provision of utilities and other services to these customers under the Ancillary Studio Services business line. We charge utilities to Disney and Netflix as costs are incurred and, thus, no margin is earned with regard to utilities costs to these customers. Media Hub occupancy rates are calculated under the same method as Stage and Other Production Accommodation occupancy rates. We had Media Hub occupancy rates of 94%, 94%, and 90% for the fiscal years ended March 31, 2019, 2020, and 2021, respectively. We collect fees, categorised as turnover attributable to Media Hub, under lease payments from our tenants. Similar to Stage and Other Production Accommodation, should customer demand increase or decrease over a given period, Media Hub occupancy rates may increase or decrease accordingly, which may affect turnover generation. Therefore, our Media Hub occupancy rate is a key factor affecting our turnover sourced from Media Hub. In addition, customers utilising our Stage and Other Production Accommodation are often customers of tenants in our Media Hub; therefore, higher stage occupancy rates can ultimately lead to higher demand for Media Hub tenant services. See “Business—Material Contracts— _Disney Long-term Contract” and “Business—Material Contracts—Netflix Long-term Contract.”_ ----- Renting space under the Stage and Other Production Accommodation and Media Hub businesses contributed a majority of our turnover for the fiscal year ended March 31, 2021. Turnover attributable to other business lines, such as Ancillary Studio Services, is also largely affected by stage occupancy rates and historically has grown generally in line with Stage and Other Production Accommodation. We believe this will continue.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Factors Affecting Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: For the periods under review prior to entering into the Long-term Contracts, our rental rates were set taking into account the demand for our stages, Other Production Accommodation and Media Hub Space. These periods were relatively strong and allowed us to undertake consistent annual rental fee increases. Historically, we established a standard rate schedule (our “rate card”) for our business lines, which included specified weekly rental rates for the stages, Other Production Accommodation and Television Studios. Individual production companies may have received discounts against the rental rates appearing on the rate card; however, our realised rental rates have been generally consistent across our major film production company customers. Increases or decreases to our rental rates have a direct impact on the turnover attributable to the affected business line and on our total turnover. Media Hub rental rates are governed by individual leases with each of our tenants, based on an appropriate rate per square foot for the nature and grade of facilities, and for the period of the lease. The rental rates for our Stage and Other Production Accommodation are provided for in the Long-term Contracts with Disney and Netflix. Rent under these Long-term Contracts is either fixed or linked to UK RPI, with rental rate increases if UK RPI reaches certain thresholds. See “Business—Material Contracts.”

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Factors Affecting Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: Post Production and Other International Activity
Subsubsection Text: Turnover from certain of our business lines, such as Post Production and Other (including International Sales and Marketing), is linked less strongly to our stage occupancy rates, compared with other business lines, such as Stage and Other Production Accommodation. For example, while turnover from Post Production is partially affected by our stage occupancy rates, results from Post Production are significantly impacted by the number of independent projects undertaken. Turnover for Post Production activities is also impacted by the level and experience of staff required and complexity of the individual project. This business line includes localisation services which offers audio mixing in multiple languages for our customers who require international reversioning services. In addition, through this business line we offer our customers mixing theatres, cutting rooms, and production offices available for dry hire at Pinewood Studios and Shepperton Studios. Historically, through Post Production we offered picture services and preparation of “dailies,” or raw, unedited production footage prepared at the end of day of filming and creative audio services involving sound mixing and voice over audio. As of summer 2019, we began to phase out our Pinewood Digital “picture services” business and as of spring 2020, we began to phase out our creative audio business. The discontinuation of picture services and creative audio services in our Post Production business line had a negative impact on our consolidated turnover for the fiscal year ended March 31, 2021. For more information on the activities undertaken in our Post Production business line, see “Business—Our Business Lines—Ancillary—Post Production.” Similarly, our International Sales and Marketing turnover is not linked to stage occupancy rates at Pinewood Studios and Shepperton Studios but is instead primarily affected by new commercial agreements being secured, or existing contracts expiring or being terminated, with only a component of the fees linked to occupancy rates at international Pinewood-branded studios. During July 2019, we announced that the collaboration with Pinewood Iskandar Malaysia Studios ended by mutual agreement in connection with the initial objectives of the collaboration being achieved. On August 5, 2019, we divested our equity interest in Pinewood Atlanta Studios, although it continued to be a Pinewood-branded studio until December 14, 2020, and we continued to provide sales and marketing services until October 14, 2020. Following discussions with the Welsh Government, our agreement for the studio in Cardiff ended on March 31, 2020. International Sales and Marketing turnover was lower for the fiscal year ended March 31, 2021, in particular, due to the cessation of the sales and marketing arrangements with the studios in Malaysia, Atlanta and Wales. For more information on our International Sales and Marketing activities, see “Business—Our Business Lines—Other Activities—International Sales and _Marketing.”_ -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Factors Affecting Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Our direct costs include costs directly attributable to providing Stage and Other Production Accommodation, and other services to our customers. They include the purchase price of utilities, rental of temporary accommodation for our customers, staff costs directly associated with the Television Studios, providing Post Production services, studio facility operations and delivering international sales and marketing agreements, all of which have a variable component and are affected by occupancy rates or, in Post Production, by work completed. There is a fixed component to our utilities costs, as there is a minimum amount of utilities spend, such as on electricity, that is required to operate our studios, regardless of occupancy rates. Historically, we have been able to pass through a portion of these costs to our customers, often with a margin. Since the commencement of the Long-term Contracts, we have been able to pass through energy costs associated with all Studio space occupied under the contracts at cost. In addition, we have variable costs in relation to equipment and facilities that are hired out to our customers on a cost-plus margin basis.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Factors Affecting Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Costs relating to the depreciation of property, plant, and equipment are generally fixed. Capital expenditure cost comprises the aggregate amount paid and the fair value of any other consideration given to acquire the asset, and includes costs directly attributable to making the asset capable of operating as intended. Depreciation is calculated on all property, plant, and equipment, other than land, from the time they are available for use on a straight-line basis by dividing the capital expenditure cost over the estimated useful life. The estimated useful life for the various categories of our property, plant, and equipment are as follows: Freehold buildings: 30 to 50 years Freehold improvements: 5 to 25 years Fixtures, fittings and equipment: 3 to 10 years Costs incurred in improving and/or expanding our studios are, therefore, capitalised and then depreciated in line with our policy. As we continue to invest in the improvement and expansion of our existing studios and facilities, costs associated with the depreciation of the corresponding capitalised costs will correspondingly increase. Software assets, capitalised as intangible assets, were put into use in May 2020 and amortised from that date. The useful life of these assets is 10 years.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Factors Affecting Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Staff costs are a significant variable expense, accounting for 26%, 24%, and 24% of our total operating costs in the fiscal years ended March 31, 2019, 2020, and 2021, respectively, and we employed an average of 261, 223, and 195 people in those years, respectively. Staff costs include salaries, social security costs, pension costs, compensation for loss of office, and other employee benefits. Our staff costs are affected by: - discretionary pay awards which are periodic salary increases and performance bonuses for our employees; - legislation governing employee pensions, in particular legislation governing the automatic enrolment of employees into a workplace pension; - changes in staff numbers and experience as our business needs and requirements change; - management restructuring and streamlining relating to changes in the management structure; and - activity-based staff requirements.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Factors Affecting Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Facility costs include the costs of maintaining our Stage and Other Production Accommodation, business rates, insurance, cleaning, and security for our studios. For the periods under review, certain of these costs could ----- be scaled back at times of low occupancy; however, there was a baseline level of facility costs required to operate our studios even at minimal occupancy rates. The Long-term Contracts encompass 100% of our Stage and Other Production Accommodation at our Pinewood Studios and Shepperton Studios sites. Pursuant to the terms of the Long-term Contracts, facility costs will continue to be borne by the Company, and we will be required to cover the costs of maintaining the state of our Stage and Other Production Accommodation to their standard at the commencement of the Long-term Contracts.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Factors Affecting Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Historically, we generally received payment for Stage and Other Production Accommodation partially in advance of customer occupation, and partially spread over the period of occupation of the studio. This payment in advance is recognised as turnover over the course of the lease and affects the timing of our cash flows. Since the commencement of the Long-term Contracts, 100% of our Stage and Other Production Accommodation is subject to Long-term Contracts that provide for either quarterly or annual payments in advance and in full. Under the terms of the Long-term Contracts, if either Disney or Netflix (as the case may be) does not require part or all of their contracted space, they can ask us to find a third-party production to hire the space. We will attempt (but are under no obligation) to secure a replacement booking but full rental fees remain payable by Disney and/or Netflix to us under the Long-term Contracts. If we are able to re-sell stage space at or above the rate prescribed in the relevant Long-term Contract, the rent received under the Long-term Contract will be refunded and we are entitled to any overage or increase above the rate pursuant to the relevant Long-term Contract. Accordingly, we anticipate greater consistency in future periods with respect to turnover generated from our Stage and Other Production Accommodation. Historically, only a fraction of our stage space was subject to long-term contracts. For example, until October 2019, only approximately 25% of our UK stages were under long-term contracts, with the remainder under typical hire arrangements. Since the commencement of the Long-term Contracts, 100% of our UK Stage and Other Production Accommodation is now hired. As our space becomes subject to long-term contracts instead of typical hire arrangements, fluctuations in occupancy rates, volatility in turnover generated from Stage and Other Production Accommodation and variability in rental rate charges will decrease. Each of the Disney Long-term Contract and Netflix Long-term Contract provides for annual rental rate adjustments. The contracts have slight variations in the annual rent escalator, although both contracts refer to UK RPI to guide the escalator at each year or periodically through the contract term, with increases subject to a floor but without a cap on UK RPI. In accordance with FRS102, certain of the indexation provisions result in revenue over the term being recognised on a straight-line basis, rather than increasing each year. As a consequence, this revenue is adjusted upwards in the initial years of the contract compared with the contractual amounts due, and this uplift will reverse over the term of the contract. See “Business—Material Contracts.”

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Factors Affecting Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Our turnover is driven primarily by rental fees that we collect from renting out space under our Stage and Other Production Accommodation, Media Hub, and Television Studios business lines. The amount of rental fees we receive under these business lines is, in turn, driven primarily by the amount of space we have available to rent and the rental rates we charge our customers. Prior to entering into the Long-term Contracts, our turnover was also impacted by occupancy rates, however occupancy rates are of less relevance because 100% of our available Stage and Other Production Accommodation space is booked or otherwise occupied pursuant to the terms of the Long-term Contracts. See “Business—Material Contracts—Disney Long-term Contract” and “Business—Material Contracts—Netflix Long-term Contract.” Our costs can be categorised as fixed costs, such as depreciation, variable costs, such as direct costs, and costs with both a fixed and a variable component, such as staff costs and facility costs. For the periods under review, the impact of variable costs on our results fluctuated based upon, among other factors, occupancy rates and our ability to pass along costs associated with any such fluctuations to our customers. However, since the commencement of the Long-term Contracts with Disney and Netflix, 100% of our Stage and Other Production Accommodation at our Pinewood Studios and Shepperton Studios sites in the United Kingdom is occupied, mitigating the potential adverse impact of fluctuations in occupancy rates. In turn, with a greater level of stability in occupancy rates, we anticipate our variable costs will stabilise and such costs will be recovered pursuant to the terms of the Long-term Contracts. However, there is no guarantee that unforeseen events, such as the COVID-19 pandemic, will not adversely affect our occupancy rates, cost base or revenue. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating _to Our Business—We face risks related to health epidemics, pandemics and other outbreaks, including COVID- 19, which could adversely affect our business.”_ A portion of our costs are fixed and cannot be attributed to one business line or directly passed on to our customers. We describe each of the factors affecting our results of operations in turn below.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic and measures to prevent its spread, including restrictions on travel, imposition of quarantines, and prolonged closures of workplaces and other businesses, may impact our business. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, our operations have not experienced significant disruption as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic. In particular, for the six months ended September 30, 2021, our turnover increased by £2.8 million or 6.1%, compared to the six months ended September 30, 2020, which we primarily attribute to operating levels of our localisation services within our Post Production business line and Ancillary Studio Services returning to normal, pre-COVID-19 pandemic levels, where our customers have full production schedules resulting in our studios being busy. See —“Results of Operations—Turnover.” In addition, for the six months ended September 30, 2021, our cost of sales was £18.7 million, an increase of £1.2 million or 6.6%, compared to the six months ended September 30, 2020, which we primarily attribute to activity levels returning to normal, pre COVID-19 pandemic levels, an increase occupation of our Television Studios and energy costs which were charged under our Long-term Contracts at cost and a slight increase in maintenance costs incurred in connection with maintenance of our facilities. See “—Results of Operations—Cost of Sales.” For a discussion of potential negative effects on our business caused by COVID-19, see “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our _Business—We face risks related to health epidemics, pandemics and other outbreaks, including COVID-19, which could adversely affect our business.”_ -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The Company separately presents, as adjusted items, gains, and losses on major disposals, certain remeasurements and other significant items. We have included certain of these adjusted items in the tables presented herein, as well as an explanation of those adjusted items. All of the adjusted items shown below are transactions that are either unusual in size or nature, or have limited predictive value. Providing additional information on adjusted items and presenting them separately from the total statutory performance of the Group provides a consistent presentation of the underlying operating performance of the Group.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Concentrated Focus on Core Business Lines
Subsubsection Text: Since the completion of our public to private transaction, we have focused our attention on core business lines and streamlined our operations. Certain historical activities, which were ancillary in nature, over-complicated our business model, utilised a disproportionate amount of management’s time and attention, and collectively reduced our total Contribution. Therefore, we have ceased the operations of such activities including: - in February 2020, we announced the closure of creative audio services in connection with our Post Production business line, with last works completed in March 2020; - in July 2019, following a decline in turnover from picture services in connection with our Post Production business, we phased out our picture services activities in this area across the remainder of the calendar year through summer 2020; and - in October 2017, we surrendered our lease in relation to Pinewood Studios Wales, resulting in the cessation of lease payments, and entered into an operating agreement, under which we were entitled to an annual fee in return for the operation of Pinewood Studios Wales, until March 31, 2020, when the operating agreement ended. ----- Accordingly, such operations which have been ceased, may affect the comparability of our results of operations between the periods presented in this Offering Memorandum.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: 2019 Refinancing Transaction and 2025 Notes Tap Issuance
Subsubsection Text: In September 2019, we incurred £550.0 million of senior secured notes due 2025 (the “2019 Refinancing

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: _Administrative Expenses_ In the fiscal year ended March 31, 2021, adjusted items included a credit of £0.5 million related to the release of unamortised deferred trademark royalties in connection with Pinewood Forest, following on from the Group formally ending its relationship with its former joint venture, Pinewood Atlanta Studios. In the fiscal year ended March 31, 2020, adjusted items included restructuring charges of £0.4 million, a receipt net of costs of £0.7 million following the early termination of the collaboration with Pinewood Iskandar Malaysia Studios that ended pursuant to a mutual agreement, and a £1.7 million fair value charge in relation to Pinewood MBS. In 2015, the Group entered into an agreement to acquire a 15% equity interest in PMBS and its wholly owned subsidiary Pinewood MBS Lighting Limited, a company that was subsequently granted an arrangement to provide lighting services at the Group’s UK facilities. The agreement included an option to step-up the Group’s equity interest in PMBS to 25% after five years for nil consideration. In December 2019, the option became exercisable and led to the reclassification of PMBS as an associate prospectively from that date, and the reversal of £1.7 million previously recognised fair value gains down to the original cost of nil. In the fiscal year ended March 31, 2019, restructuring charges of £0.9 million related to streamlining and changing the management structure. ----- _Other Operating Expenses_ In the fiscal year ended March 31, 2020, we restructured the Group’s property portfolio to optimise ownership across subsidiary undertakings, which included a transaction subject to stamp duty land tax and £2.6 million in land transfer tax that we calculated and paid in the year. This restructuring is expected to facilitate current and future commercial arrangements. Additionally, in February 2020, the Group received £2.8 million for the sale of its interest in POP Global Ltd. The investment was previously fully impaired and held at nil cost. After we discontinued picture services and our creative audio services business, our property, plant, and equipment associated with these business lines were assessed and impaired down to their realisable value, resulting in an impairment charge of £0.8 million. _Loss on Disposal of Participating Interests_ In the fiscal year ended March 31, 2020, a loss on the disposal of £1.8 million was recognised on the sale of our equity investment in Pinewood Atlanta Studios, with the sale to our joint venture partner completing in August 2019. Proceeds net of costs amounted to £12.6 million and included earnout provisions linked to the financial performance of the studios for the year ended December 31, 2019. The sale proceeds included £0.6 million relating to earnout payments received in January 2020. _Gain on Loan to Participating Interests_ In the fiscal year ended March 31, 2021, the step-up associated with the Group’s investment in PMBS was completed for nil consideration. The step-up resulted in the Group’s equity interest in PMBS increasing from 15% to 25%. In addition, PMBS issued additional loan notes to the Group. The additional loan notes were recognised initially on our balance sheet at fair value, estimated to be the face value, resulting in a corresponding gain in our income statement of £2.0 million. _Interest Payable and Similar Charges_ In the fiscal year ended March 31, 2020, the Group issued £550 million aggregate principal amount of 3.25% Senior Secured Notes, due September 2025, and entered into an amendment and restatement agreement to amend and restate the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement. Part of the proceeds from the issuance were used to fully redeem the Group’s existing £250.0 million 3.75% Senior Secured Notes, due 2023. The early redemption of the previous loan notes included a “make-whole” payment of £5.9 million to the bondholders. In addition, the derecognition of the previous loan notes and facility fees held at amortised cost resulted in an extinguishment charge of £5.9 million. Both the make-whole payment and the extinguishment charge have been presented as adjusted items.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Issuance”). The proceeds were used (i) for expansion projects, (ii) for general corporate purposes, and (iii) to pay
Subsubsection Text: In September 2014, we entered into a commercial arrangement with CRP MB Studios Productions Services Europe LLC (“CRP”) to provide lighting services to Pinewood Studios and Shepperton Studios through Pinewood MBS. In return for a revenue share under an exclusive equipment agreement, we appointed Pinewood MBS as the exclusive provider of lighting to productions based at Pinewood Studios and Shepperton Studios for a 10-year term with effect from January 1, 2015. We held a 15% equity interest in Pinewood MBS and a 15% holding in their unsecured loan notes for the first five years of the arrangement, both of which were carried at fair value. Movement in fair value with respect to Pinewood MBS was first recognised through exceptional items for the fiscal year ended March 31, 2017, which is now presented as administrative expenses/(income) adjusted items. With effect from December 31, 2019, the 15% equity holding was derecognised as a financial instrument carried at fair value and recognised as an investment in associate initially recorded at a cost of nil. The derecognition of the financial instrument was charged to the income statement as a fair value adjustment of the investment. On June 15, 2020, PMBS made the required notices to confirm the re-designation of deferred shares and legally increased the Group’s interest in the associate to 25%. We recognised additional loan notes issued by PMBS on our balance sheet at fair value, estimated to be the face value, resulting in a corresponding gain in the income statement of £2.0 million. The loan notes are subsequently measured at amortised cost. During fiscal year ended March 31, 2021, PMBS repaid £0.4 million of the outstanding loan notes. See “Summary of Historical Financial Information—Statement of _Comprehensive Income.” To the extent our ownership interest in Pinewood MBS increases through recognition_ of our share of the post-tax profits and losses of Pinewood MBS, our financial results for future periods may not be comparable.

Subsequent to, and as a result of, the 2019 Refinancing Transaction and the 2025 Notes Tap Issuance, our interest expense increased due to the aggregate principal amount of indebtedness, which impacted our finance expense, including our interest payable and similar expenses. In addition, we experienced an increase in interest receivable due to proceeds that were upstreamed in the form of a related party loan to the parent.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Comparability of Future Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: On June 6, 2019, we entered into a multi-year contract with Netflix for 100% of Stage and Other Production Accommodation at Shepperton Studios, which commenced October 31, 2019. See “Business— _Material Contracts—Netflix Long-term Contract.” On August 23, 2019, we entered into a multi-year contract with_ Disney for 100% of Stage and Other Production Accommodation at Pinewood Studios, which commenced January 1, 2020. In the periods that followed, we reported all turnover generated under the Long-term Contracts under Stage and Other Production Accommodation. Accordingly, certain turnover reported under the Media Hub business line in prior periods shifted to Other Production Accommodation due to reallocation in connection with the Long-term Contracts pursuant to the demises. See “Business—Material Contracts—Disney Long-term _Contract.” On April 2, 2021, we entered into a long-term contract with Netflix to pre-let approximately 0.5 million_ square feet of space, equivalent to 60% of the space being developed, at our Shepperton South studio. The lease will commence on completion of the development, expected towards the end of 2023, and we expect our results of operations to be similarly impacted. ----- Historically, only a fraction of our stage space was subject to long-term contracts. For example, in September 2018, approximately 25% of our UK stages were under long-term contract and the remainder was under typical hire arrangements. Since the commencement of the Long-term Contracts, 100% of our UK Stage and Other Production Accommodation is now hired. As our space becomes subject to long-term contracts instead of typical hire arrangements, fluctuations in occupancy rates, volatility in turnover generated from Stage and Other Production Accommodation, and variability in rental rate charges will decrease. Each of the Disney Long-term Contract and Netflix Long-term Contract provides for annual rental rate adjustments. The contracts have slight variations in the annual rent escalator, although both contracts refer to UK RPI to guide the escalator at each year or periodically through the contract term, with increases subject to a floor but without a cap on UK RPI. In accordance with FRS102, certain of the indexation provisions result in revenue over the term being recognised on a straight-line basis, rather than increasing each year. As a consequence, this revenue is adjusted upwards in the initial years of the contract compared with the contractual amounts due, and this uplift will reverse over the term of the contract. See “Business—Material Contracts.” Payments for Stage and Other Production Accommodation under each Long-term Contract is made in advance of the relevant period, with the Long-term Contracts requiring payment in advance, either on a quarterly or annual basis. Historically, we generally received payment under Stage and Other Production Accommodation partially in advance of customer occupation and partially spread over the period of occupation of the studio. Accordingly, the Long-term Contracts result in a predictable distribution of payments for our Stage and Other Production Accommodation. In addition, we have implemented some operational efficiencies as an indirect effect of having entered into these Long-term Contracts. As a result of these changes, our results of operations may not be comparable to prior periods. Further, the results of operations since the start of the Long-term Contracts may not be comparable with future periods, should the unleased element of Shepperton South and Shepperton North West be let under typical hire agreements.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Comparability of Future Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: We have experienced, and continue to experience, excess demand for our facilities, which we are accommodating through further expansion of our existing studios. At Pinewood Studios, and as part of the Disney Long-term Contract, Disney has committed to pre-let five new stages at Pinewood West. Work on these stages has commenced and is expected to complete in 2022, adding approximately 100,000 square feet of additional space and contributing to the future growth of the business. In addition, at Pinewood Studios, we have outline planning consent to develop an additional approximately 120,000 square feet in connection with Pinewood East Phase 3. See “—Business—Studios and _Facilities—Pinewood Studios.”_ At Shepperton Studios, we own approximately 123-acres of land, of which 97 acres have the potential for future development. In 2021, we received detailed planning consent to develop an additional 1.0 million square feet of studio space, which we intend to develop across two phases, Shepperton North West and Shepperton South. Additionally, in 2021, we entered into a long-term contract with Netflix to pre-let approximately 0.5 million square feet of space, equivalent to 60% of the space being developed, at our Shepperton South studio. The lease will commence on completion of the development, expected towards the end of 2023, and is on terms similar to the Netflix Long-term Contract. There is strong interest from several customers for the remaining approximately 0.5 million square feet being developed at Shepperton across both phases. In February 2019, we acquired Alderbourne Farm, an approximately 88-acre site adjacent to Pinewood Studios, and in August 2020, we acquired an approximately 77-acre site adjacent to Pinewood Studios which we refer to as Pinewood South, extending the Group’s total land holding in the United Kingdom to 502 acres and providing us with further opportunity to expand at a measured pace based on customer demand. In September 2020, we submitted an application for outline planning consent for the 77-acre site adjacent to Pinewood Studios. We expect to receive a decision from the local planning authority before January 2022. If successful, the planning application would give us the ability to build a global screen industries growth hub comprising: (i) additional production accommodation space; (ii) a visitor experience; (iii) an education hub; and (iv) a business growth hub. As we move forward with these expansion projects and any planned future expansion projects, there may be an increase in debt costs, initial start-up costs, and direct and indirect operating costs. See “Risk Factors—Risk _Relating to Our Business—We face completion risks, including competition from new market entrants and the expansion of new and existing studios.” In addition, there may be an increase in our revenue and Adjusted_ EBITDA. Our results of operations may not be comparable to prior periods should we pursue future expansion projects. For more information on our expansion projects, see “Summary—Our Key Strengths—Continue to ----- _Expand Our Footprint at Pinewood Studios and Shepperton Studios.” There can be no guarantee that we will_ complete these projects as planned or at all.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Comparability of Future Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: Exit from Joint Ventures and Third-Party Studio Licenses
Subsubsection Text: _Pinewood Atlanta Studios Joint Venture and Management Services Agreement_ In June 2014, we entered into a joint venture agreement with River’s Rock LLC in connection with Pinewood Atlanta Studios, subject to which we held a 40% equity interest (and received a 40% share of profit) and held 50% of the voting rights. In addition, we entered into a management services agreement, pursuant to which we were responsible for sales and marketing activity through our sales team, and in return, we were entitled to an annual sales, marketing, and licensing fee. On August 5, 2019, we completed the sale of our 40% equity in Pinewood Atlanta Studios; however, we continued to provide sales and marketing services until October 14, 2020 under a management services agreement and maintained a trademark license with Pinewood Forest (an entity owned by Pinewood Atlanta Studios). Pinewood Atlanta Studios ceased to be a Pinewood-branded studio on December 14, 2020 with the trademark license with Pinewood Forest being terminated at this time. Historically, fees earned under this management service contract were reflected in our Other Activities business line up to the point of termination of the management services agreement and, therefore, impact the financial information presented in this Offering Memorandum. For more information, see Note 3 to the Audited Consolidated Financial Statements of Pinewood Group Limited as of, and for the fiscal years ended, March 31, 2020 and 2021 included elsewhere within this Offering Memorandum. _Pinewood Studios Wales Studio Management Services Agreement_ Pinewood Studios Wales Limited, a private limited company organised under the laws of England and Wales, provided marketing, operational, and management support services to Pinewood Studios Wales pursuant to a studio management services agreement. This agreement was terminated in March 2020, and we are no longer entitled to an annual sales and marketing fee. _Pinewood Iskandar Malaysia Studio Management Services Agreement_ Historically, we had an agreement to provide marketing, operational, and management support services to Pinewood Iskandar Malaysia Studios. We terminated this agreement pursuant to a mutual agreement in July 2019 and, upon termination, we relinquished our negligible equity interest and are no longer entitled to an annual sales, marketing, and licensing fee.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Statement of Comprehensive Income Items
Subsubsection Text: Set forth below is a brief description of the composition of the continuing line items of our income statement. _Turnover_ Turnover is recognised to the extent it is probable that the economic benefits will flow to the Group and the turnover can be reliably measured. Turnover is measured at the fair value of the consideration receivable, net of VAT and other sales taxes or duty. The Group has assessed its turnover arrangements and has concluded that it is acting as a principal in all of its turnover arrangements. Where a contract spans the accounting cut-off date, turnover is recognised as a proportion of the total value of the contract completed by the cut-off date, which is calculated either on the basis of time apportionment or according to the percentage of work completed. Our turnover is derived from our six business lines: (i) Stage and Other Production Accommodation; (ii) Media Hub; (iii) Television Studios; (iv) Ancillary Studio Services; (v) Post Production; and (vi) Other Activities. (i) Stage and Other Production Accommodation: Prior to the commencement of the Long-term Contracts, customers occupied Stage and Other Production Accommodation for a period of time. Turnover was recognised as the Group earned the right to consideration for the service provided, and this was time apportioned and earned as time elapsed. For periods following the commencement of the Long-term Contracts, turnover from Stage and Other Production Accommodation has been largely derived pursuant to the Long-term Contracts payable in advance either quarterly or annually, and includes Stage and Other Production Accommodation, ----- and incorporates some of the former Media Hub space at both Pinewood Studios and Shepperton Studios. (ii) Media Hub: Media Hub turnover comprises rental income from the Group’s properties. Prior to February 2020, Media Hub turnover also included service charge income which covered cleaning, security, energy, and maintenance, which has been phased out with the introduction of higher gross rents. The Media Hub facilities include office space, workshops, archive storage and support premises. Customers contract to utilise the Group’s Media Hub facilities for a set period of time. Turnover is recognised on a straight-line basis over the term of the agreement. Where there are rent-free arrangements within an agreement, the turnover is time apportioned over the term from the commencement date of the agreement to the end of the term. Where an agreement spans an accounting cut-off date, turnover is recognised on a straight-line basis over the agreement term completed by the cut-off date. Turnover generated from Media Hub has declined slightly, as turnover earned from some space originally occupied by Media Hub tenants has been included in the demise to Disney and Netflix under the Long-term Contracts. (iii) Television Studios: Turnover is generated from the provision of the Group’s three fully serviced dedicated Television Studios at Pinewood Studios. The Group renders under contract the dedicated digital Television Studios on a fully serviced basis, including, when requested, contractors, lighting, cameras, technical equipment, dressing rooms, and production offices, all of which are priced into the contract in accordance with the customer needs. Turnover is recognised as the Group earns the right to consideration for the service provided, time apportioned in relation to the television production process. (iv) Ancillary Studio Services: For the periods under review excluding the Long-term Contracts, customers consumed utilities and were recharged the cost of the utility, based on actual consumption, plus a margin. For periods since the commencement of the Long-term Contracts, utilities are charged at cost pursuant to the terms of the Long-term Contracts. In addition, we have revenue share agreements with partners who provide Ancillary Studio Services, where fees are recognised as the services are provided. (v) Post Production: Customers occupy audio mixing and recording theatres for a period of time, and may also be provided with sound mixing or mix technicians within the hire charge. Turnover is recognised as the Group earns the right to consideration for the service provided, which is time apportioned for mixing theatres hired or recognised on a stage of completion basis for work packages involving experienced staff. In August 2019, we announced that the picture services business was being discontinued, and, in March 2020, we announced that the creative audio services business was being discontinued. Accordingly, we experienced a decline in consolidated turnover; however, we did not experience a significant change to the remaining turnover from our localisation business pursuant to the Long-term Contracts. (vi) Other Activities: We earn sales and marketing fees primarily from International Sales and Marketing. Such fees are time apportioned. _Cost of Sales_ Cost of sales consist of direct cost of sales, which can be allocated to our six business lines, and indirect cost of sales, which are costs attributable to the total Media Services segment, but cannot be directly apportioned against individual business lines. Direct cost of sales are comprised of purchase price of utilities, hire of equipment and facilities, and purchase of consumables that, for the periods under review, were all sold at cost plus a margin, staff costs relating to staff directly deployed in activity relating to the turnover lines, and other costs incurred in generating the turnover. Since the commencement of the Long-term Contracts, utilities are charged at cost pursuant to the terms of the Long-term Contracts. Indirect cost of sales are comprised of site maintenance costs, rent for temporary accommodation, and business rates, health and safety, security and cleaning costs, insurance, depreciation relating to equipment and facilities directly deployed in the turnover lines, and depreciation of facilities. ----- _Selling and Distribution Costs_ Selling and distribution costs consist primarily of staff costs related to our sales and marketing team, sales and marketing expenses, trade fairs, and publicity costs. _Administrative Expenses_ Administrative expenses consist primarily of staff costs related to our finance and corporate teams, professional fees, corporate costs, audit fees, information technology costs, human resources and training costs and amortisation of software and goodwill. Administrative expenses also include any changes in the valuation of our investment in Pinewood MBS for the periods to December 31, 2019, when the investment was de-recognised as a financial instrument held at fair value and recognised at cost of nil, with the subsequent charge reflected in administrative expenses/(income) adjusted items. _Income/(Loss) from Participating Interests_ Income from participating interests consists of our share of the results of joint ventures and associates. The Group accounts for participating interests under the equity method of accounting. In August 2019, we completed the sale of our 40% interest in Pinewood Atlanta Studios. For more information, see “—Key Factors Affecting Comparability of Future Results of Operations—Exit from Joint _Ventures and Third-Party Studio Licenses—Pinewood Atlanta Studios Joint Venture and Management Services Agreement.”_ With effect from December 2019, as a result of the step-up in the Group’s investment, we recognise our equity share of the results of PMBS. For discussion of the agreement in relation to our equity holdings in PMBS, see “—Key Factors Affecting Comparability of Future Results of Operations—Exit from Joint Ventures and Third_Party Studio Licenses—_ _Classification of Investment in PMBS Holding Limited.” _Interest Receivable and Similar Income_ Interest receivable and similar income consists of interest receivable from the loan made by the Group to its parent company, Picture Holdco Limited, other interest receivable on other bank accounts, and investments, other loan notes receivable, and fair value gains associated with the Group’s derivative financial instruments. _Interest Payable and Similar Expenses_ Interest payable and similar expenses consists of payments under our borrowing arrangements, including our interest rate swap agreements, together with fair value losses associated with the Group’s derivative financial instruments. _Tax Charge_ Tax charge consists of the sum of current tax (comprising UK corporation tax charge, amounts payable for Group tax loss relief, foreign corporation tax, foreign tax suffered, double taxation credit, and amounts (under)/overprovided in previous years), UK Film Tax Relief and deferred tax (comprising tax recognised in respect of timing differences between the recognition of trading results within the tax assessments and their recognition in the statement of comprehensive income, the reversal of tax recognised when the timing differences unwind, effect of change in deferred tax rates, and amounts over/(under) provided in previous years). _Other Comprehensive Income/(Loss)_ Other comprehensive income consists of exchange differences on translation of operations whose functional currency is not pound sterling into pound sterling as a presentational currency.

(94) 111 (218.1) Total comprehensive income for the period ............................................................** **16,096** **15,206** (5.5) _Turnover_ Turnover for the six months ended September 30, 2021 was £49.5 million compared to £46.7 million in the six months ended September 30, 2020, an increase of £2.8 million, or 6.1%, which we primarily attribute to increased activity in our TV studios and Post Production businesses, as well as our Ancillary Studio Services, which have all returned to normal pre-COVID-19 pandemic levels, partially offset by a fall in studio resale income and revenues from International Sales and Marketing following the cessation of the sales and marketing services we provided in connection with Pinewood Atlanta Studios which occurred on October 14, 2020. _Cost of Sales_ Cost of sales in the six months ended September 30, 2021 were £18.7 million compared to £17.6 million in the six months ended September 30, 2020, an increase of £1.1 million, or 6.6%. We attribute this primarily to activity levels returning to normal, pre COVID-19 pandemic levels (with increased TV and energy costs supporting the increase in revenue) and a slight increase in maintenance costs incurred in connection with maintenance of our facilities. _Selling and Distribution Costs & Administrative Expenses_ Selling and distribution costs and administrative expenses in the six months ended September 30, 2021 were £4.2 million compared to £4.0 million in the six months ended September 30, 2020, an increase of £0.2 million, or 4.8%, which we attribute primarily to staff costs associated with our studio expansion plans and higher amortisation of software, partially offset by a decrease in costs due to running fewer events or postponing events until a later period and a decrease in staff headcount in other teams that occurred during the fiscal year ended March 31, 2021. _Other Operating Expenses_ Other operating expenses in the six months ended September 30, 2021 were £0.5 million compared to £1.2 million in the six months ended September 30, 2020, a decrease of £0.7 million or 58.3%, which we primarily attribute to the loss on disposal of property, plant and equipment net of funds granted by the UK government under their Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme in the six months ended September 30, 2020, whereas in the six months ended September 30, 2021 we voluntarily returned a net £0.5 million of the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme grants received throughout the prior financial year in relation to our retained staff. ----- _Gain on Loan to Participating Interests_ Gain on loan to participating interests in the six months ended September 30, 2021 was nil compared to £2.0 million for the six months ended September 30, 2020, a decrease of £2.0 million or 100%. This decrease is due to the fact that the PMBS loan notes, which were recognised on our balance sheet in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2021 at fair value, estimated to be the face value, resulting in a corresponding gain in our income statement of £2.0 million, remains unchanged for the six months ended September 30, 2021. _Income from Participating Interests_ Income from participating interests in the six months ended September 30, 2021 was £1.0 million compared to income from participating interests in the six months ended September 30, 2020 of nil, an increase of £1.0 million or 100%, which we attribute primarily to our associate company, PMBS, benefitting from activity levels across the film and HETV production industry returning to normal, pre-COVID-19 pandemic levels. For discussion of the agreement in relation to our equity holdings in PMBS, see “—Key Factors Affecting _Comparability of Future Results of Operations—Exit from Joint Ventures and Third-Party Studio Licenses— Classification of Investment in PMBS Holding Limited.” Interest Receivable and Similar Income_ Interest receivable and similar income in the six months ended September 30, 2021 was £6.1 million compared to £5.8 million in the six months ended September 30, 2020, an increase of £0.3 million or 5.1%. We attribute this slight improvement to the fair value gain on the Group’s derivative financial instruments and the receipt of other interest income. _Interest Payable and Similar Charges_ Interest payable and similar charges in the six months ended September 30, 2021 were £12.7 million compared to £10.4 million in the six months ended September 30, 2020, an increase of £2.3 million, or 22.3%, which we attribute primarily to an increase in principal by £200.0 million our senior secured notes following the 2025 Notes Tap Issuance in January 2021. _Tax on Profit_ Tax on profit in the six months ended September 30, 2021 was £5.3 million compared to £5.1 million in the six months ended September 30, 2020, an increase of £0.2 million, or 5.0%, which we attribute primarily to an increase in the main rate of UK corporation tax, from 19% to 25%, from 1 April 2023, which has been incorporated into our deferred tax position, partially offset by the six months ended September 30, 2020 including a tax charge of £0.5 million in relation to the gain on loan to participating interests and a small adjustment to the tax estimated on the sale of the group’s equity interest in Pinewood Atlanta Studios. _Other Comprehensive Income/(Loss)_ Other comprehensive income in the six months ended September 30, 2021 was £0.1 million compared to a loss of £0.1 million in the six months ended September 30, 2020, a decrease of £0.2 million, comprised of exchange differences on translation of foreign operations into pound sterling as a presentational currency.
