Subsubsection Title: Fiscal Year Ended March 31, 2020 Compared with Fiscal Year Ended March 31, 2019
Subsubsection Text: The table below sets forth certain Group statements of comprehensive income data for the fiscal years ended March 31, 2019 and 2020.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: _Turnover_ Turnover in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2021 was £96.9 million compared to £96.4 million in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2020, an increase of £0.5 million, or 0.5%, which we attribute primarily to an increase in the performance of our UK studios, which were able to accommodate more customers at our Pinewood East Phase 2 location which was completed in autumn 2019, our Long-term Contracts which increased occupancy levels, and strong resales of production accommodation. This was partially offset by a decrease in revenues primarily due to the cessation of picture services and creative audio services, exiting our agreements with studios in Malaysia, Wales, and Atlanta, and a decrease in turnover in Post Production, Television Studios and Ancillary Studio Services as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic. Additionally, the Long-term Contracts contain indexation provisions, which, in accordance with FRS102, result in certain revenue over the initial term being recognised on a straight-line basis, rather than increasing each year. As a consequence, revenue for the fiscal year ended March 31, 2021 is adjusted upwards by £3.0 million and £1.4 million for the fiscal year ended March 30, 2020, compared with the contractual amounts due in the respective year. _Cost of Sales_ Cost of sales in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2021 were £36.4 million compared to £40.4 million in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2020, a decrease of £4.0 million, or 9.7%, which we attribute primarily to savings in our Post Production business line as picture services and creative audio operations closed, a lower level of maintenance expense at our studios as a result of a production hiatus during the first quarter of 2021 as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic, and moderate cost control measures we implemented throughout the year in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. _Selling and Distribution Costs_ Selling and distribution costs in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2021 were £0.9 million compared to £1.6 million for the fiscal year ended March 31, 2020, a decrease of £0.7 million or 44.2%. We attribute this decrease primarily to a decrease in expenditures on international events and travel as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic and streamlined business processes. _Administrative Expenses_ Administrative expenses in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2021 were £7.0 million compared to £8.2 million in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2020, a decrease of £1.2 million, or 14.1%, which we attribute primarily to a £1.9 million improvement in administrative expenses/(income) adjusted items, partially offset by a small investment in the teams delivering our studio expansion programmes and the commencement of amortisation of our new IT platform. Administrative expenses/(income) adjusted items in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2021 were a £0.5 million gain compared to a £1.4 million net charge in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2020, an improvement by £1.9 million. Following the termination of the sales and marketing services we provided in connection with Pinewood Atlanta Studios on October 14, 2020, £0.5 million of unamortised deferred trademark royalties in connection with Pinewood Forest, originally recognised on balance sheet in 2016, were released to the income statement. In the fiscal year ended March 31, 2020, we charged £1.7 million to our income statement due to the derecognition of our 15% equity holding in Pinewood MBS which had been carried as a financial instrument at ----- fair value until December 31, 2019 and £0.4 million of restructuring expenditures was incurred, partially offset by a £0.7 million receipt of monies in relation to the early termination of our Pinewood Iskandar Malaysia Studios agreement. For more information on adjustments to administrative expenses, see “Presentation of Financial _Information—_ _Other Financial Information (Non-UK GAAP).” Other Operating Expenses_ Other operating expenses in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2021 were £2.4 million compared to £0.6 million in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2020, an increase of £1.8 million, which we attribute primarily to a loss on disposal of property at Pinewood Studios following the clearance of three areas in advance of the construction of five new stages, to be occupied by Disney in accordance with the Disney Long-term Contract and advisory fees in relation to a minor acquisition which, subsequently, was not pursued. This was partially offset by the £0.7 million of receipts under the Government’s Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme during the year ended March 31, 2021, but subsequently largely returned during the six months ended September 30, 2021 after the group’s positive financial performance. The prior year reflected adjusted items totalling £0.6 million in respect of a £0.8 million impairment of Post Production fixed assets following the closure of picture services and creative audio services, a £2.8 million receipt from the sale of our investment in POP Global Ltd, which had previously been fully impaired, and a oneoff stamp duty land tax payment of £2.6 million. Since the acquisition of Shepperton from the joint venture partners in December 2014, a complex corporate structure had been in place around the subsidiary ownership of the studio. The structure was simplified in advance of the commencement of the Netflix Long-term Contract, thereby reducing future costs. _Loss on Disposal of Participating Interests_ Loss on disposal of participating interests in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2021 was nil compared to £1.8 million in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2020, a decrease of £1.8 million, which we attribute to the sale of our 40% equity investment in Pinewood Atlanta Studios that completed in August 2019. The £1.8 million loss on disposal of the equity investment in Pinewood Atlanta Studios included proceeds, net of costs, totalling £12.6 million. For more information, see “—Key Factors Affecting Comparability of Future Results of Operations— _Exit from Joint Ventures and_ _Third-Party Studio Licenses—Pinewood Atlanta Studios Joint Venture and Management Services Agreement” and Note 3 to the Audited Consolidated Financial Statements of Pinewood_ Group Limited as of and for the fiscal years ended March 31, 2020 and 2021, included elsewhere within this Offering Memorandum. _Gain on loan to participating interests_ Gains on loans to participating interests in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2021 were £2.0 million compared to nil in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2020, an increase of £2.0 million, which we attribute to the step-up associated with the Group’s investment in PMBS, which was completed for nil consideration. The step-up resulted in the Group’s equity interest in PMBS increasing from 15% to 25%. In addition, PMBS issued additional loan notes to the Group. The impact of the additional loan notes was recognised on our balance sheet at fair value, estimated to be the face value, resulting in a corresponding gain in our income statement of £2.0 million. _Income from Participating Interests_ Income from participating interests in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2021 was nil compared to £0.1 million in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2020, a decrease which we attribute to the sale of the Group’s equity investment in Pinewood Atlanta Studios, completing in August 2019. For more information on Pinewood Atlanta Studios, see “Business—Our Business Lines—Other Activities—International Sales and Marketing.” _Interest Receivable and Similar Income_ Interest receivable and similar income in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2021 was £11.5 million compared to £8.6 million in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2020, an increase of £2.9 million, or 33.8%, which we attribute to interest earned on the loan to Picture Holdco Limited, our parent company, which was originally created in December 2017, and which increased by £175.0 million following our 2019 Refinancing Transaction which closed on September 25, 2019. We also benefitted from higher interest income on the additional £2.0 million of loan notes from PMBS. ----- _Interest Payable and Similar Charges_ Interest payable and similar charges in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2021 were £20.6 million compared to £28.1 million in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2020, a decrease of £7.5 million, or 26.8%, which we attribute primarily to the non-repeat of £11.8 million of interest payable adjusted items in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2020 in connection with the 2019 Refinancing Transaction which closed on September 25, 2019, a smaller charge in relation to the value of our “out-of-the-money” derivative financial instruments (interest rate swaps used to hedge against risks associated with interest rate fluctuation), partially offset by an increase in interest payable on our senior secured notes in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2021 following the 2019 Refinancing Transaction and 2025 Tap Notes Issuance. _Tax Charge_ Tax charged in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2021 was £9.3 million compared to £5.9 million in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2020, an increase of £3.4 million, or 56.2%. Tax charged on profit before tax was higher in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2021 due in part to higher profit before tax, and because costs in relation to certain advisory fees and losses on disposal of assets were disallowed for tax purposes, while the year ended March 31, 2020 benefitted from a change in legislation in the USA to allow losses generated in 2018 to be carried back against earlier profitable periods. Tax charged on adjusted items was £2.3 million higher as adjusted items before tax totalled a £2.6 million profit in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2021 compared to a loss of £15.7 million in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2020 See “—Factors Affecting Comparability—Adjusted Items,” with certain corporate and financial restructuring commencing during in the year ended March 31, 2020 and completing in the year ended March 31, 2021. _Other Comprehensive Income/(Loss)_ Other comprehensive income in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2021 was a loss of £0.5 million compared to a £0.5 million gain in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2020, an increased loss of £1.0 million, comprised of exchange differences on translation of foreign operations into pound sterling as a presentational currency. -----

Subsubsection Text: _Turnover_ Turnover in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2020 was £96.4 million compared to £85.9 million in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2019, an increase of £10.5 million, or 12.2%, which we attribute primarily to higher demand and occupancy levels in production accommodation throughout the year, the commencement of our Longterm Contracts in the second half of the fiscal year ended March 31, 2020, Pinewood East Phase 2 coming online in autumn 2019, and an increase in scheduling of productions at our three dedicated TV studios. This was partially offset by lower revenues in Post Production due to the cessation of picture services and creative audio services, and lower revenues from the management arrangements with Pinewood Iskandar Malaysia Studios and the Studios in Wales. Additionally, the Long-term Contracts contain indexation provisions, which, in accordance with FRS102, result in certain revenue over the initial term being recognised on a straight-line basis, rather than increasing each year. As a consequence, revenue for the fiscal year ended March 31, 2020 is adjusted upwards by £1.4 million compared with the contractual amounts due for that year. _Cost of Sales_ Cost of sales in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2020 were £40.4 million compared to £41.0 million in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2019, a decrease of £0.6 million, or 1.4%, which we attribute primarily to savings in our Post Production business line, as contracted picture services and creative audio work was completed and the operations closed, a non-recurrence of a £0.9 million prior year loss on the demolition and disposal of certain assets affected by the real estate optimisation programme, partially offset by higher depreciation, business rates, and facilities costs following the opening of Pinewood East Phase 2 in autumn 2019, together with the return of energy costs to typical levels following an energy refund in the prior year. _Selling and Distribution Costs_ Selling and distribution costs in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2020 were £1.6 million compared to £1.7 million in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2019, a decrease of £0.1 million, or 8.3%. _Administrative Expenses_ Administrative expenses in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2020 were £8.2 million compared to £8.3 million in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2019, a decrease of £0.1 million, or 0.8%, which we attribute 79 ----- primarily to a £0.6 million, or 64.3%, increase in adjusted items from a charge of £0.9 million in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2019 to a charge of £1.4 million in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2020. The £1.4 million net charge in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2020 increased from the £0.9 million charge in the prior year due to a £1.7 million charge from the derecognition of our 15% equity holding in Pinewood MBS which had been carried as a financial instrument at fair value until December 31, 2019, partially offset by lower restructuring costs in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2020 and a £0.7 million receipt of monies in relation to the early termination of the management contract with Pinewood Iskandar Malaysia Studios. _Other Operating Expenses_ Other operating expenses in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2020 were £0.6 million compared to nil in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2019, an increase of £0.6 million, which we attribute primarily to adjusted items in respect of a £0.8 million impairment of post-production fixed assets following the closure of picture services and creative audio services, a £2.8 million receipt from the sale of our investment in POP Global Ltd, which had previously been fully impaired, and a one-off stamp duty land tax payment of £2.6 million. Since the acquisition of Shepperton from the joint venture partners in December 2014, a complex corporate structure had been in place around the subsidiary ownership of the studio. The structure was simplified in advance of the commencement of the Netflix Long-term Contract, thereby reducing future costs. _Loss on Disposal of Participating Interests_ Loss on disposal of participating interests in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2020 was £1.8 million compared to a loss on disposal of participating interests in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2019 of nil, an increase of £1.8 million, which we attribute primarily to the sale of our 40% interest in Pinewood Atlanta Studios, which is recognised net of a performance related earnout income of £0.5 million, which was received in the fourth quarter of the fiscal year ended March 31, 2020. For more information, see “—Key Factors Affecting Comparability of _Future Results of Operations—Exit from Joint Ventures and Third-Party Studio Licenses—Pinewood Atlanta Studios Joint Venture and Management Services Agreement” and Note 3 to the Audited Consolidated Financial_ Statements of Pinewood Group Limited as of and for the fiscal years ended March 31, 2020, included elsewhere within this Offering Memorandum. _Income from Participating Interests_ Income from participating interests in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2020 was £0.1 million compared to a loss of £1.4 million in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2019, an increase of £1.5 million, which we attribute primarily to improved occupancy at Pinewood Atlanta Studios from the start of the fiscal year ended March 31, 2020 through to the sale of our 40% interest in the joint venture, which completed in August 2019. For more information, see “—Key Factors Affecting Comparability of Future Results of Operations—Exit from Joint _Ventures and Third-Party Studio Licenses—Pinewood Atlanta Studios Joint Venture and Management Services Agreement”. Interest Receivable and Similar Income_ Interest receivable and similar income in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2020 was £8.6 million compared to £5.7 million in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2019, an increase of £2.9 million, or 51.0%, which we attribute to interest earned on the loan to the Group’s parent company, which was originally created in December 2017, and increased by £175.0 million following the Group’s refinancing on September 25, 2019. _Interest Payable and Similar Charges_ Interest payable and similar charges in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2020 were £28.1 million compared to £11.9 million in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2019, an increase of £16.2 million, or 136.9%, which we primarily attribute to the fiscal year ended March 31, 2020 reflecting a charge of £11.8 million in connection with the extinguishment of the prior loan notes and facilities at the time of the Group’s refinancing on September 25, 2019, and higher interest payable following the increase in the principal amount of senior secured notes. _Tax Charge_ Tax charge in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2020 was a charge of £5.9 million compared to a charge of £6.1 million in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2019, a decrease of £0.2 million, or 2.0%, which we attribute ----- primarily to a £0.6 million lower tax charge at the standard rate of corporation tax on profit before tax and lower unrelieved tax losses of £0.5 million, offset by £0.9 million increase in tax on gain on disposal of joint venture. _Other Comprehensive Income/(Loss)_ Other comprehensive income in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2020 was £0.5 million compared to £0.8 million in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2019, a decrease of £0.3 million, or 33.3%, comprised of exchange differences on translation of foreign operations into pound sterling as a presentational currency.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Liquidity describes the ability of a company to generate sufficient cash flows to meet the cash requirements of its business operations, including working capital needs, capital expenditures, debt service obligations, other commitments, contractual obligations, and acquisitions. Liquidity risk is the risk that we would be unable to meet our current and future financial obligations as they fall due, or can do so only at excessive cost. Following the completion of this Offering and the application of the use of proceeds therefrom to fund the Shepperton Expansion Project and the five new stages at Pinewood West, our primary sources of liquidity will be our cash from operating activities and the Revolving Credit Facility. Our liquidity requirements arise primarily to service debt in connection with our Existing Notes that will remain outstanding, the Notes offered hereby and to fund ongoing capital expenditures and to meet our operating costs. As of September 30, 2021, we had cash and cash equivalent balances of £248.5 million. A portion of the cash and cash equivalent balances as of September 30, 2021 will be deployed, along with the net proceeds of the Notes offered hereby, to fund the Shepperton Expansion Project and five new stages at Pinewood West as further discussed under “Use of Proceeds.”

Subsubsection Text: Net cash flow from (used in) operating activities ...................... 39,561 44,279 32,339 (1,904) (13,144) Net cash flow used in investing activities .................................. (613) 218,335 204,598 — (147) _Net Cash Flow from Operating Activities_ Our net cash flow used in operating activities increased by £11.2 million, from £1.9 million in the six months ended September 30, 2020 to £13.1 million in the six months ended September 30, 2021. The increase was attributable to a higher reduction in working capital of £8.1 million compared the prior period, driven by: (i) a higher unwind of deferred income balances as more cash was paid in advance of the six months ended September 30, 2021 than in advance of the six months ended September 30, 2020; (ii) a natural delay in the timing of VAT reclaims relating to capital expenditure as our studio expansion plans progress; and (iii) partially offset by a reduced level of resale-related payments during this period. Our net cash flow from operating activities decreased by £12.0 million, or 27.0%, from £44.3 million in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2020 to £32.3 million in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2021. The decrease was attributable to a variety of factors, including: (i) a £7.6 million improvement in operating cash flows before movements in working capital to £63.2 million due to improved trading results (but excluding the non-cash impacts relating to depreciation and amortisation, the loss on disposal of fixed assets in relation to the clearance of three areas of the Pinewood site in advance of the development of our five new stages, the impact of the fair value gain and losses on the PMBS investment, a gain on the sale of our investment in POP Global Ltd, and a loss on the disposal of our share of the Pinewood Atlanta studios for the fiscal year end March 31, 2020); (ii) a £20.4 million reduced benefit from working capital due a higher unwind of deferred income balances as, due to the commencement of the Long-term Contracts, more cash was paid in advance of the fiscal year ended March 31, 2021 than in advance of the fiscal year ended March 31, 2020, higher resale cash settlements, a higher level of payments in respect of VAT, and the recognition of profit, which had been previously deferred, following the termination of our management service contract with Pinewood Atlanta Studios; (iii) a decreased interest payment of £1.2 million as a result of the 2019 Refinancing Transaction and 2025 Tap Notes Issuance. In the fiscal year ended March 31, 2020, as a result of the 2019 Refinancing Transaction we made a make-whole payment of £5.9 million plus 15 months of interest payments for the senior secured notes that we redeemed. In the fiscal year ----- ended March 31, 2021, interest payments on our 2025 Notes increased due to an increase in principal following the 2025 Notes Tap Issuance in January 2021; and (iv) an increase of £0.4 million in our payment of net taxes with a higher level of disallowed costs in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2021, and payments in connection with transitioning to HMRC’s new schedule of payments in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2020, partially offset by lower net income tax payments in relation to both a tax refunds in the US and a film production company which is now inactive. Our net cash flow from operating activities increased £4.7 million, or 11.9%, from £39.6 million in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2019 to £44.3 million in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2020. We attribute this increase primarily to improved cash flows before movements in working capital of £10.4 million, mainly due to the trading results described previously, an £11.0 million net improvement in working capital with both Longterm Contracts being paid in advance, which was offset by unwindings of working capital on amounts which had been paid in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2019 in respect of the fiscal year ended March 31, 2020, offset by a £14.0 million increase in net interest paid due to the refinancing of the senior secured notes on September 25, 2019, and higher tax paid of £2.7 million following the start of the revised HMRC payment schedule for UK companies, which resulted in additional scheduled payments during the fiscal year ended March 31, 2020 which was the transition period year. _Net Cash Flow Used in Investing Activities_ Our net cash flow used in investing activities increased £22.9 million, or 175.7%, from £13.0 million in the six months ended September 30, 2020 to £35.9 million in the six months ended September 30, 2021. We attribute this increase primarily to increased expenditure related to the continued development of the five stages at Pinewood West, enabling works at Shepperton North West, and the design and enabling works in connection with expansion at Shepperton South. Our net cash flow used in investing activities declined by £177.6 million, or 84.9%, from £209.3 million in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2020 to £31.7 million in the fiscal year ended March 30, 2021. Net cash flows used in investing activities for the fiscal year ended March 31, 2020 were higher than in fiscal year ended March 30, 2021 primarily due to capital expenditures related to the development of Pinewood East Phase 2, which resulted in the Company lending £175.0 million of cash from the 2019 Refinancing Transaction to our Parent, partially offset by the receipt of £12.6 million from the sale of equity in Pinewood Atlanta Studios and £2.8 million from the sale of equity in POP Global Ltd. In addition, the fiscal year ended March 31, 2021 included increased expenditure related to the development of five new stages at Pinewood West and the acquisition of land to the south of Pinewood. Our net cash flow used in investing activities increased £167.2 million, or 397.1%, from £42.1 million in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2019 to £209.3 million in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2020. We attribute this primarily to a £175.0 million increase in the loan to the Group’s parent company as a part of the refinancing on September 25, 2019, a £10.5 million net increase in amounts spent in relation to property plant and equipment and intangible assets mainly from the continued development of Pinewood East Phase 2, partially offset by a receipt of £12.6 million for the sale of our share in Pinewood Atlanta Studios, which had resulted in losses due to low occupancy in the previous year and £2.8 million from the sale of the investment in POP Global Ltd, and the non-repeat of a £2.9 million investment into Pinewood Atlanta Studios in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2019. _Net Cash Flow from/(Used in) Financing Activities_ In the six months ended September 30, 2021, our net cash flow used in financing activities was £0.1 compared to nil in the six months ended September 30, 2020, an increase of £0.1 million, which we attribute primarily to payment of residual financing arrangement fees during this period. Our net cash flow from financing activities decreased £13.7 million, or 6.3%, from £218.3 million in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2020 to £204.6 million in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2021. The fiscal year ended March 31, 2021 reflects the net receipts of funds, after arrangement fees, from the 2025 Notes Tap Issuance. The fiscal year ended March 31, 2020 primarily reflected cash movements from the 2019 Refinancing Transaction, with a net increase of £300.0 million senior secured notes, of which we paid £75.0 million as a dividend to the Parent and £6.5 million in arrangement fees. Our net cash flow from financing activities increased £218.9 million from £0.6 million of net cash flow used in financing activities in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2019 to £218.3 million of net cash flow from financing activities in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2020. We attribute the increase primarily to the refinancing ----- on September 25, 2019, and the net receipt of £300.0 million from the net increase in senior secured notes, of which we paid £75.0 million as a dividend to the Parent and £6.5 million in arrangement fees.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: For the six months ended September 30, 2021, total capital expenditure amounted to £35.9 million, which primarily consisted of costs incurred in relation to our studio expansion plans, developing the five new stages at Pinewood West and undertaking enabling works at Shepperton North West. For the six months ended September 30, 2020, capital expenditure additions was £13.0 million, which primarily consisted of costs incurred in relation to the acquisition of land at Pinewood South, the commencement of development of the five new stages at Pinewood West, and the progression of planning applications at both UK studios which were early or preparatory steps related to the execution of various expansion projects. For the fiscal year ended March 31, 2021, total capital expenditure amounted to £31.7 million, which primarily consisted of expenditures in relation to our growth projects (including the acquisition of land and the development of five new stages at Pinewood) and other lifecycle capital expenditure. For the fiscal year ended March 31, 2020, total capital expenditure amounted to £34.3 million, which primarily consisted of investments related to the continued development of Pinewood East Phase 2, net of cash received from the sale of our investments in Pinewood Atlanta studios and POP Global Ltd. For the fiscal year ended March 31, 2019, total capital expenditure amounted to £42.1 million, which primarily consisted of investments related to the development of Pinewood East Phase 2, the purchase of Alderbourne Farm adjacent to Pinewood Studios and real estate optimisation activity. For information on our capital expenditures related to the Shepperton Expansion Project and the five stages at Pinewood West, see “Use of Proceeds.” -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: We manage our exposure to liquidity risk at the level of the Company. Our objective is to maintain a balance between the continuity of operating and development funding and flexibility through the use of the Revolving Credit Facility.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: Interest rate risk is the risk that the fair value or future values of a financial instrument will fluctuate because of changes in market interest rates. Our exposure to the risk of changes in market interest rates relates primarily to floating interest rates with respect to the Revolving Credit Facility, and the interest rate swaps. Given that the Group’s debt is predominately subject to fixed rates, we believe there is limited risk to the results from interest rate volatility.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: Credit risk is the risk that a counter-party will not meet its obligation under a financial instrument or customer contract, leading to a financial loss. We are exposed to credit risk from our operating activities, primarily with respect to trade receivables and financial instruments. Since the commencement of the Long-term Contracts, 100% of our Stage and Other Production Accommodation at our Pinewood Studios and Shepperton Studios sites in the United Kingdom is subject to Long-term Contracts with Disney and Netflix, respectively. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business— _We rely on the Disney Long-term Contract and the Netflix Long-term Contract for a significant portion of our turnover. The termination, non-renewal or default under or both of these Long-term Contracts could reduce our future turnover.” In 2021, we entered into a long-term contract with Netflix to pre-let approximately 0.5 million_ square feet of space, equivalent to 60% of the space being developed, at our Shepperton South studio. The lease will commence on completion of the development, expected towards the end of 2023, and is on terms similar to the Netflix Long-term Contract. There is strong interest from several customers for the remaining approximately 0.5 million square feet being developed at Shepperton. See “Business—Material Contracts.” Customer credit risk is managed across our Group in accordance with policy, procedures, and controls relating to customer credit risk management. We trade with recognised, creditworthy third parties, and it is our policy that all customers who wish to trade on credit terms are subject to credit verification procedures. In addition, receivable balances are monitored on an ongoing basis to manage our exposure to bad debts. -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: We do not hedge against foreign currency exposure due to our minimal exposure to foreign currency movements, as our business is conducted primarily in pound sterling.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: Market risk is the potential loss arising from adverse changes in market rates, and comprises risks relating to liquidity, interest rates, credit, and foreign exchange rates.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Turnover is recognised to the extent it is probable that the economic benefits will flow to the Group and the turnover can be reliably measured. Turnover is measured at the fair value of the consideration receivable, net of discounts, rebates, VAT, and other sales taxes or duty. The Group has assessed its turnover arrangements and has concluded that it is acting as a principal in all of its turnover arrangements. Where a contract spans an accounting cut-off date, the value of the turnover recognised is the proportion of the total value of the contract completed by the cut-off date. The following specific recognition criteria apply for turnover generated from the Group’s single reportable segment: - Film customers utilise services for a period of time. Turnover is recognised as the Group earns the right to consideration for the service provided and this is time apportioned and earned as time elapses. - Film turnover is also derived from international sales and marketing agreements, and certain consultancy agreements. Revenue is recognised based on the passage of time for the former and on a stage of completion basis by reference to costs incurred for the latter. - Television turnover is derived from the provision of services and is recognised on a time apportioned basis in relation to the television production process. - Media Hub turnover is derived from customers contracting to use the Group’s facilities for a period of time. Turnover is recognised on a straight-line basis over the term of the agreement. - Post Production revenue is derived from the provision of services and is recognised as the Group earns the right to consideration on a stage of completion basis by reference to the passage of time.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Intangible software assets are capitalised at cost and subsequently amortised over their useful economic life of 5 to 10 years.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Goodwill on acquisition is initially measured at cost, being the excess of the cost of the purchase consideration over the fair value of the identifiable assets, liabilities, and contingent liabilities acquired. Following initial recognition, goodwill is measured at cost less any amortisation or accumulated impairment loss. Goodwill is expected to have a useful life of 10 years and is amortised on a straight-line basis over that period. Goodwill is reviewed for impairment annually, or more frequently if events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying value may be impaired. For the purpose of impairment testing, goodwill is allocated to the related cashgenerating unit monitored by management. Where the recoverable amount of the cash-generating unit is less than the carrying amount, including goodwill, an impairment loss is recognised in our income statement.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Property, plant, and equipment are stated at cost to the Group less accumulated depreciation and any impairment loss. Cost comprises the aggregate amount paid and the fair value of any other consideration given to acquire the asset, and includes costs directly attributable to making the asset capable of operating as intended. Depreciation is calculated on all property, plant, and equipment, other than land, from the time they are available for use on a straight-line basis over the estimated useful life as follows: - Freehold buildings: 30 to 50 years - Freehold improvements: 5 to 25 years - Fixtures, fittings and equipment: 3 to 10 years ----- Land and assets under construction are not depreciated. The carrying value of freehold land and buildings within “Property, plant and equipment” in the statement of financial position is based on external valuations undertaken by an independent firm of Chartered Surveyors in February 2000 (as amended in January 2001) and November 2000, on each occasion, to establish the fair values of the Pinewood Studios and Shepperton Studios businesses acquired. Subsequent to these valuations, the cost to the Group of freehold land and buildings, additions, disposals, and depreciation have been recorded in line with Group accounting policies. The carrying value of property, plant, and equipment is reviewed for impairment if events or changes in circumstances indicate the carrying value may not be recoverable, and is written-down immediately to the recoverable amount. Useful lives and residual values are reviewed annually and, where adjustments are required, these are made prospectively. An item of property, plant, and equipment is derecognised upon disposal. Any gain or loss arising on de-recognition of the asset (calculated as the difference between the net disposal proceeds and the carrying amount of the item) is included in our income statement in the year the item is de-recognised.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Interests in Associates and Joint Ventures
Subsubsection Text: Associates are undertakings where the Group is considered to have the ability to exercise significant influence over the operating and financial decisions of the undertaking. Joint ventures arise when two or more parties have joint control of the rights and net assets of the undertaking. The Group accounts for associates and joint ventures under the equity method of accounting. Under the equity method of accounting, the investment is recognised initially in the Group statement of financial position at cost, and adjusted thereafter to recognise the Group’s share of income and other comprehensive income of the participating interest. Should the Group’s share of losses of the associate or joint venture exceed the Group’s interest in that undertaking, the Group discontinues recognising its share of further losses. Additional losses are recognised only to the extent the Group has incurred legal or constructive obligations, or has made payments on behalf of the associate or joint venture.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Transactions in foreign currencies are recorded at the rate of exchange at the date of the transaction. Monetary assets and liabilities denominated in foreign currencies at the balance sheet date are reported at the rates of exchange prevailing at that date. The results of overseas operations are translated at the average rates of exchange during the relevant period. Non-monetary assets and liabilities are translated based on historical rates in accordance with FRS 102, and other balance sheet information is translated using the prevailing foreign exchange rates as of the relevant balance sheet date. Exchange differences arising on the translation of opening net assets and results of overseas operations are reported in other comprehensive income and accumulated in equity. In the consolidated financial statements exchange differences arising on monetary items receivable from or payable to a foreign operation for which settlement is neither planned nor likely to occur (therefore, forming part of the net investment in the foreign operation), are recognised in other comprehensive income and reported under equity. All other exchange differences are recognised in profit or loss in the period in which they arise.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: All financial assets and liabilities are measured initially at the transaction price (including transaction costs), except for those financial assets classified as at fair value through profit or loss, which are measured initially at fair value (which is normally the transaction price excluding transaction costs), unless the arrangement constitutes a financing transaction. If an arrangement constitutes a financing transaction, the financial asset or financial liability is measured at the present value of the future payments discounted at a market rate of interest for a similar debt instrument. Financial assets are de-recognised when and only when: (a) the contractual rights to the cash flows from the financial asset expire or are settled; (b) the Group transfers to another party substantially all of the risks and ----- rewards of ownership of the financial asset; or (c) the Group, despite having retained some significant risks and rewards of ownership, has transferred control of the asset to another party and the other party has the practical ability to sell the asset in its entirety to an unrelated third party, and is able to exercise that ability unilaterally and without needing to impose additional restrictions on the transfer. Financial liabilities are de-recognised only when the obligation specified in the contract is discharged, cancelled, or expires.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The best evidence of fair value is a quoted price for an identical asset in an active market. When quoted prices are unavailable, the price of a recent transaction for an identical asset provides evidence of fair value as long as there has not been a significant change in economic circumstances or a significant lapse of time since the transaction took place. If the market is not active and recent transactions of an identical asset on their own are not a good estimate of fair value, we estimate the fair value using a valuation technique.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Obligations for loans and borrowings are recognised when the Group becomes party to the related contracts, and are measured initially at the fair values of consideration received less directly attributable transaction costs. After initial recognition, interest-bearing loans and borrowings are subsequently measured at amortised cost using the effective interest rate method, allocating the interest income or interest expense over the relevant period.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: _The Group as Lessee_ An asset and corresponding liability are recognised for leasing agreements that transfer to the Company substantially all of the risks and rewards incidental to ownership (“finance leases”). The amount capitalised is the fair value of the leased asset or, if lower, the present value of the minimum lease payments payable during the lease term, both determined at inception of the lease. Lease payments are treated as consisting of capital and interest elements. The interest is charged to profit or loss so as to produce a constant periodic rate of interest on the remaining balance of the liability. Capitalised leased assets are depreciated over the shorter of the estimated useful life of the asset or the lease term. All other leases are operating leases and the annual rent is charged to profit or loss on a straight-line basis over the lease term. Rent-free periods or other incentives received for entering into an operating lease are accounted for as a reduction to the expense and are recognised on a straight-line basis over the lease term. _The Group as Lessor_ Rental income from assets leased under operating leases is recognised on a straight-line basis over the term of the lease and recognised as turnover. Rent-free periods or other incentives given to the lessee are accounted for as a reduction to the rental income and recognised on a straight-line basis over the term. Initial direct costs associated with arranging the operating lease are included in the carrying amount of the underlying leased asset, and recognised in the statement of comprehensive income on a straight-line basis over the initial term of the leases. _Government grants_ Government grants are accounted for under the accruals model. A grant that becomes receivable as compensation for expenses or losses already incurred or for the purpose of giving immediate financial support to the entity with no future related costs is recognised in income in the period in which it becomes receivable. This includes the Government Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: _Identification of Adjusted Items_ The Group presents its results in the statement of comprehensive income to separately identify the impact of certain items (“adjusted items”) in order to provide a clear and consistent presentation of the underlying operating performance of the Group. Adjusted items are transactions that are unusual in size or nature, or have ----- limited predictive value such as disposals, discontinued operations, impairments, certain fair value remeasurements, and other significant items. The identification and presentation of transactions as adjusted items requires judgement. _Recoverability of Trade and Other Receivables_ The recoverability of financial assets, including trade and other receivables, requires judgement. The Group regularly reviews financial assets for evidence of impairment. _Classification of Investment in PMBS Holding Limited_ In 2015, the Group entered into an agreement to acquire a 15% equity interest in PMBS and its wholly owned subsidiary Pinewood MBS Lighting Limited, a company that was subsequently granted an arrangement to provide lighting services at the Group's UK facilities. The agreement included an option to step up the Group’s equity interest in PMBS to 25% after five years for nil consideration. In December 2019, the option became exercisable and the majority investor in PMBS served notice to defer a number of its ordinary shares in PMBS sufficient to increase the Group’s interest to 25%. The re-designation of these deferred shares was automatic and did not require shareholder approval or resolution. As at December 31, 2019, the Group deemed that the holding of an exercisable option to step-up the equity in PMBS gave the Group an effective interest in PMBS of 25% and, after reviewing all the facts and circumstances, considered the Group had significant influence over the entity. Accordingly, PMBS was classified as an associate prospectively from December 31, 2019. As at March 31, 2020, PMBS had not yet served the required notices to confirm the re-designation of deferred shares, nor issued the new share certificates and therefore the Group’s legal interest in PMBS remained at 15% at the balance sheet date. Prior to December 31, 2019, the initial 15% equity interest in PMBS was classified as a financial asset measured at fair value through profit or loss and presented within Other investments. Following the classification of PMBS to an associate, the financial asset was de-recognised, re-recognised as an interest in associate and measured at the original cost of the investment in accordance with FRS 102. The total equity interest in PMBS was acquired at nil cost to the Group. Accordingly, the recognition of the investment as an associate required the cumulative unrealised fair value gains booked in prior years to be reversed. In addition, the Group reclassified its investment in PMBS loan notes from Trade and other receivables to Interests in associates. In June 2020, PMBS made the required notices to confirm the re-designation of deferred shares and legally increase the Group’s interest in the associate to 25%. In the fiscal year ended March 31, 2021, the step-up associated with the Group’s investment in PMBS was completed for nil consideration. In addition, PMBS issued additional loan notes to the Group. The impact of the fair value gain/loss of the additional loan notes was recognised on our balance sheet for the fiscal year ended March 31, 2021, estimated to be the face value, resulting in a corresponding gain in our income statement of £2.0 million. For more information, see Note 3 to the Audited Consolidated Financial Statements of Pinewood Group Limited as of and for the fiscal year ended March 31, 2021, included elsewhere within this Offering Memorandum. -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: _The following is a discussion and analysis of the results of operations and financial condition of the Company based on the audited consolidated financial statements of the Company as of, and for the fiscal year ended, March 31, 2019, 2020, and 2021, prepared in accordance with UK GAAP, and the unaudited interim condensed consolidated financial statements of the Company as of, and for the six months ended, September 30, 2020 and 2021, prepared in accordance with UK GAAP. The following discussion and analysis should be read in conjunction with our consolidated financial statements and the notes thereto included in this Offering Memorandum. The following discussion contains certain forward-looking statements that reflect our plans, estimates and beliefs. See the section entitled “Forward-Looking Statements” for information relating to the statements contained in this Offering Memorandum that are not historical facts. Our results of operations could differ materially from those discussed in these forward-looking statements. Factors that could cause or contribute to such differences include, but are not limited to, those discussed below and elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum, including the section entitled “Risk Factors.”_

Subsection Title: Global Film and OTT Production Industry
Subsubsection Title: Increase of Global Production Spend on Content for Key Players ($ in billions)
Subsubsection Text: Source: Ampere Analysis. The growth has been driven mainly by streamers, including Netflix, Amazon, Apple and Hulu, which collectively accounted for 42% of total content production spend by key players in 2021, up from only 10% in 2015. For OTT platforms, the breadth and exclusivity of content, in particular original content, is a key differentiating factor and driver of subscriber acquisition and retention. Netflix and Amazon have both produced a large number of original films and television series, with many receiving awards and critical acclaim. Academy Award winning films include Extraction by Netflix and Manchester by the Sea by Amazon. Popular series include _The Queen’s Gambit, You, The Marvelous Mrs. Maisel, The Man in the High Castle, Tiger King,_ _Stranger Things_ and many others. Their content spending has increased as they have invested in an increasing number of offerings as well as in higher end productions such as _The Crown, which has estimated production costs between $6.5 million and $13 million per episode. To support their streaming platforms, Disney and Apple are increasing their investment in original content production, for both their streaming platforms and traditional distribution. For example, Disney is expecting their content expense to exceed $8.0 billion by 2024, more than double the $4.0 billion originally estimated in April 2019. Warner Media has announced that in 2021, it will premiere 17 movies simultaneously in theatres and on HBO Max in the United States. We believe that this combination of rapidly growing spend on content by existing OTT platforms, the launch of new OTT platforms by traditional media companies, and the competitive response of television broadcasters will continue to drive growth in film and television production spend and therefore demand for film and television content production facilities.

Subsection Title: Global Film and OTT Production Industry
Subsubsection Text: Demand for film and High-end TV continues to increase, driven by rising consumer expectations for higher quality content, including sophisticated visual effects, growing media consumption in emerging markets and increased accessibility to online media via tablets and smartphones. The COVID-19 pandemic has caused disruption to global cinema operations across the world to a varying degree including film releases being postponed, cinemas and movie theatres being closed, and festivals being cancelled. In the UK, productions went on a hiatus during the first national lockdown, however filming resumed over the summer. The COVID-19 pandemic has also led to an increase in the consumption of high quality content through OTT platforms. The five fastest growing streaming platforms by subscriber growth for the twelve months ended September 30, 2021 were Apple TV+, HBO Max, Disney+, Amazon Prime and Netflix, and collectively gained 163 million new subscribers over the period, reflecting an increase of 36% since September 30, 2020. Current large operators Netflix and Amazon launched their streaming services in 2007 and 2006, respectively. As of September 30, 2021, Netflix had 222 million global streaming paid memberships, an increase of 27 million from September 30, 2020, and Amazon Prime had 145 million paid subscribers, reflecting an increase of 26 million from September 30, 2020, according to Ampere Analysis. Furthermore, Apple launched their own streaming service Apple TV+ in November 2019, and as of September 30, 2021 had 88 million subscribers, reflecting an increase of 39 million subscribers compared to September 30, 2020. In response to the competition from Netflix, Amazon and Apple, traditional production companies have also announced their own streaming platforms. For example, Disney launched Disney+, its own direct-toconsumer streaming platform in 2019, and had 10 million subscribers on the first day. As of September 30, 2021, Disney+ had 87 million subscribers, an increase of 31 million subscribers compared to September 30, 2020, and is targeting between 230 and 260 million subscribers by 2024, including 30-40% from Hotstar, the Disney+ platform in India. Disney+ and Netflix together accounted for 46% of subscribers across key streaming platforms. Warner Media (owned by AT&T), launched HBO Max, which had 69 million HBO Max activations as of September 30, 2021. Global spend for high-end content, a key driver for demand for our facilities, has seen consistent growth over the last four years. Between 2015 and 2021, Amazon, Apple, CBS Viacom, NBCUniversal, HBO/Warner ----- Media, Hulu, Netflix and The Walt Disney Company (each, a “key player” and collectively, “key players”) increased their global production spend on content by 63%, equating to a CAGR of 8%.

Facilities with a track record of hosting high-end content productions (“premium facilities”) share a number of characteristics. Most importantly, these facilities are located in close proximity to a highly skilled work force that can staff thousands of highly specialised crew members required for production. Although it is possible to move crew members for the duration of a production, doing so greatly increases complexity and operational risk. As a result, premium facilities that host these productions can benefit from the presence of multiple related businesses on or near their facility (through, for example, our Media Hub model). Additionally, these premium facilities are often located in attractive areas for directors and actors to reside in for the relatively long duration of a production. Importantly, such facilities must offer extensive physical infrastructure, including a range of stage sizes, special stages (for example, underwater stages), ample backlots and ancillary spaces such as workshops and offices. Finally, such facilities must offer comprehensive security, given the special concerns in film production around privacy, confidentiality and business continuity. Facilities that exhibit all of these features create an “ecosystem” that foster on-time, on-budget production. ----- Major production companies that are active in content production use both owned sites and hired independent facilities. A limited number of facilities exist globally with the right blockbuster film production “ecosystem,” and independent facilities with such features are highly attractive for the major film production companies. This is particularly true when a major film production company has filmed successful content at a particular location, when its owned sites are filled to capacity or when productions require special stages. Although the major film production companies are repeat users of independent facilities, they are unlikely to invest in acquiring independent facilities or building their own sites, as they view themselves as investors in content rather than real estate.
