_Passengers (2016); _Centurion (2010); Angels & Demons (2009); The Fifth Element_ (1997); Gandhi (1982) Lionsgate 10+ 35 _Military Wives (2020); American Assassin (2017); Now You See _Me (2016)_ Legendary 10+ 14 _Crimson Peak (2015); Jack the Giant Slayer (2013) Netflix 7 38 _The Old Guard (2020); The Midnight Sky (2020) Amazon 6 13 _Cinderella (2021); The Expanse (2020); Small Axe (2020) HBO 15 8 _The Nevers_ (2021); My Big Fat Greek Wedding 2 (2015); The _Special Relationship (2009)_ (1) Productions are included in this tally when principal photography and production have completed, though they may still be in post production. The wide range, amount and quality of infrastructure at our facilities results in a leading market share. Between 2010 and 2021, 83 out of 274 blockbuster films were filmed at Pinewood-branded studios, representing 30% of all blockbuster films for that period. Among these 83 productions, 71 were filmed in the United Kingdom at Pinewood Studios and Shepperton Studios and the remaining 12 were filmed at Pinewood Atlanta Studios and Pinewood Toronto Studios. ----- In addition to major film production companies, which generally focus on blockbuster films, we also have relationships with several independent film production companies. Since the commencement of the Disney Long-term Contract and the Netflix Long-term Contract, we have continued to work with major film production companies other than Disney and Netflix, though we have and expect to continue to do so with reduced frequency, on a space-available basis. Under the Disney Long-term Contract and Netflix Long-term Contract, Disney and Netflix are able to notify us of the availability of unused stage space, which we can then rent to other film production companies. Additionally, as the underwater facility and Television Studios are not subject to the Long-term Contracts, we continue to rent these spaces to other film production companies as we have done historically.

We have longstanding relationships with television production companies, such as the BBC, Endemol Shine UK, Fremantle and Avalon. Such customers utilise our fully-equipped Television Studios to produce prerecorded, live and live-audience television productions, such as Would I Lie to You?, Taskmaster, Tenable and _Through the Keyhole. As the Television Studios are not subject to the Disney Long-term Contract, we will_ continue to rent this space to television production companies as we have done historically.

Media Hub facilities are located at Pinewood Studios and Shepperton Studios, allowing production companies at both studios access to the goods and services offered by tenants in our Media Hub. The tenants in our Media Hub range from individual casting specialists and a hair and makeup school to offices of large corporations such as Kodak Limited. The high demand for Media Hub space allows us to optimise our tenant mix by selectively offering vacancies to desirable tenants. We generally lease out Media Hub space to tenants for terms of twelve to 24 months. There is ongoing demand for our Media Hub space, leading to historically high occupancy rates and lease renewal rates. For the past ten fiscal years, our Media Hub business line occupancy rates averaged 95%.

We have international sales and marketing fee contracts with international partners in the Dominican Republic and Canada. These sales and marketing contracts generally have terms of five to ten years and entitle us to earn an annual sales and marketing fee in return for certain services. See “—Our Business Lines—Other _Activities.”_
Our key customer groups are film production companies, television production companies, Media Hub tenants and international partners.

On August 23, 2019, we entered into an Agreement for Lease with Banner Productions Limited in respect of stages, workshops and offices at Pinewood Studios. Parties to the agreement are Pinewood Studios Limited, as landlord of Pinewood Studios West, Pinewood PSB Limited, as landlord of Pinewood Studios East, Banner Productions Limited, as tenant, and The Walt Disney Company Limited, as guarantor. Banner Productions Limited is a private limited company incorporated in England and Wales and is wholly-owned by The Walt Disney Company Limited. The Disney Long-term Contract commenced on January 1, 2020. In connection with the Disney Long-term Contract, approximately 39,000 square feet of workshop space at Pinewood East Phase 2 was completed in summer 2020 and Disney has pre-let the five new stages at Pinewood West, for which construction is underway and is expected to complete in 2022, adding approximately 100,000 square feet. The initial term of the Disney Long-term Contract is twelve years. There are extension mechanisms under the Long-term Contract. There is an agreed base rent, payable annually in advance. Rent is reviewed annually on an upwards basis if there are increases in UK RPI. Utilities are re-charged in addition to rent. Other studio operational costs are our responsibility, and we will continue to operate and maintain the studios. ----- Where Disney do not require space at Pinewood Studios, the Disney Long-term Contract includes a mechanism for the space to be marketed and hired by us to third-party productions. The Disney Long-term Contract includes standard provisions relating to termination upon destruction of the contracted space, non-payment of rent and insolvency, but there is no other ability to terminate unilaterally by any party. The demised premises under the Disney Long-term Contract include stages, workshops and offices at Pinewood Studios, totalling approximately 505,000 square feet of stage space, approximately 438,000 square feet of workshop space and approximately 199,000 square feet of office space feet, including the new stages, workshops and offices at Pinewood East Phase 2 that were completed in autumn 2019, with one of the workshop blocks totalling approximately 39,000 square feet completed in summer 2020. Disney also has the exclusive right to use backlot space at the Pinewood Studios. Use of the premises is only for film production in respect of the stages and workshops, and general office use for the areas demised as offices. Under the Disney Long-term Contract, Disney have pre-let the five new stages at Pinewood West, for which construction is underway and is expected to complete in 2022.

On June 6, 2019, we entered into an agreement for lease with Netflix Studios UK Limited in respect of stages, workshops and offices at Shepperton Studios. Parties to the agreement are Shepperton Studios Limited, as the landlord, Netflix Studios UK Limited, as tenant, and Netflix, Inc., as guarantor. Netflix Studios UK Limited is a limited company incorporated in England and Wales, and Netflix, Inc. is incorporated in Delaware and is listed on the Nasdaq Stock Market. The Netflix Long-term Contract commenced October 31, 2019. The term of the Netflix Long-term Contract is for ten years. There are extension mechanisms under the Long-term Contract. There is an agreed base rent, payable quarterly in advance. The rent is increased annually by a fixed percentage every year, with a catch up to accumulated UK RPI every five years if higher. Utilities are re-charged in addition to rent. Other studio operational costs are our responsibility, and we will continue to operate and maintain the studios. Where Netflix do not require space at Shepperton Studios, the Netflix Long-term Contract includes a mechanism for the space to be marketed and hired by us to third-party productions. The Netflix Long-term Contract includes provisions relating to termination upon destruction, nonpayment of rent and insolvency, but there is no other ability to terminate unilaterally by any party. The demised premises under the Netflix Long-term Contract includes stages, workshops and offices at Shepperton Studios, totalling approximately 167,000 square feet of stage space, approximately 161,000 square feet of workshop space and approximately 111,000 square feet of office space feet. Netflix also have the right to use a certain amount of backlot space at Shepperton Studios. Use of the premises is only for film production in respect of the stages and workshops, and general office use for the areas demised as offices.

In 2021 we entered into an agreement for lease with Netflix in respect of stages, workshops and offices at Shepperton Studios in relation to the Shepperton Expansion Project. The parties to the agreement are the same as the Netflix Long-term Contract, being Shepperton Studios Limited, as the landlord, Netflix Studios UK Limited, as tenant, and Netflix, Inc. as guarantor. The lease is due to commence on completion of the Shepperton South development works, which is expected towards the end of 2023. As is customary in an agreement for lease involving building works, there are certain longstop date provisions for the completion of the works. The Netflix Shepperton South Long-term Contract is co-terminus with the initial term of the existing Netflix Long-Term Contract and it also contains extension mechanisms similar to the existing Netflix Long-Term Contract. There is an agreed base rent, payable quarterly in advance, which will be increased by a fixed percentage every year, with a catch up to accumulated UK RPI every five years if higher. Utilities will be re-charged in ----- addition to rent. Other studio operational costs are our responsibility, and we will continue to operate and maintain the studios. Where Netflix do not require space at Shepperton South, the contract includes a mechanism for the space to be marketed and hired by us to third-party productions. The Netflix Shepperton South Long-term Contract includes provisions relating to termination upon destruction, non-payment of rent and insolvency, but there is no other ability to terminate unilaterally by any party. The demised premises under the Netflix Shepperton South Long-term Contract will include stages, workshops and offices at Shepperton Studios, totalling approximately 0.5 million square feet of stages and Other Production Accommodation space. Use of the premises is only for film production in respect of the stages and workshops, and general office use for the areas demised as offices.

As of October 31, 2021, we had 193 staff members, comprising 99 in operations, compliance, projects, and facilities and maintenance, 46 in Post Production and 48 in head office and administrative positions. A number of our employees may be members of the Broadcasting Entertainment, Cinematograph, and Theatre Union (“BECTU”), with whom we entered into a voluntary recognition agreement on December 22, 2010. BECTU represents the interest of its members in relation to pay rates, hours and conditions of work, holiday, health and safety and training. We believe we have a good relationship with BECTU. We offer benefits packages to salaried employees, including medical and retirement benefits. We actively safeguard the position of our employees’ rights through comprehensive and regularly reviewed employment practices in the areas of recruitment, training, welfare, remuneration and employee relations. In addition to a published grievance policy, we maintain a whistle-blower policy providing an opportunity for employees to raise grievances with senior management. Our policy on equal opportunities has procedures in place to ensure that recruitment and promotion recognises such diversity and prohibits discrimination on the basis of age, gender, disability, colour, racial origin, religion or sexual orientation.
The following is a summary of certain contracts material to the operation of our business.

We are committed to do our part to combat climate change by reducing our carbon footprint and pursuing green development initiatives. We are proud of a number of sustainability efforts at our facilities. We purchase 100% of our electricity from renewable sources, utilize solar panels and have planted approximately 28,000 trees and shrubs at Pinewood East. We also provide free shuttle bus services to our customers, which we estimate has replaced approximately 100,000 journeys to our locations. Since 2012, we have achieved a 41% reduction in our carbon footprint and are on track to meet our goal of a 50% reduction by 2030.

Subsection Title: Health, Safety, Fire and Environmental Matters
Subsubsection Text: Our management is accountable for understanding and managing health, safety, fire and environmental risks and in meeting health, safety, fire and environmental objectives. We have a documented health, safety and fire policy and a documented environmental policy. Our operations are subject to increasingly stringent national and local environmental laws and regulations, including laws and regulations governing air and noise emissions; wastewater and storm water discharges and uses; petroleum spillages; the maintenance of storage tanks and the use, release, storage, disposal, handling and transportation of, and exposure to, chemicals and hazardous substances; and otherwise relating to health, safety and the protection of the environment and natural resources and the remediation of contaminated soil and groundwater. We are not currently involved in any health, safety, fire or environmental legal or regulatory actions. We are currently in substantial compliance with all applicable health, safety, fire and environmental regulations. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business—We are exposed to risks relating to regulations and liabilities _arising from our operations and assets, including environmental, health and safety laws, regulations, and liabilities.”_ -----

We support and encourage the development of the UK film and television production industries by engaging with aspiring young creatives and our community. By giving training, running a bespoke Studio Diploma and offering work experience and shadowing, we seek to develop a skilled film and television production resource base in the United Kingdom. We also sponsor numerous seminars, awards and scholarships to recognise and educate the next generation of industry professionals. We continue to sponsor Lord Puttnam’s Atticus Education Online Seminars on Creativity in Film based at Bath Spa University and the Best British Short Film Award for the Iris Prize through the use of our post production facilities. We also offer two undergraduate scholarships to the National Film and Television School (“NFTS”) and host the BFI Academy schemes that introduce young people across the country to film and television production. In 2020, we entered into a letter of intent with NFTS in relation to establishing an education and training centre as part of the potential Pinewood South development, and now sponsor scholars for students in the community. We have also hired 8 employees from the KickStart Scheme. We also work with local schools, colleges and universities, including Buckinghamshire New University, Amersham and Wycombe College, Chalfont Community College and the London Film School, in addition to visiting local secondary schools and colleges to describe opportunities for work experience and roles working directly for our studios and to give information on jobs in the film and television industries generally. We support the Skills to Aviation scheme in partnership with ScreenSkills and Buckinghamshire and Enterprise LEPs to support jobseekers previously employed in the aviation industry at Heathrow transfer their skills into the screen industries. In addition, we host several annual creative industry careers events at Shepperton and Pinewood Studios, with over 7,000 students in attendance across both sites since January 2021. In 2019, Shepperton Studios received the Rotary Business Award, presented by the Sunbury and Shepperton Rotary Club in recognition of the Studios service to the community. In 2009, Pinewood Studios and Shepperton Studios received the BAFTA Award for Outstanding British Contribution to Cinema. On July 1, 2019 we announced the Group’s new diversity, equality and inclusion (DEI) strategy, which is our commitment to building an inclusive and equal workforce where all feel respected and empowered. Our DEI plan focuses on three pillars: supporting inclusion, achieving equality and celebrating diversity. Our staff is also actively involved in volunteering for community clean-up events, with 60 staff members participating in such events since January 2021.

We maintain a variety of licenses for the operation of our business, including those related to petroleum distribution, environmental licenses, waste brokerage, and our premises licenses. We believe that we are not currently in material breach of any of these licenses.

Our intellectual property portfolio consists primarily of registered trademarks. We currently hold international trademark registrations for a number of our more important names and logos, including Pinewood Studios and Shepperton Studios. In 2017, we updated our international trademark portfolio following a rebranding initiative and new logo. In connection with our International Sales and Marketing business line, we license the Pinewood brand in exchange for a fee (as in the case of Pinewood Toronto Studios) or, in certain circumstances, an ownership interest in the business (as in the case of Pinewood Dominican Republic and Pinewood MBS). We do not actively maintain patent or copyright portfolios.

Our information technology systems enhance the efficiency of our operations with respect to all of our business lines. Our studios employ extensive information technology equipment and we make investments in our information technology systems and monitor the adequacy of our applications in use on an ongoing basis.

We maintain insurance to cover risks associated with the ordinary operation of our business, including general liability, property coverage, environmental, cyber security and employers’ liability insurance. We insure our studio locations against such hazards as fire, explosion, theft, flood, mischief and accidents. All of our policies ----- are underwritten with reputable insurance providers, and we conduct periodic reviews of our insurance coverage, both in terms of coverage limits and deductibles. We also actively monitor all key conditions under our policies and have systems in place to ensure that we remain in compliance with those conditions. We believe that our insurance coverage is sufficient for the risks associated with our operations.

We have not been involved in any material legal or arbitration proceedings which may have, or have had during the last twelve months preceding the date of this document, a significant effect on our financial position, nor as far as we are aware, are there any such proceedings threatened by or against us. We may become involved from time to time in various claims and lawsuits arising in the ordinary course of our business, such as environmental, health and safety claims, personal liability claims, employee claims and intellectual property disputes. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business—We are exposed to risks relating to regulations and _liabilities arising from our operations and assets, including environmental, health and safety laws, regulations, and liabilities.” We note that the outcome of legal proceedings can be extremely difficult to predict, and we offer_ no assurances in this regard. -----

Subsection Title: MANAGEMENT Board of Directors of the Issuer
Subsubsection Text: The Issuer was incorporated as a public limited company under the laws of England and Wales on November 8, 2017, with company number 11054849. The Issuer was formed for the purpose of issuing the Notes, facilitating the Offering and drawing funds under the Revolving Credit Facility. The registered address of the Issuer is Pinewood Studios, Pinewood Road, Iver Heath, Buckinghamshire, SL0 0NH, United Kingdom. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, the board of directors of the Issuer is as follows:

Paul Golding .......................................... 56 Director Barbara Inskip ........................................ 53 Director Luis Moner ............................................. 40 Director The business address of the board of directors of the Issuer is Pinewood Studios, Pinewood Road, Iver Heath, Buckinghamshire, SL0 0NH, United Kingdom. Brief biographies for the members of the board of directors of the Issuer are set forth later in this section. Paul Golding .......................................... 56 Chairman and Interim Chief Executive Officer Barbara Inskip ........................................ 53 Chief Financial Officer Andrew M Smith .................................... 59 Corporate Affairs Director Luis Moner ............................................. 40 Special Projects Director Nathan Shike .......................................... 40 Non-Executive Director and Aermont Representative Alison Trewartha .................................... 40 Non-Executive Director and Aermont Representative The business address of the Board of the Company is Pinewood Studios, Pinewood Road, Iver Heath, Buckinghamshire, SL0 0NH, United Kingdom. Set forth below is a brief biography of each member of the Board.

Subsection Title: Board of Directors of the Company
Subsubsection Text: The Company, Pinewood Group Limited (formerly Pinewood Group plc), was incorporated under the laws of England and Wales on December 7, 1999, with company number 03889552. The Company subsequently re-registered as a private limited company on October 5, 2016. The registered address of the Company is Pinewood Studios, Pinewood Road, Iver Heath, Buckinghamshire, SL0 0NH, United Kingdom. The board of directors of the Company (the “Board”) determines the Group’s business activities; strategy; risk management policies; commencement of any new business activities that differ from existing business activities; expansion and diversification into new geographies; acquisitions, divestments, disposals and other transactions; business combinations; significant financial decisions; capital structure and dividend policy; termination or execution of contracts and other transactions outside delegated limits; conclusion, amendment or termination of partnerships and joint ventures; issuance of shares and options; material changes to accounting policies or practices; internal and external communications; commencement, defence or settlement of any material litigation; Board committees; and the Board structure, composition and succession. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, the Board is comprised as follows:

Subsection Title: Paul Golding, Chairman and Interim Chief Executive Officer
Subsubsection Text: Mr. Golding joined the Board in October 2016 as Chairman following the acquisition of the Group by funds advised by Aermont. Mr. Golding is also a Partner and member of the Investment Committee at Aermont. Prior to joining Aermont in 2010, Mr. Golding was Head of Real Estate Asset Strategies at Norges Bank Investment Management, the group that manages the Norwegian Global Pension Fund. Prior to that, Mr. Golding worked at Merrill Lynch, where he was Head of Real Estate Investment Banking in Europe and the Middle East. Mr. Golding obtained a Masters in Finance from the London Business School. In April 2017, Mr. Golding became the Interim Chief Executive Officer and is expected to maintain this position until a suitable candidate is appointed. Upon appointment of a new candidate, Mr. Golding is expected to remain as Chairman. -----

Ms. Inskip joined Pinewood as Chief Financial Officer and was appointed to the Board in May 2019. Prior to this, she held senior finance positions in Taylor Wimpey plc, Serco Group plc and Centrica plc, having started her career at KPMG. She graduated from University College London with a BSc Honours in Economics and is a Fellow of the Institute of Chartered Accountants in England and Wales.

Subsection Title: Andrew M. Smith, Corporate Affairs Director
Subsubsection Text: Mr. Smith joined Pinewood in June 2008 as Group Director Corporate Affairs and was appointed to the Board in May 2012. Prior to this, he was Managing Partner of The Policy Partnership. Mr. Smith is a Member of the Film Skills Council, the British Film Commission Advisory Board, the British Screen Advisory Council and an associate member of BAFTA. He is a Non-Executive Director of Bucks Business First Ltd and serves as Chairman of the Buckinghamshire Thames Valley Local Enterprise Partnership.

Mr. Moner joined the Board in October 2016 as a Non-Executive Director following the acquisition of the Group by funds advised by Aermont, and was subsequently appointed as an Executive Director in April 2017. He is also a Managing Director at Aermont. Prior to joining Aermont in 2015, Mr. Moner was a Senior Investment Manager at Norges Bank Investment Management in London. Mr. Moner started his career at Merrill Lynch in 2004, when he joined the real estate advisory team. He graduated from ESADE Business School with a Master in Business Administration.

Mr. Shike joined the Board as a Non-Executive Director in October 2016 following the acquisition of the Group by funds advised by Aermont. He is also a Partner and member of the Investment Committee at Aermont. Prior to joining Aermont in 2007, Mr. Shike worked at the City Investment Fund LP, a New York City real estate fund co-sponsored by Morgan Stanley and Fisher Brothers, a New York based commercial real estate operator and developer. Mr. Shike graduated magna cum laude from Amherst College with a Bachelor of Arts in Economics.

Ms. Trewartha joined the Board as a Non-Executive Director in October 2016 following the acquisition of the Group by funds advised by Aermont. She is also a Partner and the Chief Legal and Compliance Officer, as well as a member of the Investment Committee, at Aermont. Prior to joining Aermont in 2008, Ms. Trewartha was an associate in the Mergers & Acquisitions team at Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom in London. Ms. Trewartha started her career as an associate at Deacons (now Norton Rose Fulbright) in Melbourne, Australia, in the capital markets and corporate transactions team. She graduated from Monash University with a Bachelor of Laws with honours and Bachelor of Business Management.
During the fiscal year ended March 31, 2021, the aggregate compensation (including salary fees, pension, bonus, incentive plan and other benefits) paid to the Board was approximately £0.59 million.

The Company historically has offered a long-term incentive plan to incentivise certain members of management. Following the public to private transaction, this long-term incentive plan was discontinued. We may in the future consider establishing a new long-term incentive plan. -----

Demand for facilities for film and television production (“content production”) has increased in recent years, driven by continued growth in consumer demand for high quality audio-visual content. Such premium content includes blockbuster films and High-end TV. Blockbuster films have historically accounted for a disproportionate share of global film revenues and content spend, however, with proliferation of streaming, High-end TV is catching up. Only a limited number of production facilities globally regularly host blockbuster films and High-end TV productions, as producers favour locations with well-developed infrastructure in close proximity to a highly skilled and highly specialised film production work force. Other factors, such as the availability of stable and competitive tax incentives and proximity to well connected, international airports and gateway cities are also of critical importance. The United Kingdom generally, and London and southeast England in particular, have developed a film production “ecosystem” that has attracted a large and growing share of the highest budget films globally. The ability to build new film production facilities in such locations is constrained by the scarcity of available land and a number of other factors. In recent years, there has also been a significant growth in spend on original film and High-end TV by OTT operators, such as Netflix and Amazon, with several other operators launching OTT platforms including Disney, Apple, NBCUniversal and Warner Media. This growth in spend has increased demand for our facilities directly as well as indirectly by reducing available space at competitors’ film and television production facilities. We believe long-term planning associated with spending on original content by OTT operators and on franchise films (such as the Marvel super hero franchise, Star Wars and James Bond), has also increased the predictability of spending by a number of production companies. In turn, we have observed an increase in demand to lease production facilities on a long-term basis. On the back of this demand, we entered into Long-term Contracts with Disney and Netflix who occupy space at Pinewood Studios and Shepperton Studios. We believe that excess demand for similar long-term leases continues to exist.

The Issuer is a direct wholly-owned subsidiary of the Company, which, in turn, is a direct wholly-owned subsidiary of the Parent. The Parent is indirectly wholly-owned by PW Real Estate Fund III LP, a fund advised by Aermont. Aermont is an independent asset management group focused on real estate and real estate related investment activities. Aermont was established in 2007 (previously, under a different name) and is currently comprised of a team of 20 investment professionals (including five partners) who have significant relevant experience, such as with real estate asset-rich operating companies and platforms. Aermont’s strategy is centred on long-term value creation through an operator-oriented approach, focusing on prime assets or projects at top locations in major cities in the United Kingdom, France, Germany, Spain and other European countries, as well as operating businesses and platforms with growth potential. Since 2007, the Aermont funds, including PW Real Estate Fund III LP, have received equity commitments of around €6.0 billion in aggregate. -----

In the course of our ordinary business activities, we enter into agreements with or render services to related parties from time to time. In turn, such related parties may render services or deliver goods to us as part of their business. Purchase and supply agreements between subsidiaries and affiliated companies are entered into within the ordinary course of business. We also enter into financing arrangements in the ordinary course of business with related parties within and outside the Group, including a loan to our Parent which amounted to £334.3 million as of September 30, 2021 with scheduled maturity in September 2025 bearing pay-in-kind interest at 3.55% per annum. -----

The Company and certain subsidiaries of the Company entered into a £50 million super senior revolving credit facility agreement originally dated November 29, 2017 (as amended and restated on September 8, 2019 and as further amended and restated from time to time) (the “Revolving Credit Facility Agreement”) between, among others, Barclays Bank PLC, Credit Suisse AG, London Branch, HSBC UK Bank plc and The Royal Bank of Scotland plc as arrangers and original lenders, Lucid Agency Services Limited as facility agent and Deutsche Bank AG, London Branch as security agent. The Revolving Credit Facility may be utilised by any current or future borrower under the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement in pound sterling, euro, US dollars or Canadian dollars or any other readily available currency approved by the agent by, the drawing of cash advances or the issue of letters of credit and ancillary facilities. The Revolving Credit Facility may be applied towards the general corporate and working capital purposes of the Restricted Group (being the Company and its restricted subsidiaries). In addition, the Company may elect to request additional commitments under the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement (the “Additional Increase”). The total amount of such indebtedness that may be incurred by way of Additional Increase shall not exceed the amount equal to the greater of (x) £50.0 million and (y) the lower of (i) 14.5% of Total Assets (as defined in the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement) and (ii) £100.0 million. The Company and the lenders may agree to certain terms in relation to the Additional Increase, including the margin (subject to parameters as set out in the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement). The Company expects to enter into an Additional Increase Confirmation on or prior to the Issue Date to request additional commitments to increase the total commitments under the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement to £65.0 million. Such Additional Increase will if executed, subject to the satisfaction of certain conditions precedent, take effect as an increase to the Revolving Credit Facility and will be subject to the same terms. The Revolving Credit Facility is not currently utilised but may be utilised at any time and from time to time until the date falling one month prior to the maturity date of the Revolving Credit Facility.

Loans under the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement bear interest at rates per annum equal to LIBOR for loans denominated in sterling and in US dollars or, for loans denominated in euro, EURIBOR, or for loans denominated in Canadian dollars, CDOR, plus, in each case, a margin of 1.80% per annum. The Company is in negotiations with the lenders under the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement to amend and restate the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement to provide for market standard screen rate replacement language whereby LIBOR would be replaced by SOFR for loans denominated in US dollars (with effect from a rate switch date to be agreed) and by SONIA for loans denominated in sterling (with immediate effect). A margin ratchet is based on the Net Secured Loan-to-Value Ratio (as defined in the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement and the Indenture). The margin on any loans under an Additional Increase will be agreed between the Company and the relevant lenders (subject to the parameters as set out in the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement). Default interest is calculated as an additional 1% per annum on the overdue amount. A commitment fee is payable on the aggregate undrawn and uncancelled amount of the Revolving Credit Facility until the end of the availability period for the Revolving Credit Facility, at a rate of 30% of the applicable margin for the Revolving Credit Facility. ----- The commitment fee is payable three-monthly in arrear, on the last day of availability of the Revolving Credit Facility and, if the Revolving Credit Facility is cancelled, on the date on which the cancellation is effective. The commitment fee in respect of any Additional Increase shall be agreed between the Company and the relevant lenders (subject to the parameters as set out in the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement). The Company is also required to pay customary agency fees to the Facility Agent and the Security Agent in connection with the Revolving Credit Facility.

Each advance will be repaid on the last day of the interest period relating thereto, subject to a netting mechanism against amounts to be drawn on such date. All outstanding amounts under the Revolving Credit Facility will (unless the lenders thereunder agree otherwise) be repaid on the maturity date which is the date falling six months prior to the earliest originally scheduled final maturity of the Existing Notes. Amounts repaid by the borrowers on loans made under the Revolving Credit Facility may be reborrowed during the availability period of the facility, subject to certain conditions.

The Revolving Credit Facility Agreement allows for voluntary prepayments (subject to _de minimis amounts). The Revolving Credit Facility Agreement also permits each lender to require the mandatory prepayment of all amounts due to that lender upon a change of control (which includes a “Change of Control” as defined in the Indenture). In addition, in the event of a sale of all or substantially all of the assets of the Restricted Group whether in a single transaction or a series of related transactions the Revolving Credit Facility will be cancelled and all amounts outstanding under the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement will become immediately due and payable.

The Company and certain subsidiaries of the Company (the “Guarantors”) have provided a senior guarantee of all amounts payable to the finance parties under the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement, subject to limitations imposed by applicable law and certain of the Agreed Security Principles. The Revolving Credit Facility Agreement requires that (subject to the Agreed Security Principles) within 30 business days of the delivery of each set of annual financial statements each member of the Restricted Group that is Material Company which definition includes, among other things, any member of the Restricted Group that has earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortization representing 5% or more of EBITDA (as defined in the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement), becomes a guarantor under the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement. Furthermore, the Company is required to ensure that within 30 business days of the delivery of each set of annual financial statements other members of the Restricted Group are or become Guarantors to ensure that the Guarantors represent not less than 80% of the EBITDA (as defined in the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement) of the Restricted Group (subject to the Agreed Security Principles). The EBITDA of any member of the Restricted Group that is not able to, or is not otherwise required to, become a Guarantor in accordance with the Agreed Security Principles shall be excluded when determining compliance with such 80% test.

The Revolving Credit Facility is secured by the same collateral as the Notes; however, holders of the Notes will receive proceeds from enforcement of such collateral and certain distressed disposals only after any obligations secured on a super priority basis, including obligations under the Revolving Credit Facility and any other indebtedness which is permitted to be super senior (including certain hedging obligations) have been repaid in full.

The Revolving Credit Facility Agreement contains certain customary representations and warranties which were given at the time the Revolving Credit Facility was originally established (subject to certain exceptions and qualifications and with certain representations and warranties being repeated), including status and incorporation, binding obligations, non-conflict with constitutional documents, laws or other obligations, power and authority, validity and admissibility in evidence, governing law and enforcement, insolvency, no filing or ----- stamp taxes, no default, base case model, financial statements, no litigation, no breach of laws, environmental laws, taxation, ranking, good title to assets, shares, intellectual property, group structure chart, centre of main interests, pensions and sanctions.

The Revolving Credit Facility Agreement contains certain of the incurrence covenants and related definitions (with certain adjustments and exceptions) that are set forth in the Indenture. In addition, the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement contains a financial covenant. See “—Financial Covenant.” The Revolving Credit Facility Agreement also limits the amount of Indebtedness that may be incurred under clause (1) of the second paragraph of the covenant described under “Description of the Notes—Certain Covenants—Limitation on _Indebtedness” to £100.0 million (and any refinancing thereof)._ The Revolving Credit Facility Agreement also requires certain members of the Restricted Group to observe certain additional covenants, including covenants relating to maintenance of guarantor and security coverage, further assurances, maintenance of authorizations, compliance with laws and sanctions, taxation, change of business, preservation of assets, _pari passu_ ranking, insurance, pensions, intellectual property, unrestricted subsidiaries and centre of main interests. The Revolving Credit Facility contains an information covenant under which, among other things, the Company is required to deliver to the Facility Agent the financial statements that are required to be delivered pursuant to paragraphs 2 and 3 of the covenant described under “Description of the Notes—Reports” and annual and quarterly compliance certificates. In addition to the covenants set forth in the Indenture, the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement contains a restriction on selling, leasing, or making certain other types of disposal of the Pinewood Studios property (including designating any owner of the Pinewood Studios site as an Unrestricted Subsidiary or selling directly or indirectly the equity interests of the owner of the Pinewood Studios property), with certain exceptions with respect to ordinary course leases made on arms’ length terms and (subject to maintaining any pre-existing liens on the property and ensuring that the property remains owned by a Guarantor) intra-Group disposals or reorganisations.

The Revolving Credit Facility Agreement requires the Company to maintain a minimum EBITDA (as defined in the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement) of £24.0 million (or, if higher and if the total commitments under the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement, when aggregated with the total commitments for any other Indebtedness classified under clause (1) of the second paragraph of the covenant described under “Description of _the Notes—Certain Covenants—Limitation on Indebtedness,” as of the end of the relevant measurement period_ exceeds £75,000,000, an amount in GBP equivalent to 48% of the aggregate amount of Indebtedness then outstanding under clause (1) of the second paragraph of the covenant described under “Description of the Notes— _Certain Covenants—Limitation on Indebtedness”) if, at 5 p.m. London time on the last day of the relevant_ measurement period, the aggregate amount of all outstanding loans under the Revolving Credit Facility and any ancillary facility outstanding is equal to or exceeds the higher of 50% of the total commitments under the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement as of the end of the relevant measurement period and £25.0 million. The Company is permitted to cure breaches of the minimum EBITDA (as defined in the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement) covenant either by repaying, prepaying or otherwise reducing sufficient utilisation under the Revolving Credit Facility such that the testing threshold is no longer met or by including any cure amount (being amounts received by the Company in cash pursuant to any new equity or permitted shareholder loan) as EBITDA for the purposes of the financial covenant. No more than four cure amounts may be taken into account during the term of the Revolving Credit Facility and there shall be no more than two cures in any four consecutive financial quarters or in any twelve-month period.

In addition, the Revolving Credit Facility contains, amongst others, the following events of default (subject in certain cases to customary grace periods, materiality thresholds and exceptions): - non-payment; - breach of the financial covenant (subject to cure rights); ----- - breach of other obligations under the finance documents relating to the Revolving Credit Facility; - inaccuracy of a representation or statement when made; - cross-payment default and cross acceleration to the Notes (subject to a £20.0 million threshold); - insolvency and insolvency proceedings as set out in the Indenture; - unlawfulness, repudiation, rescission, invalidity or unenforceability of the finance documents entered into in connection with the Revolving Credit Facility; or - breach of the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement by any member of the Restricted Group or the Parent.

The Revolving Credit Facility is governed by and construed in accordance with English law although certain covenants and certain events of default, which are included in the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement and largely replicate those contained in the Indenture, will be interpreted in accordance with New York law (without prejudice to the fact that the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement is governed by English law).

The Existing Notes mature on September 30, 2025. We pay interest on the Existing Notes semi-annually on each March 30 and September 30, at a rate of 3¼% per annum. The Existing Notes are general senior secured obligations of the Issuer and (i) rank senior in right of payment to all of the Issuer’s existing and future debt that is expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Existing Notes, (ii) rank pari passu in right of payment with any of the Issuer’s existing and future obligations that are not expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Existing Notes, including the Notes offered hereby, indebtedness incurred under the Revolving Credit Facility and certain hedging obligations, (iii) are effectively subordinated to any existing and future indebtedness of the Issuer that is secured by property or assets that do not secure the Existing Notes, to the extent of the value of the property or assets securing such indebtedness; and (iv) are structurally subordinated to any existing and future indebtedness of subsidiaries of the Company that do not guarantee the Existing Notes, including obligations to trade creditors. The Existing Notes are guaranteed on a senior secured basis by the Guarantors (subject to certain guarantee limitations) and are secured by a first priority security interest in the Collateral. The Existing Notes are subject to the Intercreditor Agreement that governs the relative rights of certain of our creditors under our financing arrangements as described in “—Intercreditor Agreement” below. We may redeem all or part of the Existing Notes at any time on or after September 30, 2021 at redemption prices specified as percentages of the principal amount of Existing Notes so redeemed. We may redeem also all of the Existing Notes at a price equal to their principal amount plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to the redemption date upon the occurrence of certain changes in tax law. Additionally, we may exercise a call option if up to 90% of the Existing Notes outstanding have been redeemed or repurchased pursuant to a tender offer. In addition, at any time and from time to time prior to October 31, 2023, we may on any one or more occasions redeem up to 40% of the original aggregate principal amount of the Notes with funds in an aggregate amount not exceeding the net cash proceeds received from one or more equity offerings at a redemption price equal to the 103.250% of the principal amount of the Existing Notes so redeemed plus accrued and unpaid interest and Additional Amounts under certain conditions. Furthermore, at any time and from time to time prior to October 31, 2023, we may on any one or more occasions redeem during each calendar year up to 10% of the original principal amount of the Existing Notes at a redemption price of 103.000% of the principal amount of the Existing Notes. If we sell certain of our assets or undergo a change of control, we may also be required to make an offer to repurchase the Existing Notes at specified redemption prices.

The Existing Notes Indenture among other things, limits our ability and the ability of the Restricted Subsidiaries (as defined therein) to (i) incur or guarantee additional indebtedness or issue preferred shares, subject to incurrence-based tests (described below); (ii) make certain investments or other restricted payments; (iii) create liens; (iv) sell assets and certain subsidiary stock; (v) pay dividends or make other distributions or repurchase or ----- redeem capital stock or subordinated debt; (vi) engage in certain transactions with affiliates; (vii) enter into agreements that restrict the payment of dividends by subsidiaries or the repayment of intercompany loans and advances; (viii) engage in mergers or consolidations; and (ix) impair the security interests in the collateral granted to the Existing Notes. The foregoing covenants are subject to a number of important exceptions and qualifications which are broadly similar to those under “Description of the Notes” with respect to the Notes offered hereby. The Existing Notes Indenture provides for certain events of default, including, among others, defaults under other debt instruments that (i) are caused by the failure to pay principal of, or interest or premium, if any, on indebtedness at its stated maturity prior to the expiration of the applicable grace period provided or (ii) result in the acceleration of such indebtedness prior to its maturity, and, in each case, the principal amount of such indebtedness (together with the principal amount of any other such indebtedness under which there has been a payment default or the maturity of which has been accelerated) aggregates £20.0 million or more. The Existing Notes Indenture and the Existing Notes are governed by the laws of the State of New York. The Existing Notes are listed on the Official List of the Exchange and have been accepted for clearing and settlement via the facilities of Euroclear and Clearstream under ISIN XS2052467110 (Rule 144A) and XS2289855970 (Regulation S).

To establish the relative rights of certain of our creditors under our financing arrangements, the Issuer and the Guarantors entered into the intercreditor agreement dated November 29, 2017 (the “Intercreditor

Subsection Title: Agreement”) with, among others, the facility agent, arrangers and lenders under our Revolving Credit Facility
Subsubsection Text: _Priority of Debts_ The Intercreditor Agreement provides that the liabilities owed by the Issuer, the Company and each other debtor under the Intercreditor Agreement (together, the “Debtors”) (other than any member of the ICA Group which is designated as a Topco/Senior Unsecured Borrower/Issuer under the Intercreditor Agreement (a ----- “Topco/Senior Unsecured Borrower/Issuer”)) shall rank in right of priority and payment in the following order and are postponed and subordinated to any prior ranking liabilities as follows: (i) first, liabilities owed to (i) the lenders, issuing banks and ancillary lenders in relation to any future senior secured facilities agreements (a “Permitted Senior Secured Facilities

Subsection Title: Agreement”) with, among others, the facility agent, arrangers and lenders under our Revolving Credit Facility
Subsubsection Text: Agreement and the Security Agent. The Trustee acceded to the Intercreditor Agreement on September 25, 2019 in connection with the issue of the 2025 Notes. By accepting a Note, holders of the Notes will be deemed to have agreed to, and accepted the terms and conditions of, the Intercreditor Agreement and shall be deemed to have appointed and authorized the Trustee to act on its behalf and comply with the provisions of the Intercreditor Agreement. The Intercreditor Agreement is governed by English law and sets out various matters governing the relationship of the creditors to our group including the relative ranking of certain debt of the Issuer, the Guarantors and any other person that becomes party to the Intercreditor Agreement as a Debtor or Third Party Security Provider, when payments can be made in respect of debt of the Debtors or Third Party Security Providers, when enforcement action can be taken in respect of that debt, the terms pursuant to which certain of that debt will be subordinated upon the occurrence of certain insolvency events and turnover provisions and provisions related to the enforcement of shared security. The following description is a summary of certain provisions contained in the Intercreditor Agreement. It does not restate the Intercreditor Agreement in its entirety and we urge you to read that document because it, and not the discussion that follows, defines certain rights of the holders of the Notes and of the Trustee. Capitalized terms used but not defined herein have the meanings given to them in the Intercreditor Agreement. For the purposes of this description: “ICA Group” shall mean the Issuer, the Company and any of the Company’s Restricted Subsidiaries. References to the “Notes” shall include the Notes and any other notes, securities or other debt instruments issued or to be issued by a member of the ICA Group which are designated by the Company as Senior Secured Notes under (and as defined in) the Intercreditor Agreement.

Subsection Title: Agreement”) (the “Senior Lender Liabilities”), (ii) the lenders, issuing banks, and ancillary
Subsubsection Text: lenders in relation to the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement or any future super senior facilities agreement (a “Permitted Super Senior Secured Facilities Agreement” and the liabilities being referred to as the “Super Senior Lender Liabilities”) and any hedge counterparty under a hedging agreement (a “Hedge Counterparty”) that is designated by the Company as super senior (together the “Super Senior Liabilities” and creditors thereof being the “Super Senior Creditors”), (iii) the Trustee and any trustee in relation to future senior secured notes (each a “Senior Secured Notes Trustee”) (other than certain amounts paid to it in its capacity as trustee), the holders of the Notes or future senior secured notes (the “Senior

Subsection Title: Secured Notes”) and the Security Agent in relation to the Senior Secured Notes (the “Senior Secured Notes Liabilities”), (iv) the lender under the loan made by the Issuer to the Company
Subsubsection Text: and any future loan made by the issuer of any Senior Secured Notes (if so designated by the Company in its discretion and not including, for the avoidance of doubt, the Issuer) to a member of the Group for the purposes of on lending the proceeds of any Senior Secured Notes together with any additional or replacement loan made on substantially the same terms (the “Senior

Subsection Title: Secured Notes Proceeds Loan Liabilities”), (v) the arrangers, agents, issuing banks and
Subsubsection Text: lenders under any cash management facility (a “Cash Management Facility” and the liabilities under a Cash Management Facility being the “Cash Management Facility Liabilities”), (vi) the Hedge Counterparties in relation to any hedging agreement that are not Super Senior Liabilities (together with the hedging designated by the Company as being Super Senior Liabilities, the “Hedging Liabilities”), (vii) the lenders in relation to any future second lien facility agreement (a “Second Lien Facility” and the liabilities to the lenders under a Second Lien Facility being the “Second Lien Lender Liabilities”), (viii) any second lien notes trustee (other than certain amounts paid to it in its capacity as trustee), the holders of any future second lien notes and the Security Agent in relation to any second lien notes (such second lien notes being “Second Lien Notes” and the liabilities in respect of such Second Lien Notes being the “Second Lien Notes Liabilities” and together with the Second Lien Lender Liabilities, the “Second Lien Liabilities”), (ix) any agent or trustee under any finance documents relating to any of the aforementioned liabilities, any agent or trustee under the Topco/Senior Unsecured Liabilities (as defined below) and to any agent or trustee in relation to certain other unsecured liabilities (together the “Agent Liabilities”) and (x) the Security Agent, pari passu and without any preference between them; and (ii) _second, all liabilities owed (i) to the trustee (other than certain amounts paid to it in its capacity as trustee), and the holders of any future notes issued by a Topco/Senior Unsecured Borrower/Issuer and designated by the Company as Topco/Senior Unsecured Notes (the “Topco/Senior Unsecured Notes Liabilities”), (ii) under any future loan facility made available to any Topco/Senior Unsecured Borrower/Issuer (the “Topco/Senior Unsecured

Subsection Title: Facility Liabilities” and together with the Topco/Senior Unsecured Notes Liabilities, the
Subsubsection Text: “Topco/Senior Unsecured Liabilities”), and (iii) the liabilities owed under any future loan (a “Topco/Senior Unsecured Proceeds Loan”) made by any Topco/Senior Unsecured Borrower/Issuer for the purpose of on lending the proceeds of any Topco/Senior Unsecured Notes or Topco/Senior Unsecured Loans (the “Topco/Senior Unsecured Proceeds Loan

Subsection Title: Liabilities”), pari passu and without any preference between them.
Subsubsection Text: The Intercreditor Agreement provides that the liabilities owed by any Topco/Senior Unsecured Borrower/Issuer to the Secured Parties (as defined below) shall rank pari passu in right and priority of payment and without any preference between them in respect of (i) the Senior Lender Liabilities, (ii) the Super Senior Liabilities, (iii) the Senior Secured Notes Liabilities, (iv) the Cash Management Facility Liabilities, (v) the Hedging Liabilities, (vi) the Second Lien Lender Liabilities, (vii) the Second Lien Notes Liabilities, (viii) the Topco/Senior Unsecured Liabilities, (ix) the Topco/Senior Unsecured Proceeds Loan Liabilities, and (x) the Agent Liabilities. The Intercreditor Agreement provides that the intra-group liabilities owed by one member of the ICA Group to another member of the ICA Group (other than any Senior Secured Notes Proceeds Loan Liabilities or Topco/Senior Unsecured Proceeds Loan Liabilities) (the “Intra-Group Liabilities”) will be subordinated to the ----- liabilities owed by the Debtors and Third Party Security Providers to the creditors under the Senior Lender Liabilities, Super Senior Lender Liabilities, Senior Secured Notes Liabilities, Cash Management Facility Liabilities, Hedging Liabilities, Second Lien Lender Liabilities and Second Lien Notes Liabilities, Agent Liabilities and Notes Liabilities (such creditors, together with the Security Agent, the Trustee, any receiver or delegate, any creditor of the Agent Liabilities and any arranger with respect to the Secured Liabilities, the “Secured Parties”). The Intercreditor Agreement also provides that the liabilities owed by any member of the ICA Group (other than any Topco/Senior Unsecured Proceeds Loan Liabilities) to a holding company of the Company or to any other person who becomes a subordinated creditor (a “Subordinated Creditor”) under the Intercreditor Agreement (the “Subordinated Liabilities”) will be subordinated to the liabilities owed by the Debtors and Third Party Security Providers to the Secured Parties and to the Intra-Group Liabilities. For the purposes of this description only: “Debt Documents” means the Intercreditor Agreement and the documents creating or evidencing the Cash Management Facility Liabilities, the Hedging Liabilities, the Second Lien Liabilities, the Senior Secured Liabilities, any Senior Secured Notes Proceeds Loan Liabilities (a “Senior Secured Notes Proceeds Loan

Subsection Title: Agreement”), the Topco/Senior Unsecured Liabilities, the Topco/Senior Unsecured Proceeds Loan Liabilities,
Subsubsection Text: the unsecured liabilities of any unsecured creditors who are party to the Intercreditor Agreement, the Subordinated Liabilities and the Intra-Group Liabilities (each as defined in this description). “Finance Documents” means the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement, any Permitted Senior Secured Facilities Agreement, any Permitted Super Senior Secured Facilities Agreement, the indenture in respect of any Senior Secured Notes, the facility agreement documenting any Second Lien Facility, the indenture in respect of any Second Lien Notes, the facility documenting any Topco/Senior Unsecured Facility, the indenture in respect of any Topco/Senior Unsecured Notes and any document designated by the Company as an unsecured finance document under and in accordance with the Intercreditor Agreement. “Secured Creditors” means the Senior Secured Creditors, Second Lien Creditors and the Topco/Senior Unsecured Creditors (each as defined below). “Secured Debt Documents” means the documents relating to the Senior Secured Liabilities, Second Lien Liabilities and Topco/Senior Unsecured Liabilities. “Third Party Security Provider” means Picture Holdco Limited and any person that has provided Transaction Security (including Topco/Senior Unsecured Shared Security) but is not a Debtor in respect of any direct borrowing or guarantee liabilities of the applicable secured obligations to which that Transaction Security relates designated by the Company (in its discretion). “Topco/Senior Unsecured Shared Security” refers to security at any time which is created, or expressed to be created, over (i) the shares in the Company held by any direct shareholder of the Company, (ii) all receivables owed to a Topco/Senior Unsecured Investor, Subordinated Creditor or other Holding Company or shareholder of the Company by the Company, (iii) the shares in any issuer of Senior Secured Notes and any Topco/Senior Unsecured Notes Borrower/Issuer which is a member of the ICA Group, (iv) all receivables owed by a member of the ICA Group under any Senior Secured Notes Proceeds Loan or Topco/Senior Unsecured Proceeds Loan, and (v) any other assets not falling within limbs (i), (ii), (iii) and (iv) of this paragraph of a Topco/Senior Unsecured Borrower/Issuer which is a member of the ICA Group, in each case to the extent provided for by the Topco/Senior Unsecured Finance Documents at any time and designated as Topco/Senior Unsecured Shared Security by the Company (in its discretion) in favour of the Security Agent as agent or trustee for the other Secured Parties (or if such trustee arrangements are not legally possible, in favour of all the Secured Parties or in favour of the Security Agent under a parallel debt or similar structure). Topco/Senior Unsecured Shared Security shall secure all liabilities and present and future obligations of each Topco/Senior Unsecured Borrower/Issuer and its Restricted Subsidiaries (as defined in the documents governing the relevant Topco/Senior Unsecured Notes or Topco/Senior Unsecured Facility (as the case may be)) and any other members of the ICA Group (the “Topco/Senior Unsecured Group”), each Debtor and each Third Party Security Provider to the Secured Parties under the Debt Documents. “Topco/Senior Unsecured Independent Transaction Security” refers to security (other than Topco/Senior Unsecured Shared Security) which is created, or expressed to be created, by any Topco/Senior Unsecured Borrower/Issuer or its affiliates (in each case, other than a member of the ICA Group) and designated ----- as such by the Company (in its discretion) (together, the “Topco/Senior Unsecured Independent Obligors”) in favour of the Security Agent as agent or trustee for the other Topco/Senior Unsecured Secured Parties (or if such trustee arrangements are not legally possible, in favour of all the Topco/Senior Unsecured Secured Parties or in favour of the Security Agent under a parallel debt or similar structure). Topco/Senior Unsecured Independent Transaction Security shall secure all liabilities and present and future obligations of each Topco/Senior Unsecured Independent Obligor to the Topco/Senior Unsecured Secured Parties under the Topco/Senior Unsecured Finance Documents. “Transaction Security” refers to security (from the ICA Group, any Third Party Security Provider and Topco/Senior Unsecured Shared Security, as defined below) which is created, or expressed to be created, in favour of the Security Agent as agent or trustee for the other Secured Parties (or if such trustee arrangements are not legally possible, in favour of all the Secured Parties or in favour of the Security Agent under a parallel debt or similar structure). Transaction Security which is not Topco/Senior Unsecured Shared Security shall secure all liabilities and present and future obligations of the Debtors and Third Party Security Providers to the Secured Parties (other than the creditors under the Topco/Senior Unsecured Liabilities (the “Topco/Senior Unsecured

Subsection Title: Secured Parties”)) under the Debt Documents (other than the finance documents relating to the Topco/Senior
Subsubsection Text: Unsecured Liabilities (the “Topco/Senior Unsecured Finance Documents”)). The Senior Secured Notes and the Senior Secured Notes Guarantee will be Senior Secured Notes Liabilities for the purposes of the Intercreditor Agreement. On the Issue Date, no Senior Lender Liabilities, Second Lien Lender Liabilities, Second Lien Notes Liabilities or Topco/Senior Unsecured Notes Liabilities will be outstanding. Such liabilities and liabilities in respect of other new debt financings may only be incurred and/or designated if not prohibited under the terms of the Debt Documents, including, without limitation, the covenants applicable to the Notes described under “Description of the Notes—Certain Covenants.” _Guarantees and Security: Topco/Senior Unsecured Creditors_ The creditors in respect of the Topco/Senior Unsecured Liabilities (the “Topco/Senior Unsecured

Subsection Title: Creditors”) have the right to take, accept or receive the benefit of:
Subsubsection Text: The Intercreditor Agreement provides, subject to certain conditions, for the implementation of existing, additional, supplemental or new financing arrangements that will constitute, for the purposes of the Intercreditor Agreement, Senior Lender Liabilities, Senior Secured Notes Liabilities, Cash Management Facility Liabilities, Hedging Liabilities, Second Lien Liabilities, Topco/Senior Unsecured Liabilities, Super Senior Liabilities or Hedging Liabilities (each a “New Debt Financing”). The conditions include certification by the Company that such New Debt Financing is not prohibited under the terms of the Finance Documents. Such financing arrangements may be implemented by way of refinancing, replacement, exchange, setoff, discharge or increase of any such new, existing, additional, supplemental or new financing arrangement under the relevant finance documents. In connection with and in order to facilitate any New Debt Financing, each agent in respect of any Priority Secured Liabilities and the Security Agent (and each other person party to a Transaction Security document or a Topco/Senior Unsecured Independent Transaction Security document) is authorized and instructed to enter promptly into any new security document, amend or waive any term of an existing security document and/or release any asset from the Transaction Security or Topco/Senior Unsecured Independent Transaction Security (as the case may be) subject to certain conditions, including as regards the terms of such security (which shall be, unless otherwise agreed by the Company, substantially the same as the terms applicable to the existing Transaction Security or Topco/Senior Unsecured Independent Transaction Security over equivalent assets). Where any indebtedness (“Permitted Acquired Indebtedness”) which is not prohibited under the Finance Documents is incurred by or in connection with the acquisition of (i) a person who, after the Issue Date, becomes a Restricted Subsidiary or merges, consolidates or is otherwise combined with a Restricted Subsidiary, or (ii) in relation to an asset of any such person or which is otherwise acquired after the Issue Date (together an “Acquired Person or Asset”), any security, guarantee, indemnity or other assurance in respect of such New Debt Financing which is subsisting at the date when the conditions to the incurrence of such New Debt Financing set out in the Intercreditor Agreement have been satisfied (or is to be granted thereafter, including subject to any condition or periodic testing) shall be permitted to subsist and there is no requirement to offer that security, guarantee, indemnity or other assurance in respect of any other liabilities under any Debt Document. No security, guarantee, indemnity or other assurance is required to be given by any member of the Topco/Senior Unsecured Group in respect of any liabilities (including under any Debt Document) (i) over any Acquired Person or Asset if this would breach a contractual undertaking applicable to the Topco/Senior Unsecured Group or is excluded or exempt from being given under the Agreed Security Principles (as defined in the Revolving Credit Facility ----- Agreement), (ii) over any asset required (including subject to any condition) to provide credit support in relation to any Permitted Acquired Indebtedness (other than as a result of any obligation to extend any Transaction Security rateably for the benefit of such Permitted Acquired Indebtedness), or (iii) where the grant of such security, guarantee, indemnity or other assurance is prevented by the documentation relation to such Permitted Acquired Indebtedness or would give rise to an obligation (including any payment obligation but not including any obligation to extend any Transaction Security rateably for the benefit of such Permitted Acquired Indebtedness) under or in relation thereto.

Subsection Title: Creditors”) have the right to take, accept or receive the benefit of:
Subsubsection Text: _Permitted Payments in Respect of the Senior and Super Senior Debt_ The Debtors and Third Party Security Providers may make payment in respect of the Senior Lender Liabilities, Senior Secured Notes Liabilities, Super Senior Liabilities and Cash Management Facility Liabilities (together with the Hedging Liabilities, the “Senior Secured Creditor Liabilities,” the creditors in respect thereof being the “Senior Secured Creditors”) at any time, provided that following certain acceleration events under any Permitted Senior Secured Facilities Agreement or Senior Secured Notes Indenture or Permitted Super Senior Secured Facilities Agreement or Cash Management Facility document or following certain insolvency events in relation to a member of the ICA Group, payments may only be made by Debtors or Third Party Security Providers and received by creditors in accordance with the provisions described below under “—Application of Proceeds” provided that there shall be no obligation to turnover any such payments received, other than those related to an enforcement of Transaction Security or a Distressed Disposal (as defined below) of assets subject to the Transaction Security. Any failure to make a payment in accordance with the Senior Secured Finance Documents following an acceleration event as required by the ICA shall not prevent the occurrence of an event of default under such applicable Senior Secured Finance Documents. _Permitted Payments in Respect of the Second Lien Debt_ Prior to the first date on which all of the Senior Liabilities, the Super Senior Liabilities and the Senior Secured Notes Liabilities (together, the “Senior Secured Liabilities” and together with the Second Lien Liabilities and Topco/Senior Unsecured Liabilities being the “Secured Liabilities”) have been discharged (the “Senior Secured Discharge Date”), the Debtors may only make specified scheduled payments in respect of the Second Lien Liabilities, in accordance with the finance documents governing such Second Lien Liabilities, subject to compliance with certain conditions in the Intercreditor Agreement. The principal conditions are that the relevant payment is not prohibited by any prior ranking financing agreement, including any Permitted Super Senior Secured Facilities Agreement, Permitted Senior Secured Facilities Agreement and any Senior Secured Notes Indenture (or if it is so prohibited, that all necessary consents have been obtained to permit it), no payment stop notice has been issued to the agent or trustee for the relevant Second Lien Liabilities and no payment default (subject to a de minimis threshold in the case of amounts other than principal, interest or certain fees) is continuing under any Permitted Senior Secured Facilities Agreement, Permitted Super Senior Secured Facilities Agreement, Cash Management Facility document or Senior Secured Notes document. Certain specified payments in respect of Second Lien Liabilities are also permitted at all times, notwithstanding that a payment stop notice is outstanding or such a payment default is continuing. These payments and basket amounts are substantially similar to those referenced for Topco Liabilities in (ii) of the next paragraph. _Permitted Payments in Respect of Topco/Senior Unsecured Liabilities_ Prior to the date which is the later of the Senior Secured Discharge Date and the first date (the “Second

Subsection Title: Creditors”) have the right to take, accept or receive the benefit of:
Subsubsection Text: (i) Topco/Senior Unsecured Shared Security from any member of the ICA Group or from a Third Party Security Provider in respect of the Topco/Senior Unsecured Liabilities if and to the extent legally possible and subject to any agreed security principles, and at the same time it is also offered either: (A) to the Security Agent as agent or trustee for the other Secured Parties (or applicable class thereof) in respect of their liabilities; or (B) in the case of any jurisdiction in which effective Security cannot be granted in favour of the Security Agent as agent or trustee for the Secured Parties (or applicable class thereof): (1) to the other Secured Parties (or applicable class thereof) in respect of their liabilities; or (2) to the Security Agent under a parallel debt structure, joint and several creditor structure or agency structure for the benefit of the other Secured Parties (or applicable class thereof), and ranks in the same order of priority as described under “—Priority of Debts” above, provided that all amounts received or recovered by any Topco/Senior Unsecured Creditor with respect to such Topco/Senior Unsecured Shared Security are immediately paid to the Security Agent and held and applied as set out under “Application of Proceeds” below; and (ii) any guarantee, indemnity or other assurance from any member of the ICA Group in respect of the Topco/Senior Unsecured Liabilities in addition to any guarantee, indemnity or assurance in the original form of any Topco/Senior Unsecured Finance Documents or the Intercreditor Agreement, or given to all the Secured Parties as security for the liabilities of the Topco/Senior Unsecured Group, each Debtor and any Third Party Security Provider to the Secured Parties under the Debt Documents if, subject to any agreed security principles: ----- (A) (except for any guarantee, indemnity or other assurance permitted by the Finance Documents), the Secured Parties other than the Topco/Senior Unsecured Creditors (the “Priority Secured Parties”) already benefit from such a guarantee, indemnity or other assurance or at the same time it is also offered to the Priority Secured Parties and ranks in the same order of priority as described under “—Priority of Debts” above; and (B) all amounts received by any Topco/Senior Unsecured Creditor with respect to such guarantee, indemnity or assurance are paid to the Security Agent for application as set out under “—Application of Proceeds” below; and (iii) any security, guarantee indemnity or other assurance from any member of the Topco/Senior Unsecured Group: (A) in connection with any escrow or similar arrangements relating to amounts held by a person which is not a member of the Topco/Senior Unsecured Group prior to release of those amounts to a member of the Topco/Senior Unsecured Group; (B) in connection with any actual or proposed defeasance, redemption, prepayment, repayment, purchase or other discharge of any Secured Liabilities not prohibited by the Intercreditor Agreement; or (C) as otherwise permitted by the Intercreditor Agreement. No security (other than pursuant to the secured documents relating to Topco/Senior Unsecured Independent Transaction Security or Topco/Senior Unsecured Shared Security or as described above) shall be granted by a member of the ICA Group in respect of any Topco/Senior Unsecured Liabilities.

Subsubsection Text: specified scheduled payments (including any other direct or indirect step, matter, action or dealing in relation to any Topco/Senior Unsecured Liabilities otherwise prohibited under the Intercreditor Agreement) under the Topco/Senior Unsecured Liabilities or under any Topco/Senior Unsecured Proceeds Loan (together the “Topco/Senior Unsecured Group Liabilities”) to the Topco/Senior Unsecured Creditors or any holding company of the Company or other lender in respect of a Topco/Senior Unsecured Proceeds Loan (in respect of ----- the Topco/Senior Unsecured Proceeds Loan Liabilities only) (such payments, collectively, “Permitted

(i) if: (A) no Topco/Senior Unsecured Payment Stop Notice (as defined below) is outstanding; (B) no payment default (subject to a _de minimis threshold in the case of amounts other than principal, interest or certain fees) has occurred and is continuing under any Permitted Senior Secured Facilities Agreement, Permitted Super Senior Secured Facilities Agreement, Cash Management Facility document or Senior Secured Notes document (a “Senior Secured

Subsection Title: Payment Default”), or under the Second Lien Facilities or Second Lien Notes (a “Second Lien Payment Default”); and
Subsubsection Text: (C) the payment is (1) of any amount of principal or capitalized interest in respect of the Topco/Senior Unsecured Liabilities which is not prohibited by any prior ranking financing agreements (in respect of the Senior Secured Liabilities and the Second Lien Liabilities), or any required consents to permit such payment have been obtained, (2) of any other amount which is not an amount of principal or capitalized interest (such other amounts including all scheduled interest payments (including, if applicable, special interest (or liquidated damages))) and default interest on the Topco/Senior Unsecured Liabilities accrued and payable in cash in accordance with the terms of the relevant Topco/Senior Unsecured Finance Document (as of the date of the issue of the same or as amended in accordance with the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement and the other Debt Documents), additional amounts payable as a result of the tax gross-up provisions relating to Topco/Senior Unsecured Liabilities and amounts in respect of currency indemnities in any Topco/Senior Unsecured Finance Document, (3) made in pursuance of a debt buyback programme whose establishment was not prohibited by any Permitted Super Senior Secured Facilities Agreement, any Permitted Senior Secured Facilities Agreement, any indenture in respect of Senior Secured Notes or Second Lien Notes Facilities Agreement, any Permitted Senior Secured Facilities Agreement, any indenture in respect of Senior Secured Notes or Second Lien Notes or any agreement documenting a Second Lien Facility has been obtained for the establishment of such debt buy-back programme, or (4) of amounts due under any fee or syndication strategy letter relating to the Topco/Senior Unsecured Finance Documents; (ii) if, notwithstanding that a Topco/Senior Unsecured Payment Stop Notice (as defined below) is outstanding and/or (other than in respect of paragraph (G) and (M) below) a Senior Secured Payment Default and/or a Second Lien Payment Default has occurred and is continuing and (if the Topco/Senior Unsecured Borrower/Issuer is a guarantor or borrower under any prior ranking debt facilities at such time,
